PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

TAB.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 19 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 39 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government—
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish—
the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a)establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b)limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c)control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest
(d)increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 91
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a)outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b)lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c)cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Fee Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
(ii)call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 91
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ukrainian Independence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: (1)That Ukraine, a nation of 53 millions, one of the ten largest economic entities in the world, with a land area the size of France, and a foundation member of the United Nations, which suffered 7 million dead in the forced famine engineered by Moscow in 1932-33, 6 million dead at the hands of the Nazis in World War 2 and an as yet unknown number of deaths from the nuclear fallout of Chernobyl, declared its independence on August 24, 1991.

(2)That the Ukrainian Government has exercised its sovereignty by nationalising assets of the Communist Party and taking control of industries and resources on the territory of Ukraine, appointing a Minister of Defence, establishing a defence force, taking steps to introduce a national currency, beginning the withdrawal of Soviet nuclear weapons from Ukrainian soil, and concluding treaties with neighbouring countries such as Poland and Hungary.
As Ukraine has demonstrated control of its territory, we call upon the Senate and the Australian Government to immediately consider:
(a)recognition of the declaration of Ukrainian independence, and
(b)establishment of an Australian diplomatic mission in Kiev.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days from today, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321 and made under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement on the Committee's concerns with these regulations.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is concerned that the regulations under the Freedom of Information Act appear to provide a period of five years during which the public is automatically denied access to important material, without any procedure to require a Minister to make even an adverse decision. The regulations under the Trade Practices Act cause less concern. However, they will have an impact on Australian business and in all such cases it is usual for the Committee to seek extensive assurances about the effect of such impact. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the aspects of these regulations raised by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: TRADE PRACTICES (CONSUMER PRODUCT INFORMATION STANDARDS)(COSMETICS) REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.327

These Regulations provide for the labelling of cosmetic products to indicate the ingredients used in those products. The Explanatory Statement advises that a number of people may be sensitive to certain of these ingredients. The Regulations are intended to satisfy consumer requests for information about ingredients, enable value comparisons between products and enable consumers to avoid ingredients to which they may be allergic. The Regulations are closely aligned with United States requirements in this area. It is believed that the European Community will also move to align itself with United States standards.

PARA.TAB: The Committee does not raise questions about the policy merits of these or any other instruments of delegated legislation. Rather it confines its examination to ensuring that such instruments comply with its high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal liberties.

In this context the Committee noted that the present Regulations provide important safeguards for those affected by them. Thus, there is a full right of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of adverse decisions by the Minister in respect of the administration of the scheme. Also, the Regulations do not come into effect until 31 October 1993, which is more than two years after the Regulations were made. On the face of it this is a reasonable lead time period for those people whose businesses may be affected by the changes.

Nevertheless, the Committee always looks carefully at any instrument which affects Australian business or modifies the way in which people may earn their livelihood. The Committee has received a representation that the present Regulations may be uncertain and confusing in effect, due to the number of different ways in which ingredients can be described.

The Committee has passed the representation on to the Minister for consideration. We have also asked the Committee's legal adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan, to prepare a special report on the Regulations. In the meantime, the purpose of this notice is simply to ensure that the matter is kept on the agenda of the Committee. It does not necessarily indicate that we have substantial difficulties with the Regulations at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1991 No.321

PARA.TAB: The parent Freedom of Information Act 1982 (the FOI Act) provides that certificates may be issued which conclusively determine that material in documents is exempt from public disclosure under the Act. These certificates may cover material relating to national security, defence or international relations; relations with the States; cabinet; the executive council; or internal working documents. Section 36A of the FOI Act, which was inserted by the Freedom of Information Amendment Act 1991, provides that the Regulations may provide maximum periods during which such certificates may remain in force and may provide for the manner in which they are revoked.

The present Regulations provide that these conclusive exemption certificates, which exclude public disclosure, remain in force for five years. However, they may be revoked earlier by the Minister or the Secretary to the Department or agency.

This period of five years appears lengthy. There is no explanation in the Explanatory Statement why five years was chosen as the appropriate period. The Committee is concerned that this period should be reasonable, and half a decade may be excessive, particularly for internal working documents. Now, under the new s.36A of the FOI Act, if a certificate is given in respect of s.36 (and, of course, the other relevant sections) material then apparently the public is automatically denied access to the material for five years.

The Committee appreciates that the Minister or Secretary may revoke a certificate. However, it is not clear whether there is any process for the public to request a revocation and whether there is appropriate AAT review if such a request is refused. The Committee would be concerned if it was not intended to establish such a process. As drafted, it appears that the public may be shut out of the process for five years.

The Committee will write to the Minister seeking further details. In particular, it will seek advice on whether public participation has been diluted by the Regulations and whether it is intended to provide for the public to initiate any revocation procedures.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 4 December.
Clause 16.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is dealing with clause 16 of the Bill. Senator Parer has moved Opposition amendment No. 18. It might be a reasonable idea for the Committee to go through the Bill from there on and then go back to the parts that we have missed out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I had moved amendment No. 18 and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) had just got to his feet to comment on it. I would like to comment briefly. We are picking up halfway through an amendment and it is understandable that there is a little confusion. We address two items relating to offences in our proposed amendment No. 18. The amendment reads:

PARA.TAB: Where a person furnishes a statement. . .

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister suggested that `statement' should be changed to `return'. We would accept that amendment. Our amendment reads:

PARA.TAB: Where a person . . . is required to furnish under Division 5A that contains particulars that are, to the knowledge of the person, false or misleading. . . punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding $5,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister stated that under the Government's amendment the penalty is $10,000. We would be happy to accept that amendment. That is the first part.

PARA.TAB: The second part, about which we are very concerned, relates to discrimination against a donor to a political party when that donation is made known because of disclosure. The other side of the coin is where a person or a body is coerced into making a donation to a political party. We believe that this matter relating to disclosure is a very real problem. It is the area that Dr Hewson drew attention to when the coalition parties took the view that they would accept disclosure. One of the major conditions was that people in society were protected against discrimination. It is a very real concern in the hearts and minds of many people. To give some teeth to protection against discrimination and coercion, we recommended in our amendment that, if the offender is a natural person, the fine would be $5,000 or imprisonment for two years or both, and, if the offender is a body corporate, the fine would be $20,000.

The reason for the level of the fine in both cases was to act as a deterrent to people going into the grubby business of intimidation. The reason for the two years imprisonment was to make sure, within the terms of our Federal Constitution, that if a person was convicted of this sort of thing he would be precluded from ever standing for Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated last night, the Government does not support this amendment.
—Why ever not?

—There are two reasons. First of all, there is a problem with the drafting of the Opposition amendment. I am sure, once again, it would not have been deliberate, but I do point this out as one of the two reasons why the Government is not supporting this proposal.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition amendment applies only to discrimination where a person has made a donation to a registered political party. The Government proposal will make illegal discrimination where a person involved is one who makes a donation to any political party, whether registered or not. As I say, it may not have been intentional on the part of the Opposition, but at least our parameters are broader in that respect and more people would be protected in these circumstances where some people have concern that there might be political intimidation.

Another aspect is that we feel the penalty provisions that we are proposing are appropriate and adequate; they are in conformity with the principles that apply to penalties that have been applied consistently across the spectrum of Commonwealth offences. The penalties under the Bill are $1,000 or six months imprisonment. I think six months imprisonment is a fair enough whack in itself, and any person who may be involved in this sort of activity would be quite deserving of it.

The other penalty which is important to take into account here is that offenders who offend under the Opposition's proposals would, ipso facto, under section 44(i) of the Constitution, be ineligible, for ever, to run for Parliament. Given the fact that there is a $1,000 penalty or six months imprisonment under our proposal, the further penalty for life against standing for parliament may be a big one—though I must admit, having gone through the last two days, it may be something people would appreciate, in one sense. We think the penalties in our proposal are adequate but, more importantly, our proposal covers a wider spectrum of possible offences as opposed to the Opposition's.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that, we are happy to make the net as broad as possible to catch anyone who would engage in what I believe is something that is totally unacceptable; certainly it is totally unacceptable to the Opposition and I am sure it is totally unacceptable to the Democrats. In the interests of doing that, we would be prepared to remove the word `registered' from the term `political party' so that it applies to all political parties throughout the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the Minister considers that the penalties we are proposing are too great. Evidence was given to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures on the issue of this sort of intimidation. I remind the Senate of the evidence that Mr Sherry gave to the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: On two separate occasions, purely as a result . . . of the threat my research, which was turning into a book . . . I was warned by Bob Hendricks, the State Secretary of the Electrical Trades Union of Queensland. He did not touch me but he threatened me with physical harm. On both of those occasions I took notes of it. On one of those occasions I taped one of the phone calls.
He went on to say:
This is a record that I made of it. At 4.20 p.m. on 7 August 1990, Bob Hendricks, the State Secretary of the Queensland Branch of the ETU, said that my book did not have the support of the ETU:
`If you're trying to fix the Union, then why should I help you? If I find out you're trying to fix the Union, then don't worry, I'll fix you good and proper, good and proper.
Two days later Bob Hendricks elaborated on the threat—and I quote again:

If I had evidence of that, that's what I'd do. When I say fix you, yes, I didn't say fix you, I said fit you. F-I-T. And that means fit you. And I mean by fit, I mean, quite bluntly, well, you can work it out for yourself. I used the word fit. And I guess that I'd become, I may become violent. Because I am not appreciative of people doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not a violent person.
—We have Senator Burns saying that this Bob Hendricks is not a violent person. Good heavens, I hope the Democrats are listening to this. He is saying that Hendricks is not a violent person.
—I know the man and that is true.

—He knows the man and he will guarantee that. But this is a taped recording of his threat over the telephone. We have Senator Schacht, Senator Faulkner and Senator Aulich saying, `Don't you know it's illegal to tape telephone conversations?'. That is how this crew works. This bloke said, `I feared for my life'—
—Do you support illegal taping?
—We have Senator Burns saying that it is illegal to tape a telephone conversation. They reminded the witness that it is illegal to tape a telephone conversation.
—Don't you know that?

—And I am asked, do I not know that. I can assure Senator Schacht that, if he were on the other end of the phone telling me he would fix me, I would tape it too. Mr Sherry said—and I just hope members of the public in the gallery can understand what the Labor Party is doing—that the union was threatening him, he feared for his life, so he taped the telephone conversation. Yet Labor senators said to Mr Sherry, `You shouldn't have; it's illegal to do so'—not horror, horror, about the threat; just, `It's illegal to do so'.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) is saying that our penalty in this clause for intimidation is too great because it seeks to debar someone for life from entering politics. Quite frankly, that sort of intimidation is extreme. And do not let us forget that, after I read out that quote the other day, Senator Cook interjected, `What's wrong with that?'; so he did not think there was much wrong with that telephone conversation. We, on this side of the chamber, think there is a lot wrong with it.

Senator Bolkus today has underlined his belief that there is nothing very wrong with it. He believes that our penalties are too great; that someone should not be debarred for life from entering this Parliament. I do not agree with the Minister in any way at all. I believe that that is the very least we should do in respect of someone who indulges in that sort of intimidation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter the debate on this clause. However, in view of the fact that Senator Walters, in referring to the evidence given to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Disclosures quoted the remarks of Mr Sherry and, in doing so, named the people he made allegations against, I think it only appropriate that I should put on the record the fact that the Select Committee wrote to all the members so named in Mr Sherry's evidence, bringing to their attention the allegations made in that evidence so that they would have the opportunity to respond accordingly. Already some have responded with affidavits, which have been tabled.

PARA.TAB: I point out that, as this evidence by Mr Sherry was given towards the end of the Select Committee's period of existence, those citizens who were named, if they so chose, can put forward material to refute Mr Sherry's allegations through the Standing Committee of Privileges of this Parliament, so it can be put on the record. It should be noted that Senator Walters accepts absolutely the allegations made by Mr Sherry. It is her right to do so. However, they are allegations and, so far, the people who have responded completely deny them and have done so in the form of sworn affidavits.

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be no-one in this Parliament who does not agree that there has been, is, or is the potential for, intimidation. The Opposition's amendment seeks to protect people. I am not going to get into a debate with Senator Schacht about this. I simply wish to say that our amendment seeks to protect individuals. Anyone who believes in human rights and the ability of people freely to go about Australia and make contributions to whomever they like would agree that they should be entitled to do so. If they breach that, they should be subject to the harshest penalties, and that is what this amendment is about.

—We should limit ourselves to a discussion of the principle. There is a question mark over the Committee's view as to whether it had sufficient evidence of intimidation, leaving aside Mr Sherry. The principle is a very serious matter. The Opposition's amendments aim to provide a strong deterrent. It has brought the penalty into line by changing it to $10,000. I guess there is an argument that $1,000, not six months gaol, may not be a sufficient deterrent. It is very hard to argue that somebody who would engage in such behaviour would be a suitable candidate for Parliament. On the principle of this amendment, I indicate the Democrats' support.
—It is necessary that I make a short statement as a result of the scurrilous attack by Senator Walters on a fine trade unionist, Bob Hendricks, a friend of mine whom I have known for 20 years.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The ETU never voted for me in a pre-selection.
—They don't vote for you?

—No. What I say comes from the heart and from a position of integrity and knowledge, which is quite different from Senator Walters, who does not even know the man. I have known Bob Hendricks for more than 20 years. He has struggled very hard on behalf of trade unionists and those who have been oppressed in this nation. He has been a conservationist since he was a young man. He loves nothing more than to walk in the bush, listen to the birds and observe the birds and the trees. He is really a placid person.

PARA.TAB: During the years I have known him, I have never once heard him make any threat or try to suppress the views of other people. However, I do know that he has been physically threatened and bashed as a result of his work to protect Fraser Island from those who would have logged every last tree and destroyed the island through sandmining. That is the picture of a man who was scurrilously attacked by Senator Walters. I am sure that my description of this person must carry a lot more weight because, as I said, I have known him for 20 years. He is a man to be admired, not to be criticised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Kernot is right. Our clause 21, rather than amendment 21, is being amended by the proposed amendment to section 327. I refer the chamber to page 11 of the Government amendments, particularly amendment No. 36, which deals with interference with political liberty. I suggest that the Opposition amendment replaces the Government's proposed addition to section 327.

PARA.TAB: On page 11 of the Government's amendments, amendment No. 36, `Interference with political liberty etc.', states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Section 327 of the principal Act is amended by inserting before the penalty the following subsection. . .
That subsection is a proscription against hindering or interfering with:
. . . the free exercise by another person of the other person's right to make a gift to a political party, a candidate or a group of candidates. . .

I am suggesting that, instead of the Government's proposal there, we pick up—given the fact that the Democrats are in support of it—subclause 11 of the Opposition's proposal currently before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's desire to have an increased penalty in cases where someone's political liberty is interfered with would then be picked up in the relevant position. I do not know how we do this mechanically.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put Opposition amendment No. 18. If that is not passed, we will wait until we get to Government amendment No. 36. Then, Minister, you would be able to move to put that in its place.

—By way of clarification, the Opposition amendment No. 18—and I should like to get the view of the Democrats on this—contained two parts. One concerned offences; that was clause 16, which amended section 315 of the Act. I understood Senator Kernot to say that the Democrats would accept the Government's position in respect of that.

—We are happy to accept the Minister's proposal for the Opposition's proposed new subsection 11 which applies to intimidation, but the Opposition spokesman was about to speak about the first part, which concerns whether a person knowingly makes false or misleading statements.
—We did that last night.

—This is in relation to disclosure. I think the Minister is proposing that we vote against that part and he would incorporate the Opposition's concerns which are identified at the top of page 7 of the Opposition's amendments in the new part in his amendment No. 36 on page 11 of the Government's amendments. I should like to hear Senator Parer's views on leaving out proposed new subsection (d) of the Opposition's offences section in amendment No. 18.

—I would prefer to leave our clause as it is. I know it is a little hard to envisage when we are preparing this sort of legislation but we felt so seriously about the prospect of intimidation that we thought it should be a very broad net and all encompassing. The words `by subjecting him or her to any other detriment' in proposed new subsection (d) picks up something which at this stage may be somewhat hard to envisage but it certainly broadens the net. The penalties are such that anyone who engages in this sort of practice should be well aware of the fact that it is very broad and encompassing.

—Could the Minister inform us of the principal Act and how it will affect that section because none of us have the principal Act here. I should like to see just how it fits into the principal Act so we understand that there would be nothing in the principal Act that would defeat any of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Walters for the opportunity to do this. At page 233, clause 327 of the principal Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not hinder or interfere with the free exercise or performance, by any other person, of any political right or duty that is relevant to an election under this Act.
That is the principal Act. Our intention in our clause 21—which, to save time, was to be amended—was to amend section 327 to add another subsection which would say:
A person must not hinder or interfere with the free exercise by another person of the other person's right to make a gift to a political party, a candidate or a group of candidates.

Basically, the intention was to add to the existing section 327 a provision that would make illegal any interference with donating to a political party. I am suggesting that we leave section 327 as it is, but that we add after the existing section 327 in the Act a proposed new section 327A, which would encompass the Liberal Party's proposed subclause 11, which is being discussed at the moment. It is not my desired position but, given the fact that the numbers are for it, I would suggest that the Liberal Party's provision against discrimination go in as a proposed new section 327A.

PARA.TAB: We will not support proposed subclause 12. There already exists at law the common law of tort and anyone who suffers damages by such actions would have that access available to him or her. The other problem that I have been advised about with proposed subclause 12 is that there are definitional problems with it. In fact, by its vagueness, it may limit other existing rights. Essentially, there are rights available under the common law of tort. Given the fact that now we will be incorporating provisions that will mean a $5,000 fine, imprisonment of two years and life disqualification from parliament, I suspect the only thing we have not incorporated in this legislation is a public execution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Kernot asked me about proposed subclause 12. While I would agree that there are often avenues available under common law for people to sue for damages, I think this matter is of such great importance that it should be spelt out again here. It reinforces what is available and it seems to me that it strengthens something which I think is vital to the freedom of Australians: to support, contribute or do whatever to any political party in this country.

—I agree with what Senator Parer has said. But I also think that the Minister's summary of what we are imposing in proposed subclause 11 probably is sufficient and I am happy to rely on common law in these circumstances.

—I ask the Minister whether this penalty of not being able to stand for parliament for life is an automatic consequence of the sentence. Is the penalty of $5,000 or two years in gaol provided elsewhere in the Act?
—The Constitution provides that if someone were convicted of an offence and receives, I think, six months penalty—
—One year.
—Sorry, one year's penalty—our provision was 6 months—then he or she is automatically disqualified from standing for parliament for life.

—To sum up, Senator Bolkus has now said he will agree to have our proposed subclause 11 incorporated in his amendment, to which we will agree. The Australian Democrats have indicated that they will not agree to proposed subclause 12, but they will agree to proposed subclause 11. So it seems as though we are all agreed on subclause 11 being incorporated. We would have preferred to see proposed subclause 12 incorporated. However, both the Democrats and the Government will not accept that. Therefore, I suggest we move along with the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 18. After clause 19, page 16, insert the following clause:
"19A. After section 320 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Electoral expenditure by government funded bodies

PARA.TAB: `320A. (1) Where an electoral advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice is authorised by:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)an institution, authority or body (whether incorporated or not) that, in the 3 years preceding the printing, publication or distribution of the advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice, has received financial assistance from the Commonwealth, a State or a local government body; or
(b)a person acting on behalf of such an institution, authority or body;

the institution, authority or body must ensure that the advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice includes a statement in letters not smaller than 10 point stating the total amount of that financial assistance that the institution, authority or body has received in those 3 years and the source of that financial assistance.

PARA.TAB: `(2)Where a press release containing electoral matter is issued by an institution, authority or body to which subsection (1) applies, the institution, authority or body must include the statement required by that subsection in the press release.
`(3)In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "by-election" and "election" have the same meanings as in Division 5A;

PARA.TAB: "electoral advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice" means an advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice that contains electoral matter, but does not include an advertisement in a newspaper announcing the holding of a meeting.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This proposed new clause basically spells out that, where an electoral advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice is authorised by an institutional body which receives any sort of government funding, and it has received that funding in the three years preceding the printing or publication of the handbill, that organisation shall put on the advertisement, handbill or notice a statement in letters not smaller than 10 point stating the total amount of that financial assistance the institution has received in those three years and the source of that financial assistance.

PARA.TAB: The reasoning behind this provision is to prevent the situation, which has been suspected for quite some time—and debated, I know, on both sides—of a government giving handouts, in the main to non-government organisations, and recipients in return supporting that government, of whatever colour, during an election campaign. Claims and counterclaims have been made across this chamber in respect of that. We have had them in regard to organisations such as the ACF and the Greens. We have also had them in regard to road organisations. And so the list goes on. To us, it is proper that there should be a statement to the effect that a handout has been given by a government to a particular organisation. Often handouts have in fact been given after an election.

The argument is that these organisations can contribute from other sources. Well they might. A government handout relieves an organisation of a lot of its administrative costs, whether it be the payment of salaries or some other grant. We are talking about fairness and equity. We are talking about proper disclosure. The Opposition's belief is that, where an organisation is in receipt of handouts, it should come clean and indicate to the public of Australia that it may not be promoting the government of the day, of whatever colour, with clean hands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the Opposition is trying to achieve. I know that many people have question marks over what happens to government grants. The Opposition is really making huge complications for people who are doing things honestly. For example, the Australian Conservation Foundation has a separate electoral fund. Even if it were to receive a grant, as it indicated it has, to take part in the environmentally sustainable development process—obviously it would not use that money for printing election pamphlets—three years after receiving that grant it would still have to print in 10 point on any pamphlet the fact that it had received that money. That catches those organisations unfairly. I understand what the Opposition is trying to do, but I think it is going too far. The Opposition is applying it to press releases, handbills, pamphlets and notices. I am sorry; I think it is going too far and it would be too difficult.

—I have a brief comment on the matters raised by Senator Kernot. One of the tests in this Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is how far we are prepared to go on disclosure. We are saying that if organisations are in receipt of government funds—many of these bodies receive substantial government funds—and they wish to take part in an election, and that is fair enough, they have to disclose where their funding comes from. One of the very dramatic changes which has occurred in the last decade, particularly under this Labor Government, is the vast use of taxpayers' funds to be given to special interest groups. There has been an explosion of instances where taxpayers' funds have been given to various bodies, some of which have been mentioned, such as trade unions and so forth. That is fine.

PARA.TAB: We are not saying that governments at the end of the day have to make those choices. We are saying that if organisations are in receipt of substantial government funds and they wish to take part in an election campaign—we are not quarrelling with that—they have to disclose in small type on press statements, and when they go out and make statements, that they are in receipt of government funding. This is an even-handed proposal. It affects the groups which support us, the groups which support the Australian Labor Party, and the groups which support the Australian Democrats.

In my view there is, quite rightly, increasing community concern about the use of government funding. This is a central matter of disclosure. We are now seeing how far the Government and the Australian Democrats are prepared to proceed down this disclosure road. I think Senator Kernot has at least recognised that there is a problem in this area. She does not appear to recognise that government funds given to particular organisations free up the funds of the organisations for other activities. I urge Senator Kernot to reconsider her position and the position of the Australian Democrats on this very important disclosure issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment. We see it as nothing less than a legalised witch-hunt. That is probably what some members of the Opposition have been on about in respect of these groups for some time now. It is inequitable, it is unfair and it stinks of a witch-hunt. It means that legitimate groups in our community will have to label themselves with the tag of having support from government resources.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is worded in such a way that it would damage enormously a whole range of legitimate organisations out there. Putting direct contact with parliamentarians aside, there are two main ways that people can have their voice heard by government. Firstly, if they have the resources they can contact a lobbyist who knows the ropes and can exercise influence in all sorts of ways. We have seen how they operate around this place. Sometimes on an issue one cannot move two feet without one of them coming in from behind closed doors or whatever.

The other way—and this is the way that community organisations which do not have resources go about it—is to form community groups. Green groups, Aboriginal groups, consumer groups, local child-care centre collectives, local health collectives, women's health groups or whatever represent those in our society who do not have the resources; and they are the groups that effectively run the agenda for those particular community concerns. This is basically the way in which under-resourced sections of our community can have a voice in the process.

What is being asked here is that these groups tag themselves when, quite legitimately, they get government support to make that voice heard. For instance, under this proposal the Salvation Army would have to indicate when conducting appeals that it was receiving government assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is only on electoral stuff.
—It is not. It is very much broader than that. If Care International were running a campaign on child-care—
—It says `electoral advertisement'.

—If the Salvos were running an electoral campaign in respect of poverty, if the Green groups or whatever were running a campaign, if the local child-care collective were running a campaign for more funds for its section of the community, for some strange reason they would all have to put on their press statements, pamphlets or whatever that they get government assistance. These groups legitimately get government assistance and they legitimately spend it. If they do not legitimately spend it, already the Auditor-General has the capacity to go in and see how those funds are spent. Let us get off the witch-hunt; let us get back to the main game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister, in light of that interpretation of the amendment before the Chair, whether he would be prepared to accept a further amendment which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an electoral advertisement, an electoral handbill, an electoral pamphlet or an electoral notice is authorised by:
That would meet his requirements and I am sure that we on this side of the chamber would be happy to propose that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would refer honourable senators to the principal Act which contains a very broad definition of electoral matter. This substantiates what I said about the ambit of this proposal.

—I want to try to convince Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats of the importance of this matter. I say to Senator Schacht that I feel provoked enough to rise on this matter. Through the very Estimates committee process that Senator Schacht referred to a few minutes ago, I uncovered—both last year and this year—the abuse of community sports grants. We uncovered in the various States that somewhere between 80 and 90 per cent of those sporting grants go into marginal Labor seats.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia last year something like 84 per cent of voluntary sporting grants and community facility grants went into marginal Labor seats. I think there is a similar figure in New South Wales. In Western Australia the year before, something like 90 per cent of those grants went into marginal Labor seats such as Canning and Stirling.

Furthermore, I think it is important for Senator Kernot and other Democrat senators to know how this Government operates and how these funds are used. I have also uncovered a specific case where some community facility grants and sporting grants were given to some organisations which have made submissions to the electoral commissioners in the redistribution process. What I am saying is that some groups which have received between $10,000 and $50,000 have put in submissions to electoral commissioners supporting the submission of Labor Party members in the redistribution process.

That does not need to reflect on those organisations. But my strongly held view is that where a government grants money to those sorts of organisations, or any other organisation, and they make a political statement in support of or in opposition to that government, it is quite proper for the voters to know that those groups have received that funding. If one political party says, `We're going to stop funding some of these organisations' and the other party says, `We're going to keep funding them', and those organisations go out and spend money convincing the Australian people to vote for the party that promises to maintain their funding, it is appropriate that people know that the organisations are receiving funds from the government and that they have a vested interest in the re-election of that government. That is the crucial part.

The Democrats should understand that this sort of political corruption is going on. I know that the Democrats are opposed to this sort of activity. It comes down to the fact that we have a government giving money to organisations which then support submissions by Labor Party members to electoral commissioners to change boundaries. That is the very sort of corruption that the Democrats are opposed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell has made an appeal to the Democrats on something that is not even covered by the Oppositions's own amendment. He is complaining about a sporting body supposedly supporting a Labor Party redistribution. Opposition amendment 320A(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an electoral advertisement, handbill, pamphlet or notice is authorised by:
Well, sending off a letter in support of a redistribution is not covered by any of those descriptions. So what Senator Campbell is raising is outside even his own amendment.

PARA.TAB: The difficulties of this amendment are not appreciated by the Opposition. For example, in the last election the National Association of Forest Industries spent well over $1m on putting its viewpoint in quite a political way. The Association used authorised political advertisements to put forward its viewpoint on what it thinks should happen in the forestry industry. I have not been through all the companies associated with the National Association of Forest Industries but I will bet two bob to London Bridge that somewhere in there a local government body or a State government has given a tax concession, or a land tax concession, to a timber mill; that the Association or a member of the Association has, directly or indirectly, received some sort of financial assistance.

Senator Campbell is suggesting that at the end of its television advertisement the Association should run up a list saying, `We got this tax concession on land tax from the Nunjikompita Council and so on'. That is the sort of outcome that we will see from the Opposition's amendment. It is just absurd. If the Opposition wants transparency, it should adopt the processes of the Parliament, which are well known—for instance, the Estimates committees—FOI Act requests and so on. I am sure that Senator Campbell, with his diligent ability, will continue to chase all these rabbits down every warren and burrow around the place to find out whether these organisations are getting this sort of money. That is his right; it is part of the democratic process. But to say that the National Association of Forest Industries now has to put a tag on its television advertisement indicating that its membership has got all these bits and pieces of financial assistance from either Commonwealth, State or local government is an absurdity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Kernot, I think it is my duty to remind honourable senators that this has been declared an urgent Bill. The time expires at 12 noon.

—I am conscious of that, Mr Chairman. I make the point that accountability and transparency are two important principles. The Opposition had in mind an amendment which put in train an audit trail so that we could have looked at how government grants were being spent. I think that is a more sensible way to go than what the Government is trying to achieve in this amendment. I think it catches people unfairly, as I have said previously.

—Senator Schacht has shown how even-handed the amendment, as proposed by the Opposition, is. If the Association of Forest Industries was in receipt of a large grant, under this amendment it would have to disclose it. If the Association of Forest Industries ran those advertisements, it would have to have that disclosed. That is fine by the Opposition.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is very unusual that Senator Kemp can speak when he is not in his seat.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my left! I can handle this without all of the interjections on my left. Senator Kemp asked whether he could speak from that position, and I acceded to his request.

Clause 20.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 20 is consequential on another clause which has been defeated. The Government will not proceed with this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that also incorporate proposed new subsection 13, which is the definitional aspect?

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 19.After clause 21, page 16, insert the following clause:
"21A. Section 329 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a)by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: `(2) A person must not, during the relevant period in relation to an election under this Act, authorise the printing, publishing or distribution of any electoral matter containing a statement:
(a)that is untrue; and

TAB.TAB: (b)that is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive.';

PARA.TAB: (b)by inserting in subsection (4) `, (2)' after `subsection (1)';
(c)by inserting after subsection (5) the following subsection:

`(5A) In the prosecution of a person for an offence against subsection (4) by virtue of a contravention of subsection (2), it is a defence if the person proves that he or she did not know, and could not reasonably be expected to have known, that the electoral advertisement contained a statement of the kind referred to in subsection (2).'.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is another attempt by the Australian Democrats to have truth in political advertising. I think the arguments are well known. We find it unbelievable that those who advertise products are subjected to very strict requirements, whereas we, as politicians, are able to make all sorts of wild and misleading claims in political advertisements.

PARA.TAB: I know that there are difficulties. If there were more time, I would challenge people to say why it is impossible to achieve this amendment today. The Democrats will not call a division on it because of the time limit. However, this is very important to us, as evidenced by our record in this place over the past eight years or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has always had a lot of sympathy with the approach of the Australian Democrats on this. Senator Kernot would be aware of what the Labor Party did at the Brisbane City Council elections with its publications. We are all aware of that. The Labor Party put out the most absolute, outrageous lies on pieces of paper. The Labor Party should be ashamed of what it did.

PARA.TAB: In the interests of time, having said that, the Opposition, while it has sympathy for this and would like to see a way around it, does not believe that it is workable. The Electoral Commission, in its report to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, said—I am not sure whether I have picked its words correctly—that it would not like to be involved in policing this because of the difficulties involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would love to get a provision such as this which is workable. The provision went before the parliamentary committee and was found to be unworkable. If something such as this had been in operation, I am sure that Mr Goldsworthy would have been retracting some press statements in the last few days.

—The Australian Democrats have unsuccessfully attempted to amend the legislation with respect to truth in political advertising on a number of occasions. We have been vigorously pursuing the two-minute limit and the talking heads proposal because, hopefully, that will move us in that direction. It will be far more difficult for people to use deceptive and misleading material under those conditions. That substantially moves us in the direction which the Democrats wish to go.

—No-one would argue with truth in advertising in principle. The simple fact is—I draw the Committee's attention to the evidence that has been given to the Select Committee—that putting it into practice and making determinations about it are quite another matter. Given the time constraint, I simply say that the principle is fine in theory but putting it into practice is nigh impossible. This was demonstrated in the evidence put to the Select Committee, not only by the Electoral Commission but also a number of people from industry groups in the advertising arena and the like, which outlined the practical difficulties in applying the truth in advertising rule in political advertising.

Clause 22 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 22A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 21.After Clause 22, page 16, insert the following clause:
"22A. After section 386 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.TAB: `386A.(1) The Commission must, within the prescribed period in relation to the next general election held after the commencement of this section, cause documents to be prepared in accordance with the regulations and delivered to each household in Australia.
`(2) A document delivered to a household under this section must contain relevant information about:

TAB.TAB: (a)each nominated House of Representatives candidate in the Division where the household is situated; and
(b)each nominated Senate candidate in the State or Territory where the household is situated;

SPEECH.PARA: together with such policy statements as are prescribed.

PARA.TAB: `(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), the following information is relevant information about a candidate:

TAB.TAB: (a)the candidate's full name;
(b)the name of the registered political party (if any) which is to be printed adjacent to the candidate's name on the ballot paper for the forthcoming election under section 214;
(c)prescribed information (if any) about the candidate's qualifications, career, occupation and interests, being information supplied by the candidate to the Commission.

PARA.TAB: `(4) A document under this section must also contain:

TAB.TAB: (a)if a candidate to which it relates supplies the Commission with a photograph of the candidate—a black and white reproduction of the photograph in the prescribed form; or

(b)if no such photograph is supplied by a candidate, but the candidate supplies instead what purports to be a depiction of the logo of the registered political party which is to be printed adjacent to the candidate's name on the ballot paper for the forthcoming election under section 214—a black and white reproduction of that depiction in the prescribed form.

PARA.TAB: `(5) Any failure by the Commission to comply with this section, or anything contained in any document delivered under this section, has no effect:

TAB.TAB: (a)on the general election referred to in subsection (1) or on any Senate election conducted at the same time as that general election; or
(b)on the election of any person as a member of the House of Representatives or as a senator as a result of such an election.

PARA.TAB: `(6) No civil or criminal action or proceeding of any kind lies against the Commission or any other person (other than a candidate) or body in relation to the preparation, publication or delivery of any document under this section, or in relation to any matter contained in any such document.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment requires the Australian Electoral Commission to have delivered to every household in Australia—not to every voter—a smallish booklet/pamphlet which would contain basic factual information. That information would include: a photograph of the candidate or a logo for the party, if the candidate represents a party; a few short curriculum vitae materials, such as would be ascertained from the nomination form; and a short policy statement on behalf of the candidate. It is my expectation that each candidate would receive about one-third of an A4 sheet. For the Senate group there would be one-third of an A4 sheet and the team would be treated as one.

PARA.TAB: It is my view that despite all of the advertising that takes place, many electors still do not efficiently find out who is running.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in print, not on billboards, not in cinemas and not on talkback radio. It is quite likely—I know it will be the same at the next election—that too many people do not know who is running in their electorate. This is a simple attempt to say to every elector, in the same way they get information on referendum campaigns, `These are the people who are running; these are some basic details about them'. I am only asking for this proposal to be trialled for the next Federal election, at a cost of $2m. The Democrats have rejected the increase in Senate funding. Four million dollars has been appropriated by this Bill. This proposal has been costed at $2m. It is printed on recycled paper; there are absolutely no frills. The details will be provided within 48 hours of nomination.

PARA.TAB: I am very conscious of not embroiling the Electoral Commission in any political comment or controversy. The Electoral Commission's responsibility is simply to have it delivered to every household in the same way as are referendum booklets. I cannot see any problem with facilitating access to basic information; it is the right of every elector. This will assist people to ignore the hype, look at the basic details and make up their own minds. They can take it to the polling booth with them if they want to. In the long term it may assist us to move towards having no how to vote cards.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is implacably opposed to this clause. When it was first raised by Senator Bolkus it was referred to as the mail-out clause. That is exactly what it is. It is a classic example of giving with one hand and taking away with the other. Earlier the Democrats came in here and said that they would take the moral high ground and say, `Look, we are not going to take the additional funding for the Senate'. That is great, because it will save the taxpayers of Australia around $5m.

PARA.TAB: I am critical of the Government for supporting a system whereby a pamphlet has, at taxpayers' expense, to go to every electorate in Australia and have on it things such as a photograph, a CV and a brief policy statement. One of the arguments—this is where the inconsistency comes in—for lengthening television advertisements to two minutes and radio to one minute was that information should be provided so that electors could get a better understanding of what the parliamentary parties stood for.

A brief policy statement is an absolute nonsense. It is the same sort of thing we got in the early days of the elections in PNG. We could see a populist person put out his policy for the next election, in a little electorate, saying that there is free beer for all the electors. That would get a lot of votes, I would say. That is the sort of frivolous thing that we can see coming up.

How can we justify extra funding in this climate? Senator Kernot said she had a costing from the Electoral Commission. I will accept what it has told her. But there is no way in the world that she can send every elector, bearing in mind there will be different electorates—

TALK.START.PARA: —Household.
—Fine; it will be sent to every household in this country.
—Delivered to every household.

—It does not matter whether it is delivered by post or not. If Senator Kernot does her costings, she will probably find that pamphlets addressed `To the Householder' and delivered by Australia Post are probably as cheap as we can get. It costs about 8c or 9c a letter. That is the cheap part. There is over $1m involved in that. All that the candidate or the party has to do is give a photograph with the CV and those other things. Then it has to be printed and there has to be a different pamphlet for every electorate. Then we come to the Senate. How many Senate candidates were there in the last New South Wales election?
—Fifty or 60.
—Fifty or 60, each with a photograph and a CV.
—I didn't say that.

—I would like to restate the Liberal and National parties' point of view on this whole issue. We are opposed to public funding. This is just going to the taxpayer without the taxpayer having any say in it and supporting political parties. The role of candidates or parties is to tell the electorate who they are and what they stand for. That is the reason for political parties; it is not the role of the taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: This proposal is an incredible imposition on the taxpayers of Australia. Yet again there is an attempt by this Government—it is not an attempt; it will be successful, unfortunately—to carry this through. I want to put on the record that when we come into government—which will not be very long; it will happen at the next election—this whole issue of public funding will be thrown out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer should note that the proposal from the Democrats in clause 386A(1) says `in relation to the next general election'. This is really a sunset clause. It is a trial. If it is to apply at the following election the legislation will have to come back to be amended. If Senator Parer is in government, heaven forbid, I am sure he will not put it through. Even if we are in government and the numbers in the Parliament are the same, we still have to proceed with the Bill to do it the second time. It is only guaranteed for the next election.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Parer makes great mention of the fact that the Opposition will not have a bar of these sorts of proposals. If there is any provision of public funding in any form —either in this Parliament or other Parliaments—he says every time that he will not have a bar of it. If it is carried, he is up the front line with everybody else getting his hands in the till to get his share of it. If he was so principled about it he would say, `We won't have any of it. You can stick it'. But no, he is straight up the front. He will be right up the front getting his share of it if it is passed by the Parliament, despite these so-called principled objections that he makes here.

Finally, I want to draw Senator Parer's attention to one of his own amendments, that donations should be tax deductible uncapped—anything over $2 can be tax deductible. If millionaires give $100,000 to a political party they can claim that as a tax deduction and get back 47c in the dollar. That is revenue forgone. That is public funding in another form. If Senator Parer was really consistent, he would not be putting up that proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is voluntary, not compulsory—that is the point.

—But it is a cost to the taxpayer. It is revenue forgone. It is a cost to the revenue. If the Opposition amendment, or the variation by the Democrats, is carried I am sure that when it goes back to the House of Representatives one of the arguments the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) will put up is, `We want to know what the cost to the revenue is of revenue forgone'. It is, therefore, a form of public funding. Senator Parer has fallen already on the principle of saying, `We would never support any public funding'. This is an amendment containing an unlimited, uncapped public funding proposal which benefits the top end of town.

—Traditionally, there has been a debate as to how the State supports the political process in this way. Traditionally also, and increasingly over the world, the move has been towards public funding of campaigns and less towards the tax deductibility of donations, for the reason that the latter is most inequitable. That is why this Parliament some years ago adopted the public funding approach.

PARA.TAB: I have been inclined to support the Democrats' proposal as it appears today, at least for the one-off period, and at this stage I will support what is before us. It is always going to be a choice between public funding and tax deductibility. The Democrats have to understand quite clearly that if their proposal for tax deductibility gets up, or the Opposition's proposal for tax deductibility gets up, both that and this will not be able to survive. It is a choice they have to make and it is one that I think is quite clear, but it may well be that this Bill going through will encompass both proposals.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my left!

—It is fair to say that a double cost would be one that the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) would find very difficult to accept. Having said that, I think the proposal is a useful way of getting information out to people, and it is worth a try. There is not a chance in it, in that what is being proposed is something that operates already in respect of referenda and the Opposition has found that sort of mechanism quite useful. It is a defensible proposition, but those opposite cannot have everything and get away with it.

—It is a defensible proposition and I regret that the Minister has linked it in the way he has. I understand the arguments on tax deductibility and I would have made the same points as Senator Schacht. If there is objection to a $1m or $2m trial there is an inconsistency in proposing a tax deductibility which is going to go on in perpetuity and cost millions and millions of dollars to revenue. There is nothing wrong with trying new ideas. I am proposing only that we do this for one Federal election. It will be a great benefit to voters.

—I ask the Minister how this would work. It has been said today that there were over 50 candidates in a particular Senate election. What proportion of the total document will be applied to political parties or to candidates? Does this mean that the size of the document will depend on the number of actual candidates and that each of the candidates will get precisely the same length? If that is so, that opens itself to a degree of political advertising at the expense of the taxpayer for groups that may be put up as front men for the major political parties. I think that is a disgrace.

—It is anticipated that all candidates will have access to the booklet to provide up to a prescribed number of words, and candidates will be listed to appear, we anticipate, in accordance with the way they have come out in the draw for the election. To that extent, a booklet may be a different size between one electorate and another, but the candidates' contribution to that booklet will be the same size.

—Does that apply also to the Senate? This is where the problem arises. This is where the problem certainly will arise at the next election, not only in respect of this matter but also in respect of the free time that is going to be available. I am sure that at the next election there will be front organisations put up by people in order to get involved in the free time.

PARA.TAB: What is the situation going to be as far as the election is concerned? Is it going to mean that the preponderance of the document will be taken up by a whole list of candidates—by front groups—and that the major parties, or those who are currently members of the Senate, will not be given a proportionately fair share of that document? I think the whole system is crazy. It is not like the referendum documents at all. The referendum documents place the for and against proposals, and those decisions are made by people elected by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is of intense interest to the Liberal and National parties, which oppose it. We will not speak because we are conscious of the shortage of time. The fundamental proposition that is being put to the chamber is on the costing. Senator Kernot assures us that it will cost $2m; we believe it will cost at least $9m. In those circumstances, if the Senate makes a decision to support that, the Democrats then have a moral obligation to meet any cost overruns beyond the $2m from their resources. I presume they will give a commitment to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: 19.At end of bill, page 17, add the following Part:

SPEECH.PARA: I move amendment No. 19 on its own, not Nos 19 to 21. Amendment No. 20 and amendment No. 21 will be treated separately, although they are related.

PARA.TAB: The aim of this amendment is to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow for contributions of $2 and upwards to political parties to be tax deductible. The background to this is that the Labor Party has a substantial advantage over every political party in this country. It is the political arm of the trade union movement. All union dues, as everyone knows, are tax deductible—and no-one is disputing that. However, amounts of money are paid from those tax deductible union dues as affiliation fees to the Labor Party. That does not happen to any other party in Australia.

In addition, any donations that come from the union movement to the ALP come from tax free money. This is not commonly known. Unions are a different kettle of fish from what they were 10, 20 or 30 years ago, when they existed simply to look after their members. They have become very big business and, in some cases, they are as big as any other big business in this country. They own lots of CBD property and they have income-producing operations. They are now at the point where, in fact, if they owned part of the casino on the Gold Coast—they may well own part of it; I do not know—all income paid to the trade union would be tax free. Any donations that flow on to the Labor Party are tax free donations.

It is pretty simple. I heard Senator Schacht before saying that we on this side of the chamber were doing all sorts of things. For goodness sake, let us try to level the playing field; let us get a bit of fairness into this. I have been over this time and time again in this debate and it was talked about in the second reading debate. We are stuck for time, but let me just say that I understand that the Democrats intend to move an amendment the intent of which is to put a lid of $100 on those donations. It was my view that we would have been happy with some sort of a lid. We believe that what the Democrats propose is too low. In fact, an appropriate lid would have been the level at which disclosure was required, and anything below that would have been satisfactory.

Our amendment would enable people voluntarily to make a donation to the party of their choice—not compulsorily through public funding. In our view, the two are related. Notwithstanding the limitation of the amendment which I think the Democrats will move, we believe this would be a step forward which would be to the benefit of the smaller parties, the people who rely on the small donations. That, to me, is what fairness is all about in this country. When the Democrats propose their amendment to our amendment, we will support it, naturally.

I objected strenuously when the Minister, on the previous amendment moved by the Democrats, threatened blackmail. There was an absolute threat: `If you don't go along with this, we will make sure that we won't go along with the second part'. The Minister said, `If you Democrats go along with that, we throw out'—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's an absolute exaggeration.

—That is exactly what he said, and the honourable senator knows it. I make that point in passing. But, in principle, we move that contributions of $2 and upwards to political parties be allowable as a tax deduction.

—I think my running sheet has some things missing. Senator Kernot, it seems to me that your additional amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 all refer to the Opposition amendment No. 20. I did not know whether you wanted to move 1,2 and 3 or just 3, as you mentioned.

But, in the meantime, I seek leave to move together amendments Nos 2 and 3 circulated in our name on the paper headed `Additional Amendment No. 1'.

`(7A) The total deduction allowable to a taxpayer under paragraph 78(1)(aaa) in a year of income shall be limited to $100.'.".

—Mr Chairman, might I offer a bit of assistance? Senator Kernot might listen. I have moved amendment No. 19 only, not Nos 19, 20 and 21.
—When you are talking about No. 19, some of us are calling that No. 20.

—I have moved the amendment which provides for contributions to political parties of the value of $2 and upwards to be tax deductible. I have not yet gone on to the next part, which amends the Industrial Relations Act. Now that I have moved my amendment, Senator Kernot might like to move her amendment to my amendment and then we can come to a conclusion on this matter.
—I am limiting the Opposition's deduction to $100, and I have not talked about the next one.
—Can I seek clarification from Senator Parer? Does this mean that he is talking not only about corporation donations, but also private donations, of $2, up to a limit of $100?
—To respond to Senator Harradine, the $100 is really directed towards private people, but it is anyone.
—The Democrat amendment No. 3 makes it quite clear that after the second taxpayer we add `where the taxpayer is not a company'.

—Does that mean you are not proceeding with amendments 21 and 22?
—Does that mean that Senator Parer is not happy for it to be amended to `companies' and that shareholders should have the same responsibilities as everybody else?
—We do not have time to debate it, so the best thing to do is withdraw it, because of the gag.

SPEECH.PARA: (20)Clause 6, page 9, after proposed section 95D, insert the following section and Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Some matter not to be broadcast during certain other periods

PARA.TAB: "`95DA.(1) If, when a prescribed day in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to an election to the Parliament, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Commonwealth during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.

`(2)If, when a prescribed day in relation to the legislature of a Territory (other than the Australian Capital Territory) occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to an election to the legislature, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of that Territory during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.

TAB.TAB: (a)starts 3 calendar months before the day on which the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory is next due to expire; and
(b)ends immediately before the start of the election period in relation to the next ordinary election to the Legislative Assembly.

PARA.TAB: `(4)In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "election" does not include a by-election;
"prescribed day" means:

TAB.TAB: (a)in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the House of Representatives is next due to expire; and
(b)in relation to the legislature of a Territory—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the legislature is next due to expire.

SPEECH.PARA: `Division 3—Free election broadcasting time Application of Division to radio broadcasts

PARA.TAB: `95DB.(1) Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring or permitting the Service or a licensee to broadcast an election broadcast by radio.
`(2)Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring the Corporation to broadcast an election broadcast by radio other than on its metropolitan and regional AM networks.

`(3)Despite section 95DC, the Corporation may broadcast by radio a broadcast that complies with paragraphs 95DC(a) to (e), inclusive, but which lasts for longer than 1 minute, and any such broadcast is taken to be an election broadcast for the purposes of this Division.
`(4)Despite anything in this Division, the Corporation may determine the times when it broadcasts election broadcasts by radio.

`95DC. Subject to section 95DB, a broadcast made on behalf of a political party, a candidate or a group in relation to an election is, for the purposes of this Division, taken to be an election broadcast if, and only if:

(a)the broadcast is of an advertisement that consists of words spoken by a single speaker (without dramatic enactment or impersonation) accompanied, where the advertisement is televised, by a transmitted image that consists of the head and shoulders of the speaker; and
(b)the broadcast does not include any other image, or includes a single additional static background image only; and
(c)no other vocal sounds are included in the broadcast; and

(d)the speaker is a candidate in the election or, if the election is a Senate election, is either a candidate or a senator whose place will not become vacant at the end of the 30 June next following the election; and
