(f)the broadcast lasts for:

TAB.TAB: (i)in the case of a televised broadcast—2 minutes; and
(ii)in the case of a broadcast by radio—1 minute; and

PARA.TAB: (g)the broadcast is made using a unit of free time allocated to the broadcaster under section 95DJ.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Automatic grant of free time to certain parties

PARA.TAB: `95DD.(1) The Tribunal must, within the prescribed period in relation to an election grant a period of free time to:

(a)the political party that comprised the government of the Commonwealth, Territory or State, as the case may be, immediately before the end of the last sittings of the relevant Parliament or legislature held before the election; and
(b)the political party that comprised the official opposition of the Commonwealth, Territory or State, as the case may be, immediately before the end of those sittings; and
(c)any other political party that was accorded official party status by the relevant Parliament or legislature and held that status immediately before the end of those sittings.

`(2)The period to be granted to the political party referred to in paragraph (1)(a) is the period equal to 40% of the total time in respect of the election, and, if there is more than one such party, the Tribunal must divide that period between them in accordance with the regulations.

`(3)The period to be granted to the political party under paragraph (1)(b) is the period equal to 40% of the total time in respect of the election, and, if there is more than one such party, the Tribunal must divide that period between them in accordance with the regulations.

`(4)The period to be granted to a political party referred to in paragraph (1)(c) is the period equal to 10% of the total time in respect of the election, and, if there is more than one such party, the Tribunal must divide that period between them in accordance with the regulations.
`(5)In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "election" means an election (other than a by-election) to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b)the legislature of a Territory; or
(c)a State Parliament;

SPEECH.PARA: "total time", in relation to an election, means the total free time available in respect of the election, being a time worked out in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications for grant of free time

PARA.TAB: `95DE.(1) The chief executive officer of a political party (other than a political party to which section 95DD applies), or any other person or group of persons, may apply to the Tribunal for a grant of free time in relation to an election (other than a by-election) to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b)the legislature of a Territory; or
(c)a State Parliament.

PARA.TAB: `(2)An application must be in the approved form and made in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on applications in relation to Senate elections

PARA.TAB: `95DF.(1) If, on receipt of an application by a person for a grant of free time in relation to a Senate election, the Tribunal is satisfied that:

TAB.TAB: (a)the person is a candidate in the election; and

SPEECH.PARA: the Tribunal must grant the person a period of free time.

PARA.TAB: `(2)The period to be granted to a person under this section is a period determined by the Tribunal in accordance with the regulations, being a period equal to not less than 5% of the total time in respect of the election nor more than:

TAB.TAB: (a)if a period has not been granted in respect of the election under subsection 95DD(4)—20% of the total time; or
(b)in any other case—10% of the total time.

PARA.TAB: `(3)If the Tribunal is required under this section to grant a period of free time to 2 or more persons, the Tribunal must divide the period determined under subsection (2) between them in accordance with the regulations.
`(4)In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "total time" has the same meaning as in section 95DD.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on other applications

PARA.TAB: `95DG.(1) If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a political party of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the party has endorsed one or more candidates to contest the election, the Tribunal may, subject to the regulations, grant the party a period of free time determined in accordance with the regulations.

`(2)If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a person or a group of persons (other than a person or persons to whom section 95DF applies) of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the person, or each of the persons, is a candidate in the election, the Tribunal must grant the person or group a period of free time in accordance with the regulations.
`95DH.(1) The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chief executive officer of each political party to which a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)every other person to whom such a period has been granted;

SPEECH.PARA: of the period so granted.

PARA.TAB: `(2)If the Tribunal refuses to grant an application under section 95DF or 95DG, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify the applicant accordingly and specify its reasons for refusing the application.
`(3)The Tribunal must cause a notice to be published in the Gazette specifying:

TAB.TAB: (a)the political parties and persons to whom a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)the period that has been granted to each of them.

PARA.TAB: `95DJ.(1) The Tribunal must divide each period of free time granted under this Division into units of free time in accordance with the regulations.

`(2)If the division of a period of free time granted to a political party, person or group under this Division results in a number of whole units and part of a unit, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, distribute that part of a unit to or between any other political parties, persons or groups granted a period of free time under this Division.

`(3)The Tribunal must, in distributing a part of a unit of free time, ensure that the periods of free time which the political parties mentioned in paragraphs 95DD(1)(a) and (b) receive after the distribution are equal.
`(4)The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, allocate units of free time to broadcasters.

`95DK.(1) Subject to this section, where one or more units of free time are allocated to a broadcaster under section 95DJ, the broadcaster must make the unit or units available for use in making one or more election broadcasts during the election period for the election on behalf of the political party, person or group to whom the time is granted.
`(2)Subject to this section, the broadcaster must use the units in accordance with the regulations and any guidelines determined by the Tribunal.
`(3)A broadcaster must not make an election broadcast in relation to an election before the close of nominations for the election.
`(4)Subject to this section, a broadcaster must make, during the election period in relation to an election, at least:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the case of an election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—3 election broadcasts by television on each day on which the broadcaster is required to use units of free time allocated to it to make an election broadcast; and
(b)in the case of an election to the legislature of a Territory—the prescribed number of election broadcasts by television on each such day; and
(c)in the case of an election to a State Parliament—2 election broadcasts by television on each such day.

SPEECH.PARA: There was some debate in the chamber yesterday about this matter and I thought it would not hurt to have a specific prohibition in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment because we have already come to a package which I moved and had accepted a little while ago in respect of disclosure. As I said last night, the motivating force for that was to exclude membership lists.

PARA.TAB: We now have in place a situation, which we have all agreed to, whereby any income or expenditure over $1,500 is automatically disclosed and anything under $1,500 has to be disclosed by regulation. It is exempt unless there is a regulation in place to make it disclosable. Therefore, any bona fide membership would have to be disclosed by specific regulation, because we all know that memberships do not go over $1,500 if they are bona fide. There is no need for this amendment at this stage, because what we adopted five or 10 minutes ago protects the membership lists from the sort of intrusive behaviour that the Opposition might be concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Campbell, because I would hope that at no stage in the future of this country would we expect any government to bring in a regulation that required party membership to be disclosed. For that reason, the Opposition supports Senator Campbell's amendment.

—I have not had time to consider this amendment in detail; it is one of the amendments from the Opposition that I have not seen. TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with Government amendment No. 20, as amended.

—This was a deferred discussion from yesterday, when it was felt that the proposal that was before the Committee was not flexible enough to accommodate individual State situations and State concerns. The matter was particularly raised in respect of the opposition parties in Queensland. Thereafter, Senator Boswell raised with my office the question of the National Party in Western Australia or whatever it may be called there.

PARA.TAB: We have also had to focus on a number of other issues which go, for instance, to what happens when in the case of a Senate election a senator has not had to run in the preceding election but ran in the one before that, and how essentially one takes into account all State peculiarities. The proposal that is before us is one that, I suppose, if one were to describe it generically, could be classified as democratic proportionality, and that is the concept that we have tried to pick up. That is one concept; another concept has been to incorporate flexibility. The third concept is, in the context of flexibility, to ensure that State peculiarities are also picked up and can be accommodated.

So the clause is very general. It ensures that regulations will be formulated for each State. It also ensures that there is capacity for the break-up of time to be made on a State rather than a national basis. I give the assurance that the regulations will be in place within six months. That is, I think, a concern that some people have had. As I say, the regulations are disallowable by either House of Parliament. So there is that ultimate guarantee that if the regulations are not fair in the way that the Senate or the House of Representatives determines, they can, in a sense, be rewritten.

What we have before us is a mechanism which, for instance, would accommodate the situation that Senator Harradine would have: he did not run at the last election but he ran in the election before that. His position could be accommodated in regulations. In addition, the emergence of new parties is accommodated. The principles and the letter ensure that 90 per cent of the total time will be made available to existing parties which are represented in the respective parliament; 10 per cent will then be available for emerging groups and they would have access to that.

The final decision will be taken by the Broadcasting Tribunal in accordance with regulations. All of those regulations will be in place in six months. It is intended that we will put them in place as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, to us this is the core of this Bill. We were arguing very strongly all the way through that the amount of time available in this very powerful medium should be determined by some objective, democratic process, and not simply by the ability to pay. This provision ensures that. The most objective measure of a party's support quite clearly is the number of votes cast at the previous election. We believe that this gives effect to the proper way in which that time should be allocated.

—The National Party has some considerable difficulty with the wording of the amendment as it stands. I note that Senator Bolkus gave certain undertakings in the chamber just a moment ago. But I must outline our reservations in more detail because we feel unhappy about relying upon regulation to give effect to this, and I should just go through it.

PARA.TAB: At the last Federal election, the National Party stood candidates in only 46 of the House of Representatives seats, obtaining across Australia an aggregate vote of 8.42 per cent. But the National Party stood no candidates at all in the Northern Territory, Tasmania, South Australia or the Australian Capital Territory.

It clearly has to be the case that the amount of time which is allocated is allocated within each State and by reference to the votes obtained within each State, because there is no point in the National Party getting advertising time, for example, in Tasmania, where there is no National Party. This, of course, affects Independents such as my friend Senator Harradine, and also Senator Vallentine's successor. The WA Greens obtained 8.41 per cent of the WA vote, yet obtained nationally only 0.77 per cent of the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard that but I would ask Senator Coulter to bear with me because I am outlining a position and he will just have to hear the whole thing. The other thing about the Greens is that they were split amongst a number of parties. For example, there were green Senate parties calling themselves the Australian Green Party, the Environmental Independents, the Green Alliance, the Greens and the WA Greens.

PARA.TAB: Subject to discussing this during this very brief committee debate with one of the Clerks, if I can find one, I must mention the fact that we would feel it more appropriate that it be amended so that proposed new section 95DD(1) has added to it on the second line, after the words `grant a period of free time', the words `within each State or Territory' and in proposed new section 95DD(3) in line six, after the words `party or its candidates', add the words `within that State or Territory'.

We feel it is absolutely critical, if this Bill is going to pass this Committee, that it be set out perfectly for the regulations because, as the Minister said, it is subject to further consideration. But I think we are already making very clear requirements in subsection (3) as to the regulations. I believe it is most appropriate, therefore, that these considerations be put in that subsection and in subsection (1) of proposed new section 95DD now to keep the consistency of this amendment and to give clear effect to what the Minister has said. Obviously, if the Minister has given an undertaking, surely he would have no objection in principle to what I am talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is necessary to put the amendment in the Bill as Senator O'Chee has suggested. Paragraph 3 makes it quite clear that there is flexibility within the regulations to account for the difficulties which I can understand the National Party has. In certain States the National Party does not exist and in other States it exists very strongly. The free time provision will have to take into account the position of a third or fourth party, such as the National Party.

PARA.TAB: However, that can all be done by way of the regulations tabled in this place, and disallowable, and as part of negotiations before a Federal election. In a Federal election, under a State system, the allocation of free time in each State can be adjusted by regulation. Once we start writing this into the Act now, we will go in a cycle in which we will never be satisfied. We will be trying now to cover every possible eventuality which we do not know will exist; whereas the regulations can always be adjusted, disallowed and redone according to a situation that may occur suddenly.

I think the difficulty is greatly overstated. I think once the system is operating—as it has operated with regard to ABC free time for 40 years without any great difficulty—it will work under regulations. The difficulties that the National Party raises and other third, fourth or fifth parties, individual Senate candidates, sitting senators and Independents raise, can all be accounted for through sensible discussion and in the regulations. I do not think it is necessary to amend the legislation as Senator O'Chee has suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day for democracy when, because the Australian Democrats and the Government get together to ram through a Bill with such far reaching implications, we could well have the situation whereby the Democrats will have a vastly increased share of the free time—something like 13 per cent—the Labor Party and the Liberal Party will do fairly well out of it, but people like Senator Harradine, Senator Vallentine or some other Independent who may happen to be in the Senate could get absolutely nothing. The minor parties, which are not even here, could well end up with not one second of time. The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is fundamentally flawed because we cannot have 115 per cent of 100 per cent. It just does not work. But because this Bill has been chopped around so much, it ends up allocating more than 100 per cent of total free time.

PARA.TAB: I point out to the Minister for Administrative Services and to Senator Kernot, or anyone in the Australian Democrats who might like to listen, that the new amendment, which I understand has been brought in by the Minister—I have not seen it, except on a bit of paper that was faxed to my office—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had it for a while. I talked to you about it two hours ago.

—I maintain that I have not seen it come through the chamber. I do not know whether the amendment which the Minister is proposing is the one that will end up in here. In fact, I understand it has been amended once already. It shows that 90 per cent of the time will go to the political parties which have people in parliament. I refer the Minister to clause 95DF(2), which says that other people—meaning people in parliament who are not members of a political party—will have a minimum of 5 per cent of the total time and a maximum of 10 per cent of the total time. If there are three Independents in the Parliament, three times 5 per cent is 15 per cent. If we add 15 per cent to 90 per cent, we get 105 per cent. What will happen with that? What will happen to all the parties which are not represented in parliament and all of those Independents, such as Mr Ted Mack? Where does he go? Where does he get his free time from? We have already spent 105 per cent of the total time. How can it be done? This Bill is fundamentally flawed because people have gone around trying to amend it on the run.

PARA.TAB: It is the most important Bill that has ever been raised in relation to free speech and democracy in this chamber. It is an absolute sham and a mess because the Government has not had the time or the inclination. It has been aided and abetted by this crew in the corner who call themselves the champions of democracy in Parliament. We have not had the time to debate this. If we had, these sorts of things would have been brought to light.

I also mention, in relation to that thing which shows that the whole Bill is fundamentally flawed, that the Government is completely taking away from councils like the Brisbane City Council and the Townsville City Council—just to name two—the right to advertise on the electronic media. If that had been the case before the last election, the Labor Party, with all its lies and its misinformation campaign, would not have got up. So maybe it is a good thing. Although that right has been taken away, the champions of democracy in the Australian Democrats have not even addressed its loss. I hope that Senator Kernot answers to her Brisbane electorate for that when she gets back.

In addition to those things, there are myriad complaints about this particular clause. I particularly acknowledge that Senator Brownhill, on behalf of the National Party, has asked to be associated with these because of the time restriction, the guillotine.

The whole Bill is fraught with opportunities to rort the system, to give the ALP additional time. The question then arises whether one takes it State by State; the Minister has given some undertaking on this. Does one take it upper chamber, lower chamber? What happens if all the green groups around Australia unite and become a section of the Australian Democrats? Do their votes from the last election go into it? They are things that could really happen and have to be looked at. They cannot be looked at on the run and they cannot be dealt with in regulations because the legislation is going contrary to that particular idea. There are an enormous number of inequities and unfortunate things.

I say to Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine that they could well be without any free time. It just so happens that at the moment both of them are associated as parties. But Senator Vallentine came in here not as that. Which party is Mr Mack in? If he wants to come here as an Independent, where does he go? The Democrats do not care because they have 13 per cent of the public purse; the Government does not care because it will make sure it gets its snout in the trough yet again. But it does not give a damn about the Independents, the smaller parties and those that represent the majority of Australians.

I think the whole thing should be sent back to where it belongs and put on the scrap heap so that we can have free speech. There are an enormous number of technical matters that I would like to raise, but I retire at this time because the debate has been guillotined and I would like other people to have the opportunity to speak.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Macdonald's remarks. We are in a tight situation here and we are trying to make the best of it. The proposition we have at the moment is that the parties in this Parliament or the State Parliament get 90 per cent of the appropriated time allocated on a proportional basis on the vote they received at the last election. That raises problems of its own. For instance, at the last Queensland State election the National Party got a very bad vote. I have seen that happen to the Liberal Party. Probably every party has its ups and downs.

PARA.TAB: If appropriated time is locked into the last performance, that then entrenches the last performance. The party will never break out of that. So it goes around in ever-decreasing circles. Because it got a bad vote last time it cannot advance its vote the next time as it does not have any access to the appropriated time. That is a problem that I think the Government has not considered.

The National Party contests a very small number of seats. Yet, in the seats it does stand for, it can get a very high proportion of the vote. In Maranoa and Gwydir, for example, the National Party gets 70 and 80 per cent of the vote. Yet the National Party has only 8 per cent of the total vote in Australia. The Government might say that we can allocate that back into the States, but it certainly will not work that way. I know that time is running on and Senator Walters wants to have access to the floor, but we have to advance the belief that this 8 per cent, translated into free time, will never allow the National Party to advance. This provision will never allow any other minor parties to advance.

Members of the National Party have been told not to worry because, when the regulations come down, we can open the debate again and view it again and sweetness and light will reign in the Senate. I have not seen much evidence of that in the last two or three days. It is always my worry, too, that when one disallows a regulation one cannot disallow part of it. One has to disallow the whole of the regulation. It could be interwoven with some of the things the Democrats require or some of the things the Labor Party requires. I do not believe that we are going to get the appropriate recognition of our problems under a review of the regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll look after you.

—If the Labor Party ever looks after the National Party, it would be the first time in 70 years of National Party history that it did so. Senator Schacht must forgive me if I do not have a great deal of confidence in his assurance to the National Party because for 70 years the Labor Party has put the boot heavily into the National Party. I do not expect anything to be different when this regulation comes up. I agree with Senator Macdonald. I am getting the wind-up signal, so we have a quarter of an hour to make the best of a very bad job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, may I have the attention of the Minister and Senator Kernot on this very important matter. The Minister has told us—and I would like Senator Kernot's response to this—that clause 6 will be brought in in regulations within the next six months. If the Minister brings it in, as soon as the Senate rises—within a week—those regulations will be in force until we come back.
—I have an amendment to make sure that does not happen.

—I am making an important point. If the regulations come in as soon as the Senate gets up, we will not have any opportunity to disallow them. Tasmania is expecting an election in February. The Senate would not have the opportunity of disallowing those regulations in the meantime. Those regulations would stand in force during a State election to be held perhaps in February. I need an assurance from the Minister that those regulations will not be tabled or gazetted until this Parliament resumes and has the opportunity of disallowing those regulations. That is one very important point, I am sure the Minister would agree.

PARA.TAB: Will these new amendments apply to local government? Will the amount of time be applicable to local government? I have two different amendments from the Government. I have one that says `Amendments of Amendments moved on behalf of the Government', that is, amendments to the Government's amendments. I have another one that says `Amend of amendment moved on behalf of the Government' and I do not know where that one fits in. Could Senator Bolkus explain these two different amendments to amendments that I am holding in my hand now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Just read it out.
—The amendment that I am asking about is to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 and is headed `Amend of amendment moved on behalf of the Government' and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. (20), proposed paragraph 95DC(d), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(d) the speaker is a candidate in the election or a member of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or a State,or of a legislature of a Territory; and".

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been carried.
—That has already been dealt with and now we are dealing with just this one about the regulations, which is the one that I am concerned about.

—What we are dealing with—and I am sure the Chairman could tell me if I am wrong—is all of clause 6 of the Bill. A number of amendments have been circulated to that by parties, but the discussion so far has been particularly in respect of the circulated amendment to amendment No. (20) in respect of proposed new section 95DD. Senator Walters asked a couple of questions. It is anticipated that there will be an amendment coming up from the Democrats which Senator Kernot might talk about and which could cover some of those problems.

—As I see it, we are dealing with Government amendment No.(20). Senator Bolkus, I do not think that you have formally moved the amendment to amendment No. 20. Perhaps you could formally move that. That is the one that Senator Walters was speaking about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6, page 9, after proposed section 95D, insert the following section and Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Some matter not to be broadcast during certain other periods

PARA.TAB: ``95DA.(1) If, when a prescribed day in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to an election to the Parliament, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Commonwealth during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.

`(2) If, when the prescribed day in relation to the legislature of a Territory (other than the Australian Capital Territory) occurs, it does not do so during the election period in relation to the legislature, a broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of that Territory during the period that starts on that day and ends immediately before the next election period starts.
`(3) A broadcaster must not broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Australian Capital Territory during the period that:
(a)starts 3 calendar months before the day on which the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory is next due to expire; and
(b)ends immediately before the start of the election period in relation to the next ordinary election to the Legislative Assembly.
`(4) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: ``election'' does not include a by-election;
``prescribed day'' means:

PARA.TAB: (a)in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the House of Representatives is next due to expire; and
(b)in relation to the legislature of a Terrtory—the day that occurs 3 calendar months before the day on which the House of Representatives is next due to expire.

SPEECH.PARA: Application of Division to radio broadcasts

PARA.TAB: `95DB.(1) Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring or permitting the Service or a licensee to broadcast an election broadcast by radio.
`(2) Nothing in this Division is to be treated as requiring the Corporation to broadcast an election broadcast by radio other than on its metropolitan and regional AM networks.

`(3) Despite section 95DC, the Corporation may broadcast by radio a broadcast that complies with paragraphs 95DC(a) to (e), inclusive, but which lasts for longer than 1 minute, and any such broadcast is taken to be an election broadcast for the purposes of this Division.
`(4) Despite anything in this Division, the Corporation may determine the times when it broadcasts election broadcasts by radio.

`95DC. Subject to section 95DB, a broadcast made on behalf of a political party, a candidate or a group in relation to an election is, for the purposes of this Division, taken to be an election broadcast if, and only if:

(a)the broadcast is of an advertisement that consists of words spoken by a single speaker (without dramatic enactment or impersonation) accompanied, where the advertisement is televised, by a transmitted image that consists of the head and shoulders of the speaker; and
(b)the broadcast does not include any other image, or includes a single additional static background image only; and
(c)no other vocal sounds are included in the broadcast; and
(d)the speaker is a candidate in the election or a member of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or a State, or of a legislature of a Territory; and
(e)if section 117 applies—the required particulars within the meaning of that section are announced by the person who speaks the words of the advertisement; and
(f)the broadcast lasts for:

TAB.TAB: (i)in the case of a televised broadcast—2 minutes; and
(ii)in the case of a broadcast by radio—1 minute; and

PARA.TAB: (g)the broadcast is made using a unit of free time allocated to the broadcaster under section 95DJ.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Automatic grant of free time to certain parties

PARA.TAB: `95DD.(1) The Tribunal must, within the prescribed period in relation to an election, grant a period of free time to each politicsal party that:
(a)was represented by one or more members in the relevant Parliament or legislature immediately before the end of the last sittings of that Parliament or legislature held before the election; and
(b)is contesting the election with at least the prescribed number of candidates.

`(2) The total free time period to be granted to political parties under subsection (1) is the period equal to 90% of the total time in respect of the election, and the Tribunal must grant each of those parties such part of that total free time period as it determines in accordance with the regulations.

`(3) Regulations made for the purposes of subsection (2) must, so far as is practicable, give effect to the principle that the amount of free time granted to each party should bear the same proportion to the total free time period mentioned in that section as the number of formal first preference votes obtained by that party or its candidates at the last election to the relevant Parliament or legislature bears to the total number of such votes obtained by all of the parties mentioned in subsection (1) or their candidates at that last election.
`(4) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: ``election'' means an election (other than a by-election) to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b) the legislature of a Territory; or
(c) a State Parliament;

SPEECH.PARA: ``total time'', in relation to an election, means the total free time available in respect of the election, being a time worked out in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications for grant of free time

PARA.TAB: `95DE.(1) The chief executive officer of a political party (other than a political party to which section 95DD applies), or any other person or group of persons, may apply to the Tribunal for a grant of free time in relation to an election (other than a by-election) to:
(a) the Parliament of the Commonwealth; or
(b) the legislature of a Territory; or
(c) a State Parliament.
`(2) An application must be in the approved form and made in accordance with the regulations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on applications in relation to Senate elections

PARA.TAB: `95DF.(1) If, on receipt of an application by a person for a grant of free time in relation to a Senate election, the Tribunal is satisfied that:
(a)the person is a candidate in the election; and
(b)the person was a member of the Senate immediately before the end of the last sittings of the Senate held before the election; and
(c)the person is not a member of a political party to whom a grant of free time has been made under section 95DD;

SPEECH.PARA: the Tribunal must grant the person a period of free time.

PARA.TAB: `(2) The period to be granted to a person under this section is a period determined by the Tribunal in accordance with the regulations, being a period equal to not less than 5% of the total time in respect of the election nor more than 10% of that total time.

`(3) If the Tribunal is required under this section to grant a period of free time to 2 or more persons, the Tribunal must divide the period determined under subsection (2) between them in accordance with the regulations.
`(4) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: ``total time'' has the same meaning as in section 95DD.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Grant of free time on other applications

PARA.TAB: `95DG.(1) If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a political party of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the party has endorsed one or more candidates to contest the election, the Tribunal may, subject to the regulations, grant the party a period of free time determined in accordance with the regulations.

`(2) If, on receipt of an application for the grant to a person or a group of persons (other than a person or persons to whom section 95DF applies) of a period of free time in relation to an election, the Tribunal is satisfied that the person, or each of the persons, is a candidate in the election, the Tribunal may grant the person or group a period of free time in accordance with the regulations.
`95DH.(1) The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify:
(a)the chief executive officer of each political party to which a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)every other person to whom such a period has been granted;

SPEECH.PARA: of the period so granted.

PARA.TAB: `(2) If the Tribunal refuses to grant an application under section 95DF or 95DG, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, notify the applicant accordingly and specify its reasons for refusing the application.
`(3) The Tribunal must cause a notice to be published in the Gazette specifying:
(a)the political parties and persons to whom a period of free time has been granted; and
(b)the period that has been granted to each of them.
`95DJ.(1) The Tribunal must divide each period of free time granted under this Division into units of free time in accordance wit the regulations.

`(2) If the division of a period of free time granted to a political party, person or group under this Division results in a number of whole units and part of a unit, the Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, distribute that part of a unit to or between any other political parties, persons or groups granted a period of free time under this Division.
`(3) The Tribunal must, in accordance with the regulations, allocate units of free time to broadcasters.

`95DK.(1) Subject to this section, where one or more units of free time are allocated to a broadcaster under section 95dj, the broadcaster must make the unit or units available for use in making one or more election broadcasts during the election period for the election on behalf of the political party, person or group to whom the time is granted.
`(2) Subject to this section, the broadcaster must use the units in accordance with the regulations and any guidelines determined by the Tribunal.
`(3) A broadcaster must not make an election broadcast in relation to an election before the close of nominations for the election.
`(4) Subject to this section, a broadcaster must make, during the election period in relation to an election, at least:

(a)in the case of an election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth—3 election broadcasts by television on each day on which the broadcaster is required to use units of free time allocated to it to make an election broadcast; and
(b)in the case of an election to the legislature of a Territory—the prescribed number of election broadcasts by television on each such day; and
(c)in the case of an election to a State Parliament—2 election broadcasts by television on each such day.
`(5) A broadcaster who is required to make an election broadcast must do so free of charge.
`(6) A broadcaster is not required to make a unit or units of free time available under section (1):
(a)if the political party, person or group to whom the time is granted notifies the broadcaster that he, she or it does not intend to use the time; or
(b)in the prescribed circumstances.

`(7) A licensee who is required to make an election broadcast is entitled to such additional broadcasting time, for the purpose of broadcasting other material, as is determined in accordance with the regulations.

`95DL. If the Tribunal makes a decision refusing an application under section 95DF or 95DG for the grant of free time to a political party, person or group of persons, the party, person or persons may appeal to the Federal Court of Australia against the decision.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that I shall be moving an additional amendment No. 2 as amended. I want to speak to it and explain it to Senator Walters. The additional amendment No. 2 seeks to ensure that, if the regulations are not formulated within six months of the commencement of part 111D or before the issue of writs for the next general election, then part 111D—Political Broadcasts—of the Act will not happen; it lapses. I have amended that to say that this part does not apply in relation to an election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth or of a State or in relation to an election to the legislature of a Territory until regulations are made for the purposes of the whole lot, section 95DD.
—So, new free time.

—No. It is simply that, if the regulations are not formulated within six months, in the due process, with us all involved and able to see and disallow them, then the lot lapses. But it is unreasonable to expect us to exclude needs that apply to the ACT election which is coming up very soon. It is unreasonable of us to say to the Government, `You must write the whole lot before the ACT election is held'. We would not be able to be involved in that process, and I think that is what Senator Walters wants to be involved in. This is a guarantee that we have our right in the formulation of the regulations and, if it is not done within the time, then it all lapses.
—What happens if the regulations are done before the time? This is the thing that concerns me.
—They'll be done.
—Yes, but we do not have time to disallow them; we have to have time to disallow.
—I am sure that the Minister will respond that it just cannot and will not happen. We are talking about until 19 December.

—It is very much my intention—and I do not think it should happen otherwise—that regulations—for instance, those that may apply to the ACT forthcoming election—be tabled in this place. I think we are coming back on 18 or 19 December and they should be available for the Parliament to consider before then. Were the regulations to apply also to any Tasmanian election, we would give the Senate the opportunity to scrutinise those regulations also by having them before us for those sittings.

—Because there is the guillotine on this Bill, rather than attempt to move an amendment at this stage, I put a question to the Minister which may alleviate our concerns. Can the Minister provide an undertaking that, when the regulations are tabled, the regulations shall allow each political party to allocate such portions of its total grant of free time to individual States or Territories in such quantities as bear a proportionate relationship to the number of first preference votes obtained by that political party or its candidates within that State or Territory compared with the total number of formal first preference votes obtained by all parties or candidates within the relevant State or Territory?

—I think I said at the start that the Tribunal would expect—and the regulations would reflect this—that the apportionment would be made on the basis of State. We would not want to leave some of our national organisations as the final arbiters as to who gets what. I think Senator O'Chee's concern is as to whether the apportionment will be made to accommodate a State breakdown rather than a broad national approach. I said earlier when I introduced this that it is anticipated that it will be done on a State by State basis.

—I am not sure that I quite understand what was said. I do not know that I necessarily agree with my colleague on that. But the matter I want to rise on is the question of the amendment that the Democrats are moving where it says `made' and `take effect'. I need a lesson on constitutional law here but, if one tables the regulation, has it not then been made and taken effect? It may then be disallowed some days later, but it has already been made and taken effect. So on that—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is the law. That is the sort of thing one has to be careful of. That is why there is a danger in doing this on the run. The amendment states `made' and `take effect'; they are made and do take effect within a short period of time. They can then be disallowed, but not retrospectively.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the amendment. I beg your pardon. Had I seen the amendment, maybe I would not have said that. But that again emphasises why we should not be doing this on the run.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Government amendment No. (20), as amended, be agreed to.

—I understand that the Government's interpretation of its draft is that one should understand the expression `static image' to include the possibility of using charts or graphs—this is the background or helpful devices to the talking head. I was a little surprised by that, and I was considering moving an amendment to in effect bring in what the majority of the Committee recommended, that is, that graphs or charts should be able to be used. I therefore ask the Minister to confirm that the Government's understanding of static image is that graphs or charts can be used.
—If it does not move, it is static, and a graph or a chart is static.

—I have a very quick question for the Minister, so that I understand. If we have a television program free ad where we have a so-called talking head and a graph or chart, does this mean that, say, the person, whether it be the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition, can point to the chart, or is that not in?
—He can do whatever he likes with it.
—But can he actually point to the chart on the television ad?

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a bit concerned about the fact that just head and shoulders and all this nonsense has been described as idiotic. Presumably, a person who is trying to explain something is able to point to a chart with a pointer, even though the pointer is moving.

—I wish to take it one step further, to totally clarify the point. The Government's draft uses the expression, `includes a single, additional static background image only'. I understand that the Government believes that to mean graphs; in other words, `a static image only' does not simply mean one graph. If Mr Hawke, Mr Keating or whoever happens to be the Prime Minister wishes to point to three separate graphs, that is within what is intended to be the restraint in this legislation.

—What is intended is the technology that allows for moving background imagery, phase-ins and phase-outs and those sorts of things. One even sees it on reports from Canberra these days where the journalists—
—The flag waves.

—One might see it in respect of that, but there is also a range of imagery for an entire program that flows behind the person speaking. That is what we are trying to stop, rather than a static chart or graph.
—I ask the Minister, and possibly the Democrats, about the 105 per cent.

—We sat and worked this out last night. I suppose if all of us were here we would have to have some command of the numbers, but we never got to 105 per cent. In fact, at one stage we were concerned that we would finish up with something like 81 per cent. It is fair to say that in the assessments that we made there is a capacity for 100 per cent. Of course, in cases where there are no emerging parties it could fall as low as 90 per cent, but 105 to 106 per cent was not anticipated.

—I ask the Minister and his advisers to follow this through with me. We start with 90 per cent; we have provision DF which says that the independent senators get no less than 5 per cent; if there are three independent senators, three times five is 15, plus 90 equals 105. Is the Government assuming that there will never be three independent senators, so it could not give a stuff? Is that right or wrong?

—Regarding Senator Macdonald's concerns about independents coming through and how much of the cake they can get, I am advised that the maximum is no less than 5 per cent but up to 10 per cent. There is a guarantee of 5 per cent but a maximum of 10 per cent to be shared.
—No less than 5 per cent. That means everyone must have 5 per cent. If there are four independents, four times five is 20 and if you add 20 to 90 you get 110.
—No, Mr Chairman. That 10 per cent would be shared amongst all those eligible. If there are not more than two, then those two get 5 per cent each.
—It doesn't say that.
—Read it.
—The question before the Chair is that Government amendment No. 20, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for consideration of the Bill has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 17, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent further consideration of the bill till 5 p.m. this day.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, I seek an extension of time using this contingent notice of motion because of the very matters that are being raised by those behind me, including Senator Walters. There are important issues still unresolved as a result of this guillotined debate.In particular, I am still not sure whether my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne was able to move his amendment before you brought down the axe and told us our time was up. It would be appalling if there is a circulated Opposition amendment that was not put.

PARA.TAB: Apart from that, there are the very important issues of the constitutionality of what the Government is seeking to do, which remain unresolved. There is the constitutional question of appropriation of property—in this instance, from the television stations concerned—for which no compensation is being offered, which is highly debatable. The Democrats, in particular, would probably realise that there have been further opinions circulating in the Parliament this morning suggesting that, in fact, that will fail.

If it fails, and it is severed, the Bill will return to what the Government wanted in the first place, and not what the Democrats wanted. In other words, it will return to a full ban without the talking heads exception that the Democrats say would advance democracy. I would have thought that if it was the Democrats' objective to get their amendments into law, not simply into this piece of legislation, they would want that issue properly resolved.

There is the second constitutional question in relation to the power of the Commonwealth to bind the States in their elections. That issue has not been properly debated or resolved in this chamber. It has been put to me—and I do not doubt it, as it has been put by most eminent institutional experts—that there is a very good chance that the Bill will fail on that ground. It will fall because, quite reasonably, the Commonwealth should not be able to interfere in the electoral process within the States. What it does in its own backyard is its own business, but this Government, because it is broke in the States as well as in the Commonwealth, wants to prohibit electoral advertising within each of the State elections.

I do not think that is well understood outside this Parliament at the moment. The Government is not just banning electoral advertising in Commonwealth elections, it wants to ban it in all State elections and in all local government elections as well. There is a very good chance that the High Court will say that it is beyond the Commonwealth's competence, that the Commonwealth cannot do that and the Bill falls. On that ground, that should properly be debated and explored by this Parliament before it finishes its business.

The issue that I mentioned concerning the appropriation of property—that is, the income earning potential of television stations—should be explored properly. Even the Government has an interest in exploring that properly because if it is severed, the Government wins and the Democrats lose; but if it cannot be severed, the whole of the Bill falls under that head.

These issues should be debated properly. The only way they can be looked at properly would be for this Bill to be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Legal constitutional experts could be called before that Committee and could put their evidence on the public record, so that when this Parliament comes back and debates the report of that Committee, it would have the advice of the most eminent constitutional experts in Australia as to whether it is debating something that is unconstitutional or not.

It is important that debates in this place be on the basis of the best available information. Even Senator Schacht presumably would want a well-informed debate. But the course of action that the Government has taken in relation to this Bill, that is to guillotine it and not allow full and proper debate, has the effect that the constitutional experts' advice will not be put before the chamber. That is a wrong and inappropriate way with which to deal with legislation. In particular, it is not an appropriate way to deal with legislation in the House of debate of the Australian Parliament, that is, the Australian Senate.

It is not good enough. If the Democrats realise the foolishness of what they have agreed to and allow an extension of time and then allow us to refer this Bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee this afternoon, then democracy and proper legislative process will be advanced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support my colleague's appeal for more time. It is obvious that we have run out of time.
—You have had 40 hours.

—We have had 40 hours, but everyone has the right to speak and everyone has the right to put his proposition. To accommodate that, we sat for almost 24 hours until 8 o'clock in the morning. We got on with the job and now we are on the amendments in the committee stage. I think that everyone in the chamber would agree that we have tried—all bets were off, politics were out—to find successful amendments. But as the amendments unwind, we find all sorts of unintended consequences coming up that will make this Bill impossible.

PARA.TAB: One Australian Democrats leader lost her political head because she flew in the face of the requirement that party members believe in freedom of speech. That is their fundamental belief and there is no doubt that the Australian Democrats senator from Tasmania would agree with that. If Senator Kernot's amendment is carried and we disallow the regulations, we will invalidate the Bill. We will then have a complete ban on television and radio advertising.

There is no escape from this. The Government has probably led the Democrats down that path. We have found that we will have a Bill that will be overthrown by the court and a total ban on advertising. I do not think that is what the Democrats want. I believe that they want some type of freedom of speech, but we will have absolutely no freedom of speech.

Please do not rush this Bill through. It is one of the most important Bills that we have ever had to face. It really touches on what we in Australia fundamentally believe in and that is the right of free speech. I believe the Democrats support that right, but because they have been locked into this situation they are going to blow their own constituency apart—their own constituency demands freedom of speech. That is what I understand the Democrats to be about. They are for freedom of speech and they want that to be pushed forward on the radio and—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're not for freedom of speech.

—I believe that is what their constituency is for but somehow they have been waylaid by the Labor Party here and have been directed down another path. The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has taken them one step at a time down that path. Now we will end up with a total ban on advertising and absolutely no contact with the electorate through television. But even if that goes the other way, we have taken $30m away from private and commercial enterprises—$18m of Federal funding and $12m of State funding. We have put a gun at the television stations' heads and said, `We demand $30m or we will pull the trigger, that is, take your licence away'. Is that the sort of freedom that the Democrats stand for? If it is, I do not understand their constitution, although I thought I did. They are flying in the face of what their constituency is all about.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the Democrats, I see that they are worried. They know that I am hitting the point. I say to the Democrats senators here that they cannot, if they believe in freedom of speech, just walk up to a television station and say, `We demand $30m of your money'. That is what we would have to do. We would just be walking up and saying, `If you do not give us that $30m, you will not have a licence'. I cannot understand where the freedom is in that.

There are other problems that this Bill is facing. Parties such as the National Party are being forced to stand in Melbourne seats, where they will get 3 or 4 per cent of the vote, so that they get an increased appropriated time. The whole Bill is flawed. It is flawed all the way through and therefore we have to give it more examination. To do this we need more time. I ask the Democrats to extend this time. It is a very important Bill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just ask honourable senators to cast their eyes around the chamber and recall the incident while Senator Boswell was speaking. Over in one corner, the Government and the Democrats were negotiating yet again. If ever there were an example of how flawed this Bill is, how confused this chamber is as a result of the legislation we have before us—
—Mr Chairman, I have a point of order.
—It is the deals that are being done to try to fix and patch up this—
—Order! There is a point of order.

—I am raising a point of order. Sit down, you are not at the football now! I am being misrepresented here. I had a very vigorous discussion with the Australian Democrats. I always have and always will.
—There is no point of order.

—Clearly it was not a point of order, Mr Chairman, and I thank you for that ruling. Clearly it was made just to waste time. My point is that we have legislation that touches at the heart of democracy, its freedom of speech. It is important legislation before this Parliament and before this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The Government Whip came in earlier today and asked why we wanted an extension of time to 12.45 p.m., as we had already had X number of hours. Senator Schacht interjected a moment ago that we had had 40 hours so why would we want more time. I will tell them why we want more time. Because the Government has amendments and amendments upon its amendments on legislation that it has introduced in this Parliament. It is the Government that has been fumbling, inept, incompetent and inefficient in presenting legislation and amendments to this chamber. We on this side of the chamber, the Democrats and the Opposition, have had to attempt to amend on the run the Government's legislation with the principal Act. We have had only a few hours in which to try to put this legislation into some reasonable shape and form.

Yesterday Senator Bishop and other speakers put on the record constitutional advice from Sir Maurice Byers that this Bill will be constitutionally invalid. If it is constitutionally invalid, we will resort, under the broadcasting provisions, to the Government's original intention, which is a complete ban on advertising. The legislation as it is now with the amendments that we have made and the bandaids that we have put on it for the last few hours means that the councillors and the Mayor who are standing for election to the Brisbane City Council—which, incidentally, is bigger than the Government of Tasmania—are totally disenfranchised from advertising in any form. That is what we have done—disenfranchised that section of local government within the community.

I remind the Government Whip, Senator Schacht and other members in this chamber that the Opposition made no request for General Business today. That is 2 1/2 hours of our time that we have devoted to debating this legislation. We did not seek to take it away from the Government. We gave it up for the purpose of debating this legislation.

Another point is that the ABC has raised the difficulties that it sees with this legislation as it relates to the ABT. I know the Democrats are concerned about that, as we are. But there simply has been no time to consider drafting amendments. The Table Office and the draftsmen have done an outstanding job in very difficult circumstances in trying to keep the amendments up to members and senators. But the point is that within the ABC there are difficulties and they have been identified. We have not had an opportunity to address those in the form of drafting amendments. We ought to refer this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so that it can then undertake appropriate drafting and report back to this chamber.

I remind the chamber that this will not delay the passage of the legislation. The House of Representatives is not coming back until 17 and 18 December. The Senate has a full sitting week next week. The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs can meet tomorrow and give consideration to constitutional advice on the validity of the laws that we are attempting to pass, recognising that if the laws are invalid, as clearly eminent advice has suggested they are, they will be tested and thrown out. The Australian Democrats then need to consider that, if the laws are invalid and thrown out, there will be a total ban and they will have been sucked in to adopting the Government's procedures.

We obviously need more time for drafting amendments to take account of the ABC's concerns and so that the Senate can give appropriate and proper consideration to the ABC's concerns and to the constitutional advice that has been put on the table. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Hill and want to reiterate the remarks that I made yesterday about the legality of the provisions banning advertising. When I raised the matter, I had not seen the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers contained in the letter from Allen Allen and Hemsley. When I subsequently got that advice, I took care to table it in the Parliament because it confirmed all the points that I had made earlier in the day. I can only stress in this debate that this just highlights the ineptitude of the Minister handling this Bill. If the Bill had been handled by a better Minister, we may not have ended up in this mess.
—Mumbles and fumbles.

—The way old fumbles—that is a very good name for him—handled this legislation, the way the Government has handled it, is an absolute embarrassment and disgrace to the Government. The attitude it took in its negotiations with the Australian Democrats was to first present them with a deal which they thought was sustainable. The Government has misled the Australian Democrats just as it has misled the rest of the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus stood in this chamber yesterday and had the audacity, when questioned on the point of constitutionality, to say that he had had a bit of a chat with one of the legal advisers. He did not have anything in writing and, therefore, information could not be tabled in this Parliament for us to look at.

One can only say that that is typical of the way this entire legislation has been handled. It has been guillotined through the lower House and then brought into this chamber in such a shambles that we still have pieces of paper cascading down from the rooftops like snow in a northern hemisphere Christmas. It is an absolute disgrace and condemnation of this Government that it is so inept and behind in its ability to handle legislation that it is not on top of handling its own department or the advice that comes to it. When it comes to negotiating with the Australian Democrats, the Government has totally misled them.

The proposition I put yesterday is this: who is supposed to pay for the provisions relating to the ad ban section of the Bill, that is, that part which commandeers $18m-worth of time from television stations? The shareholders of the television stations are the people who are supposed to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats call that free time.

—The Australian Democrats have the audacity to say that it is free. As I said yesterday, there is no such thing as a free lunch and there is no such thing as free advertising; somebody has to foot the bill. In this case, the Government is expropriating the rights of those television stations. It is commandeering them and then transferring them to its own and other people's benefit. That is an acquisition within the meaning of the Constitution and the Government is not doing it on just terms. That is the basis of the argument that I put yesterday—property, acquisition and no just terms. Sir Maurice Byers has also expressed an opinion on this and says that the legislation is invalid.

PARA.TAB: I would have expected that a competent Minister, anyone with any degree of ability at all, not only would have had these constitutional points dealt with but also would have anticipated them and, in good faith, would have tabled relevant documents in this Parliament and made them available to us so that we could make a decision on the matter.

It is an absolute disgrace that we had to make the protest we did the night before last by sitting right through the evening and through breakfast so that we could make the Australian people aware of the incompetence of the Minister who has charge of this Bill. Quite frankly, I feel sorry for his colleagues. I would have thought that, as he is a Minister, there would be some reasonable expectation that he would have some degree of competence, but the Government has given this most complicated legislation to the least able of its Ministers.

The manner in which the number of amendments that, as I said, have come cascading through, and the misunderstandings and the areas of uncertainty show quite clearly that we need further time to debate this issue and that it needs to go to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

As I said yesterday when I raised the question of validity of the legislation, the Minister had the hide to stand up and call me a bush lawyer. I do not think I can think of a term that I could apply to him that sums him up more than `simply incompetent', and I say that he ought to resign.

The other thing is that the Senate needs time. Sir Maurice Byers's opinion has come to light and, as the Government has used Sir Maurice Byers over time to advise it, presumably it will give weight to both the original speech I made and the opinion that Sir Maurice Byers has put down. Clearly, this matter must go to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee so that we can have some confidence in the matter we are dealing with. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is in a total shambles. I ask the Government where it stands as far as States rights are concerned. We have a Bill in front of us that is going to impose—

—I will come to Senator Schacht's argument in a minute. We are in a shambles and we are pretending to set the standard for elections in Western Australia, Queensland and anywhere else you may like. This is the shambles that we have put up with for the last two days.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, unbeknown to me until the other day, we are setting the standard for local government elections. If any elections have been run properly in Australia to date, they would be in local government. It means that local government in Perth, Southern Cross, Kalgoorlie or even in Victoria, if they have them down there, will be set by the shambles of this Parliament.

What are we going to do? Going further down the track, what am I going to say to the regional and remote people of Western Australia this weekend in regard to what they can do in their local government elections, or even in the Federal elections, because radio is out? Radio is the only medium that reaches every square foot of Australia and it is totally out. What am I going to say to those people? All of this has happened because the Labor Party is broke.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is broke too!

—That is why it has happened. The Government is broke also: all Labor governments around Australia are broke. We have got forced donations, which Senator Schacht questioned me about the other night. He believes that, because people have a licence to run a radio station, they should be forced to donate to election campaigns around Australia. Anyone else with licences from any government—Federal, State or local—has to go and get his cut. That is what is called protectionism, and the Mafia existed on that many years ago.

PARA.TAB: Let us go down the line of these licences. When half of Comcar's services are done away with, it will be quite okay because we will be able to use free taxis. Taxis are licensed, so we can use our share of them for free. This is exactly what Senator Schacht said the other night. It is just as well prostitutes are not licensed in Australia because he would want his cut of them as well.
Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave Senator Schacht the hint on it. If he goes down that line, that is what we will get to. The Labor Party is broke and it wants all media shareholders around Australia to carry its message. I am afraid that that is not the way to go. The Australian Democrats are broke, and that is why they are backing the Government. The Australian Democrats have had their overtime cut. That was going into party funds; that is why they are broke.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot should not laugh at me. Senator Lilywhite is the one who upset everyone about private vehicles on the weekends, because she abused them during the week. The Australian Democrats are broke and we have to put up with it.

PARA.TAB: Under this Bill the Government cannot advertise for the last three months. Can Senator Ray tell me whether, leading up to an election, he will paint out or put bags over those signs along the road that I saw yesterday on the way back from Melbourne saying `Federal Government Building Better Roads'? Can someone answer that? More detailed information has to be put in front us.

It is being proposed that we give the Bill to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee to deal with. Can anyone—even the Democrats—tell me that that would not be cheaper than going to the High Court? Senator Coulter is on record as saying that the High Court should settle it. That will cost money. We are trying to save $18m here, but others would give three times the $18m to the High Court and the solicitors that go with it. The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee is free, so give the Bill to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of very serious problems that still have to be considered in this Bill. I want to briefly mention again two of them. The first one concerns the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which has very serious and real concerns about this Bill. They are concerns which need to be inspected much more closely. The purpose of this motion is to get this Bill referred to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee so that these sorts of things can be looked at. The ABC has genuine and very serious concerns that need to be looked at.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, there is the question of the 100 per cent. I agree entirely with Senator Bishop. Senator Bolkus is obviously incapable of performing his job but, more than that, he cannot even add up. I do not care what he or his advisers say—proposed new section 95DF clearly says that a person who fits into this category, an independent senator, gets a period determined by the Tribunal, `being a period equal to not less than 5% of the total time in respect of the election'.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are three such candidates, 5 per cent is multiplied by three and comes to 15 per cent. Add that to 90 per cent and it comes to 105 per cent. That has to be looked at by some decent lawyers and by people who can understand, which obviously Senator Bolkus cannot. There is the question of the expropriation of $18m of citizens' money. In the days of Magna Carta, governments were stopped from walking in and simply expropriating money.

PARA.TAB: Senator Zakharov interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like the Government taking Senator Zakharov's house without compensation. If it did that she would be the first one up in arms. But when the Government does it to someone else's property, honourable senators opposite think it is a laughing matter. They think it is good fun to take money from a fellow Australian citizen. An amount of $18m is being expropriated by the state and not a cent of compensation is being suggested. That sort of thing caused a revolution in 1215; it is the sort of thing that has caused revolutions throughout the centuries. Yet the Government laughs, thinking it is funny to take someone else's property.

PARA.TAB: I also mention the Brisbane City Council, which is a very big government. I am sure that you, Mr Chairman, and your Whip will be straight on the phone to Lord Mayor Soorley about stopping the Federal Government making rules on what that city council can publicise and how it can advertise the lies that it wants to print on its advertisements. All this will be stopped. That may be the one saving grace in the whole thing. Even the Brisbane City Council Labor Party—which told such massive lies in the last city council election—should be allowed the opportunity of advertising its message. This Bill completely stops that.

We got amendments at 9 o'clock this morning. At 10 o'clock we got a different set of the same amendments. Not only are we confused, but the Government is confused too. The Minister is confused and totally incapable of running this debate. I intend to sit down and allow Senator Walters to say something before the time expires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read into Hansard the editorial from today's Mercury. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Government senators and supportive Australian Democrats will hang their heads today—from exhaustion. They should be hanging with shame.

PARA.TAB: The senators—after sitting for the longest single session in 26 years—are poised to pass legislation which is undemocratic and un-Australian. It discriminates. It censors.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the basis of this entire legislation. It is undemocratic, it is un-Australian, it discriminates and it censors. As has been said by so many members on this side, the whole—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That at the expiration of the time allotted, the questions be put in respect of any remaining amendments to the bill circulated by the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and an Independent Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: That is to make sure that all those amendments which have been circulated can be voted upon. I think Senator Crichton-Browne's matter was already before us. Just to make sure that nothing slips through the net, that motion will catch it all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I would seek to move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent further consideration of the Bill, namely, a consideration of the Bill by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, before the third reading is put.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, I would move this contingent notice of motion because I believe that the Australian Democrats must have been confused—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! My advice is that I have to dispose of Senator McMullan's motion first. I put the motion moved by Senator McMullan. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no—
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Are we permitted to discuss this motion? I was standing when—
—Order! There is no time left for debate. The time has expired, so I have to put the motion.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. If there is no time left for the debate, how can the Minister then put a completely new motion before the chair?
—Because the Committee just gave him leave to do so.
—How can you give leave if there is no time left?
—The Committee can do anything by leave.

—Mr Chairman, pursuing the matter raised by Senator Macdonald, I was asked whether we would give leave for the motion to be moved—that is, the motion to allow amendments circulated to be voted upon. I said that we would give leave for that to be moved, obviously. You are about to call the motion, despite the expiry of time, that the amendments circulated be voted upon. Senator Macdonald has asked to debate that motion, which is quite legitimate, as I understand it. If you rule that this is a procedural matter upon which there can be no debate then, pursuant to another contingent notice of motion in my name, I will move that that part of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prohibit debate upon Senator McMullan's motion.

—There are two issues here. One is whether this particular motion Senator McMullan has moved falls within that ambit of the guillotine. That is for you, Mr Chairman, to decide, on advice. The second point is to clarify it. Mr Chairman, you were in the process of putting that motion when Senator Macdonald sought the call. I think, to be fair to him, he rose not after the noes but between the ayes and the noes.
—It was a bit earlier than that.

—I can usually pick a winner at the races. The way I saw it was that Senator Macdonald rose in mid-point. I do not know what the ruling is on that either. I am saying that it is usually the practice of the Chair, if this is debatable and the call has not been finalised because the Chairman has not seen the honourable senator, to continue to give that senator the call. I do not think there is much doubt about that; that has been the Senate practice. Mr Chairman, I do not know whether you want to rule on that second matter: if someone rises after you have started calling the ayes and the noes, whether a senator is recognised and whether that is done at the mid-point or right up to the end. That is the second area that we would have to determine.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish to speak to the point of order. You had the motion already before the Chair from Senator McMullan and it seems to me that he should be following the procedures as set out in 142 (4), which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: For the purpose of bringing to the conclusion any proceedings . . .
It sets out the mechanism which he has outlined and that seems to me to be the appropriate course to follow. That motion is before the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order.
