The motion as moved by Senator McMullan was not as Senator Coulter described it, `to bring to a cessation'; it was indeed to extend, because the cessation came at the end of the application of the guillotine. The position is, as I understand it, that Senator Macdonald was on his feet at the first available moment, that is, when nobody else was on his or her feet.
—The Government imposed the guillotine.

—Quite right. Indeed, there is a motion before the Chair from Senator McMullan which we ought to be debating. Senator Macdonald was on his feet at the first available time that the Standing Orders permit him to be on his feet; that is, when there is nobody else on his or her feet. Mr Chairman, I do not know whether you were gazing at the Government side and did not notice him before you started to speak. That is quite possible. I do not know whether Senator Robert Ray was gazing somewhere else before he saw Senator Macdonald, but the bottom line is we have a motion before the Chair which properly ought to be debated, and you have a foreshadowed motion from Senator Hill. If you choose to rule against the right to debate the motion, as moved by Senator McMullan, then we will take another course of action. Clearly, as Senator Macdonald was on his feet at the proper time, the proper thing to do is to allow him now to debate the motion as moved by Senator McMullan.
—Could I suggest that Senator Macdonald seek leave to speak to the motion. I am suggesting that because I think that leave will be granted.
—I appreciate that, Mr Chairman. Thank you for the courtesy and for the advice. Some of my colleagues may want to speak on the motion as well.
—Senator Macdonald, I am ruling that the—
—Is it possible for me to speak on the point of order, Mr Chairman?

—Let me make an explanation, and you might like to add that to your point of order as well. I am just trying to be helpful. My understanding is that leave was granted to move a motion in relation to the amendments. My ruling is that leave was granted to move the motion. Leave was not granted to debate the motion.
—How do we know that?

—Because time has expired under the closure motion. That is my ruling. Senator Macdonald, if you wish to disagree with the ruling there are procedures to do so. But I suggest that you seek leave to speak to the motion.
—Mr Chairman, I thought you were going to give me an opportunity to discuss the point of order.
—Yes, if you are on a point of order, you can speak to the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. First of all can I just clear up the matter that Senator Ray raised? Maybe the tapes of the television coverage will show this, if it is necessary. I believe that as Senator Hill was taking his seat I was rising. Mr Chairman, we do have a difficulty at times—
—I have not disputed that at all.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. If you happen to be looking the other way, it is very difficult to attract your attention unless an honourable senator does something. Thank you for taking that point. On the ruling that you have just made, that leave was sought to move the motion, you said that leave was not sought to debate the motion. At this stage could I possibly seek leave for the Opposition to debate the motion?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contingent upon notice of motion standing in my name, I would seek to move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would enable debate on the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, we are pursuing this matter because it is of vital interest. The Australian Labor Party has taken the decision—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have to be careful. Do you have a contingent motion which covers that matter? I cannot find one.

—I have a contingent notice of motion which covers the right to suspend all Standing Orders outside the period of the guillotine. There are four specific ones in relation to the guillotine. This is actually outside the guillotine.
—It is not. That is the whole point.
—Why don't you read the Standing Orders?
—Which one?

—Standing order 142(4) provides that circulated amendments by the Government shall be put to the vote at the end of the time. In order to avoid further procedural matters, Senator McMullan has gone outside the terms of the guillotine and has sought leave to move a motion to allow other circulated amendments to be put. That is not within the scope of the guillotine at all. He has moved that motion and in the normal proper way we have sought to debate that motion. I respectfully suggest that the matter is being wrongly ruled upon to say that we do not have a right to debate that motion. I find that astonishing. If that is your ruling, under the normal contingent notice of motion, I then take the procedure that allows us to suspend Standing Orders to debate matters that are outside the guillotine. That is the basis on which I am so moving.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on a point of order: I draw the attention of the Chair to the language of 142(4) in the second last phrase of that particular paragraph where it says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . any other question requisite to dispose of the business before the Senate or the committee, . . .

That is properly within the ambit of the guillotine. Senator McMullan sought and was granted the leave of the chamber to circulate and to have further amendments considered in the voting pursuant to the guillotine—that is what he sought leave for—and the amendments in question now have the status of another question being requisite to dispose of the business before the Senate or the Committee. If there is any conceivable doubt as to whether Senator McMullan's motion is within the scope of the guillotine, that doubt is utterly removed by the language of 142(4), and I suggest that you rule accordingly, Mr Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have ruled accordingly that this is part of the procedures of standing order 142, so it is still within the ambit of the closure motion and therefore no debate can occur on the motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on the point of order: That seems to be a new interpretation you have given to your previous ruling. I want to address the point raised by Senator Evans which of course was a selective reading from the relevant standing order. The words quoted by Senator Evans of standing order 142(4) are:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . and any other question requisite to dispose of the business before the Senate or committee, . . .
The rest of the sentence reads:
. . . and no other amendments, new clauses or schedules shall be proposed.

That is exactly why Senator McMullan had to seek leave outside the terms of the guillotine to ask to put that motion. Very specifically, the standing order is quite clear so that the motion that Senator McMullan moved is outside the guillotine. If it was not, he would not have had to seek leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to foreign affairs.
—I think the piece of advice that came from my colleague over there, to you, Senator Evans, that you ought to stick to foreign affairs, is a good one.

—Order! The Chair is just trying to assist the committee in line with the Senate Standing Orders. I have looked at the contingent notices of motion and no contingent notice of motion refers to standing order 142 in relation to allowing a motion that is moved at the end of the time to be debated.
—I am not moving under the guillotine contingent notices of motion. I am moving my general contingent notice of motion No. 2, which provides that I have a right to move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate. . .

SPEECH.PARA: Under that contingent notice of motion, I have sought suspension of standing orders in order that the motion moved by Senator McMullan be debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, I am not necessarily opposing what Senator Hill says. If Senator Hill is not moving a contingent notice of motion relating to the guillotine but is moving an ordinary contingent notice of motion, how does that rest with Standing Order 142(6), which says that at the time all other business shall be pushed aside—Senator Hill's motion comes under `other business' rather than guillotine business—and a vote shall be then taken? It seems to me that that may even preclude his contingent notice of motion if it does not specifically relate to the guillotine.

—Mr Chairman, I also raise a point of order. It is a bit puzzling to me how Senator Hill can contend that his contingent notice of motion No. 2 applies. As I read it, it says that he is going to move that motion contingent on the Senate on any day concluding its consideration of any item of business and prior to the Senate proceeding to the consideration of another one.
—No. That is another one.
—That is in No. 2, as I read it, on page 45 of the Notice Paper. So it seems to me, Mr Chairman, that it does not apply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a look at contingent notice of motion No. 2. It does not apply because it reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: To move (contingent on the Senate on any day concluding its consideration of any item of business and prior to the Senate proceeding to the consideration of another item of business). . . ..
The Senate has not concluded an item of business. It is still on the business of the particular Bill in front of us and the closure motion. So there is no contingent notice of motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order on that point. You are obviously interpreting the leave which was granted to Senate McMullan as lengthening the time of the guillotine. That is not what it did. When Senator Hill rose to put his motion, in fact business had been concluded. In terms of guillotine, business had been concluded. There had been no vote on Senator McMullan's motion at all. The reason that Senator Hill's motion was foreshadowed and, indeed, is being put is that you have denied rightful debate on Senator McMullan's motion. Therefore, we have no option but to use that mechanism. There has been no vote on Senator McMullan's motion. If the motion is lost—which is quite possible—the guillotine would still apply. So it is quite clear that Senator Hill is, in fact, speaking at the time of conclusion. The point that Senator Ray raised about standing order 142(6) is not relevant because it talks about the commencement of business. What we are talking about is the conclusion of business. Let us remember that it is the Government's guillotine; we did not want it.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order.
—Order! I am making a ruling, Senator Walters. You can take your point of order after—
—You will not give me permission to put a point of order, Mr Chairman?
—The ruling that I am making is that we have a motion before us from Senator McMullan and there is no debate on the motion. Therefore, I intend to put the motion. The question is that the motion—
—Is the Government now withdrawing its leave from Senator Macdonald?
—Senator Macdonald did not have leave.
—Mr Chairman, could I seek leave for me to debate Senator McMullan's motion?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The question that I want to raise—I do not want to specifically debate this with Senator McMullan—is simply what his motion is and what we are to understand by it. I thought I heard him mumble very quickly—and I do not use that in a derogatory sense—that it was to deal with Democrat and Independent motions that had not been dealt with. He mumbled something about Senator Crichton-Browne's motion. I do not know whether that is correct or not. If Senator McMullan does not happen to be correct and Senator Crichton-Browne's motion is not to be dealt with, does that mean that he is excluded and we will then deal with the Democrat and Independent motions? I am not quite sure. This is why I want to discuss the matter.

PARA.TAB: Might I say, however, that this is simply another example of how the Democrats and the Labor Party have completely hijacked democracy in this country and how they have completely put the question of free speech under such a timetable, under such a guillotine, that all of these sorts of problems come up. Senator McMullan was forced to move an amendment after the debate has been supposedly guillotined. I understood that Senator McMullan and his Party, and Senator Coulter and his group down at the end of the chamber, moved a guillotine motion for consideration of the Bill to be extended beyond 7.30 last night. The time has been extended on a number of occasions since then, the last being an hour ago. The time allotted for consideration of this matter, which is of such great importance to free speech and democracy, is being extended all the time.

As I understand Senator McMullan's motion—maybe I do not understand it properly—it is to allow further things to be done after the guillotine, which the Labor Party and the Democrats insisted be perpetrated on Australian democracy. This simply shows the whole problem with using the guillotine and rushing through one of the most important Bills ever for Australian democracy. The Democrats, who came into this Parliament to keep the bastards honest, have crawled across with the Labor Party, and I hope the people of Australia will understand that.

These are very important matters. I think the amendment which Senator McMullan is moving is important. Although I do not speak for the Opposition, I am sure that it is one that we would support. It is important to democracy that all of these things be tried. But we are rushing them through in two minutes or whatever it is going to take. We are going to have no discussion on them. We are going to be in the position where other legislation will be rushed through in this way. There is absolutely no doubt that this Bill will be back before this chamber. It will be before the High Court of Australia. It will come out of the High Court in a form which the Democrats did not intend. They are going to be conned and it serves them right. There will be no talking heads at all.

Senator Kernot got advice from Sir Maurice Byers, so she understands that. There will be no talking heads so we will be back to a complete ban. I hope that the Democrats revel in that when it happens; it serves them right.

The ABC is a most important part of this discussion. It is something that I understood Senator Kernot to be particularly interested in. What we do with the ABC is a very important matter. We should not tie it up with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who voted against it?
—I am giving Senator Kernot the opportunity to change my mind by having it fully discussed by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
—Don't you lie.

—I did not have the chance to hear Senator Kernot's argument because her Party guillotined it and pushed it through so we could not debate it. How can I be expected to understand that when that lot guillotined it through and absolutely prevented adequate debate? I needed to consider the question of the ABC.

PARA.TAB: I was asking the Democrats to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so that I could go along, understand and agree on what it was all about if I could be convinced that the ABC had made its case. That could be done in the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. But what happened? These people would not even agree to that. Coming back to Senator McMullan's motion, I simply ask Senator McMullan for some clarification. What does it mean? Does it mean that only Democrat and Independent amendments will be put?

TALK.START.PARA: —All amendments were circulated. He did say that.

—I had not heard that, Senator Ray. Thank you for telling me. He did speak rather quietly and quickly. That is the thing that I wanted to raise in the debate, Senator McMullan, and I thank you for giving me leave to raise that question with you.

—by leave—I believe Senator Macdonald has just abused the privilege of the opportunity. I just have to put on the record the absolute dishonesty and hypocrisy of the discussion in this place on the matter of the ABC. My amendments on the ABC were some of first pre-circulated in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The second point I want to make is that we were discussing the ABC when the Government and the Opposition indicated that they would not support my amendments. Just a few minutes ago, the Liberal Party came over to me and offered me one of those disgusting deals that it finds so odious—that if I would to agree to the request—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Olsen! Senator Kemp! Order!

—We are very selective about the way we use the word `deals' in this place. I want to put on the record that I was offered that, if we would vote to send this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Opposition would be willing to look again at the ABC question. Senator Macdonald's comments are totally dishonest, and I want to put that on the record.
—Order! I am putting the question.
—Mr Chairman—
—I am putting the question.
—Point of order.
—I am putting the question.
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! Take your seat. I am putting the question.
—Senator Walters rose prior to the question being put.
—Do you have a point of order in relation to my putting the question? Otherwise, I will put the question.
—I have, Mr Chairman.
—What is your point of order?

—Mr Chairman, my point of order is that you have not put the question and enabled Senator Kernot to seek leave and you have then stood and refused me the opportunity also to seek leave. I request that you allow other members on this side to seek leave before you put the question.

—Mr Chairman, I must say that I support Senator Walters on the point of order. It is possible for a senator, before we put this, to seek leave to speak on the matter. There is no way that you can give them the call to speak on the matter—your ruling, I believe, is impeccable on that. It is possible though for any senator in the chamber to seek leave under standing orders to speak on it. I tell you what: you have no chance of getting it, having abused it the last time.
—Mr Chairman, I seek leave to ask you a question.
—Is leave granted?
—No!
—It is an echo.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Chairman, you made a ruling a little while ago. Could you let me know why it was necessary for the Manager of Government Business, Senator McMullan, to seek leave to put a motion if it was inside the guillotine time?
—Because the time had expired.
—Mr Chairman, did I hear Senator Walsh use a term in relation to Senator Walters that I believe this chamber censured him for once before? If so, would you kindly make him withdraw it.
—I did not hear anything. It is very difficult for the Chair to hear anything sometimes. The question is that Senator McMullan's motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear what was said. All I heard from that corner of the chamber was the word `no' and someone told me it was an echo.
—Mr Chairman, you have not answered my question.
—I certainly did. I said that he had sought leave because time had expired.
—But you then said it was inside the guillotine time. If it was inside the guillotine time, why would he have to seek leave?
—Senator Crichton-Browne, did you have a point of order?
—Yes. I use this opportunity to seek leave to speak for a few moments in respect of an amendment which has been circulated—
—It is a separate time—
—Mr Chairman, I think that highlights the fiasco. It is not possible to move an amendment—is that what Senator Ray is arguing?

—Senator Crichton-Browne, are you concerned about whether your amendment was moved? If you are, I have ruled that your amendment was circulated and it is, therefore, covered by Senator McMullan's motion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you Senator Watson. I wish to seek leave to speak for a couple of moments on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to ask you a question which relates to Senator Walters's question. I and, I believe, a number of other senators on this side of the chamber, did not completely understand the answer. I seek leave to put that question to you.
—I suppose you have put the question to me, have you not?
—I have not. I will not cheat on the time or take time to put the question unless leave is granted.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time Senator McMullan sought leave to have the remaining amendments put collectively, the time for the guillotine had already passed by some considerable period. It is not a question of getting near to the time a guillotine operates and then deciding that, because we are near the end, we ought to do the sensible thing—and I think Senator McMullan's motion is the sensible thing. We had passed through the time for the guillotine.

PARA.TAB: Since we have passed through that, why are we not on some other business? Was there just a general understanding that the guillotine did not have to be taken notice of and, therefore, we continued? Or is it the case that some procedural motion had been moved to extend it? If a procedural motion had not been moved to extend it, were we, by some ladies' and gentlemen's agreement, continuing? We were well outside the time. We are not talking about a couple of minutes here, we are talking about a considerable period of time. We were not just near the end of it. My confusions arises, Mr Chairman, because your answer to Senator Walters was that the time had expired. If we were at the point of expiration, I would understand what you were saying, because people would say—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. We gave Senator Vanstone leave to ask a question which I thought she asked about 3 1/2 minutes ago and she is now making a speech.
—Mr Chairman, it will not take much longer; I think you understand the point I am making.
—I understand the question you are asking.

—If we were right at the point of expiration, I could understand your reply to Senator Walters. As we were not, as we were well past that expiration, as we were clearly, in your mind, in some other form of business that required leave for Senator McMullan, why are we not in this other form of business that will allow Senator Hill to move his motion?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, I will make an explanation and it is the last one I wish to make. If any honourable senator still has any queries, I think I should put out a paper on the matter. Section 142 (4) of the Senate Standing Orders states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . any other question requisite to disposal of the business before the Senate or committee. . .

PARA.TAB: The honourable senator is quite correct, the time had expired, but the guillotine had not expired; the guillotine is still in operation. I do not like the word, but the `closure' is still in operation until the business has been disposed of. Certainly time had expired but the closure had not expired. Because time had expired, I asked Senator McMullan to move it by leave. At this stage, I intend to put the motion moved by Senator McMullan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I rise on a point of order.
—You need to report progress now.
—It is Question Time.
—Order! Three honourable senators are trying to speak at once. I will take Senator Teague.

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. It being past the hour of 2 o'clock, under the Standing and Sessional Orders, I put it to you that the Chair needs to seek leave to report progress. At 2 o'clock we are supposed to begin Question Time.
—We are in the middle of business, and the business has to be disposed of before we go to Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move the motion that I foreshadowed some time ago under my contingent notices of motion, and that is:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent further consideration of the bill without limitation of time.

SPEECH.PARA: I move that because important questions need to be resolved as to the constitutionality of what the Government is doing by banning advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Please keep speaking while I check that there is a contingent notice of motion.

—It is No. 17. This is not the motion that I moved some time ago which was to extend debate until 5 o'clock tonight; this is to direct the Bill immediately to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so that it might consider a number of serious matters. The first concerns the ABC. Contrary to what Senator Kernot indicated a moment ago, we are prepared to look at amendments to allow the ABC to continue to administer free time during elections on the ABC. Everyone in the chamber agrees that those amendments have not been put before the chamber in a form that can be properly debated.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. Senator Hill indicated that he is moving this contingent notice of motion pursuant to motion No. 17, which appears in the Notice Paper. Notice of motion No. 17 entitles him to move only this:

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent further consideration of the bill, or the stage of the bill, without limitation of time or for a specified time.

My understanding is that he is not so moving; he is moving for reference to a committee and that the Bill not be considered until such time as it has been dealt with by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That is not the same as the particular language which he is authorised to use pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 17. Therefore, he is out of order. Therefore, we should proceed to consideration of the guillotine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill is not entitled to use contingent notice of motion No. 17. A presidential ruling, made only in recent days, states that during the closure a contingent notice of motion can be used once only, and it has already been used. It is not possible to use contingent notice of motion No. 17.
—Mr Chairman, will you direct me to the standing order that so prescribes?
—The Standing Orders of the Senate comprise the Standing Orders and presidential rulings.
—They comprise Standing Orders!

—They comprise presidential rulings as well. Unless presidential rulings are disagreed with, they are in force as standing orders. That ruling was made on Tuesday. It was not dissented from, so it has the—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I would like you to read in full the time, date and body of the ruling, and then I would like you to cite examples of previous rulings being upheld and overruled. I would like you then to cite the standing order which requires you to follow the presidential ruling.
—I will find them for the honourable senator.

—On the point of order: I have not previously entered into the question. Mr Chairman, I believe that, if your ruling is to be persisted with, my rights are being denied under notice of motion No. 23 which is my contingent notice and which is in the same form as the contingent notice of motion of Senator Hill. Is it a fact that you are saying that, because Senator Hill has previously moved his contingent notice of motion, that denies me the opportunity to move pursuant to my contingent notice?
—The way I understand the presidential ruling is that a similar contingent notice of motion cannot be used.

—I will not debate that; of course I am not entitled to do so under the Standing Orders. I recall attempting to move pursuant to my contingent notice of motion at the time the President ruled. I am concerned about that. I am wondering whether at some future time a paper could be delivered to the Senate in respect of that particular matter. It is an entirely separate question and goes to the individual rights of individual senators who are representing, perhaps, a different constituency from the ones that the Leader of the Opposition represents.
—I am intending to proceed.

—In view of the fact that on its face contingent notice of motion No. 17 does not preclude moving in the direction foreshadowed by Senator Hill and in view of the fact that I assume the Democrats are interested in having this matter properly dealt with, I wish to move dissent from that earlier presidential ruling.
—You may dissent from a presidential ruling at the time the ruling is made. If you wish to dissent from a ruling you should dissent from the ruling of the Chair.
—I wish to dissent from your ruling, Mr Chairman, upholding that earlier presidential ruling. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the ruling of the Chairman be dissented from.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that you put your motion of dissent in writing, as required by the Standing Orders. I apprise the Committee of standing order 198. It reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: If an objection is taken to a ruling or decision of the President, such objection must be taken at once and in writing, and a motion moved that the Senate dissent from the President's ruling.
I would rule that `President' includes `Chairman of Committees'. The standing order continues:
Debate on that motion shall be adjourned to the next sitting day, unless the Senate decides on motion, without debate, that the question requires immediate determination.

I have a motion from Senator Alston which reads: `I move dissent to the ruling that Senator Hill not be entitled to use contingent notice of motion No. 17'. Unless the Committee decides on motion, without debate, that the question requires immediate determination—

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the question requires immediate determination and be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We have a motion that the matter requires immediate determination without debate.

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: under standing order 145, once Senator Alston has moved that your ruling be objected to, you must leave the chair, and the Senate resume. Those are the terms of standing order 145. As I understand Senator Alston's motion, it is that your ruling as Chairman be objected to.
—You are correct, but we have to determine whether it requires immediate determination.
—You have to leave the chair.
—You cannot accept the motion. You are not in the chair.
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: we may have to decide that but, with respect, not with you in the chair.
—Order! Just take your seat for a moment.
—You are not in the chair. You must leave the chair once the motion has been put, as Senator Macdonald has pointed out. You may read it but out of the chair.
—Under standing order 145, I shall leave the chair, and the Senate resume.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The President having resumed the chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I made a ruling that contingent notice of motion No. 17 in Senator Hill's name could not be used again, in accordance with the ruling that you made on Tuesday. Senator Alston has moved dissent from my ruling.
—Am I able to move my motion?

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Order! I am trying to get us out of a difficult situation. I will not be helped by continuous points of order until I have time to be apprised of what has happened. I have not been yet.
—My point of order was going to be just that—that this place is in a shambles. As my colleague Senator Calvert has said, if they cannot run the chamber, they cannot run the country either.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Sit down!

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that this is what happens when we try to ban free speech in a country. This is the sort of rabble that comes—
—Order! The honourable senator will resume his seat.
—Order! As I believe it, it is my task to determine whether the ruling that Senator Colston gave was correct.
—No, it is not.
—As it is in accordance with the ruling that I gave last Tuesday, which was not dissented from, I uphold the Chairman's ruling given by Senator Colston.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I understand that you have been placed in a difficult situation.
—Are you on a point of order?
—Yes. Will you just listen to it?
—You don't just jump up. You get the call.
—My point of order is—
—You have not got the call, Gareth.
—Order! I am in the chair. There will be no more interjections from either side.

—Mr President, my point of order is this: the Chairman of Committees made a ruling that we were bound by an earlier ruling of yours and from that ruling today I move dissent. Pursuant to standing order 145, that matter having been laid before you as required, the Senate is now entitled to debate that motion of dissent.
—Order! Senator Alston is completely in order to dissent from my ruling.

PARA.TAB: Government members—No, he is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he is.
—I will do that in due course if it becomes necessary, but I do not believe that it is necessary because standing order 145 clearly covers the very situation that we are in at the moment.
—Spare us from petty sessions lawyers.

—You are not being paid to speak either. Standing order 145 is directly designed to cater for the very position that we are in. Having moved that dissent from the ruling of the Chairman, the matter has been referred to you as required, Mr President, and the Senate is now obliged to address the issue.
—Order! I have sought advice on this and I have ruled on the Chairman's ruling. The only avenue open to you now is to move dissent from my ruling.

—Dissent from the ruling, Mr President, has been moved. Quite clearly you have misread standing order 145. The matter before you, Mr President, is the matter of the dissent against the earlier ruling of the Chairman, and you are simply in the chair to resolve that matter. You cannot now substitute yourself and say you can move to standing order 198.
—That is the very point I made, that I have resolved that matter.
—You can't.
—Well, I have.

—Mr President, you do not have jurisdiction to do that. Standing order 145 is specifically designed to resolve such an impasse, not by you acting as a court of appeal but by the Senate itself resolving the matter. It is quite clear that there is a set of procedures to be followed. Dissent is moved from the ruling of the Chairman; the Chairman then leaves the chair and the Senate resumes. Now we have reached that point.

PARA.TAB: The matter having been laid before you, as it has, the Senate should now proceed to address the issue. That is the stage we are at, and we are inviting you to simply follow the letter of standing order 145. If you ultimately decide not to do that, then we will move dissent from your current ruling. But we invite you to say that it is not necessary to have reached that stage as yet, and that all you need to do is apply 145 as spelt out.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President; the case put by Senator Alston prima facie is right. There are two different sections of the Standing Orders: 145 which deals with the committee as a whole and 198 which deals with presidential rulings. My reading of 145 infers that we do not want these matters determined in committee; we want them determined in the chamber as a whole. Therefore, I think there is a weakness in Standing Orders that allows it virtually to be put without debate when it is a presidential ruling but not with a deputy president's ruling.

PARA.TAB: It is on those two things, Mr President, that I think we are getting confused. I believe we are also facing—and I hope we are not facing—a campaign just to simply disrupt for disruption's sake.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we are not, because long term the other issue here, which is relevant to Senator Hill, is how many contingent notices of motion in a row can be moved because, if there is no limit on them, it is possible never to do any business in the Senate. But that is another issue to follow through. I think that is what prompted the President's original ruling of Tuesday the previous week.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I put it to you that, given the nature of standing order 145, it is necessary to follow the procedures laid down there.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. Read it. Senators have to address themselves to it.
—It is funny, Senator Baume, but I do not need your help by your agreeing with me. It would not do my preselection any good at all.

PARA.TAB: So, Mr President, whilst I am not dissenting, like Senator Hill, from your ruling, I am asking you to consider the difference between 145 and 198. The only difference really is in the long run that senators may address the matter if a gag is not moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may address you on a point of order, Mr President, to try to resolve this difficulty we have got ourselves into. As I understand it, 145 deals with dissent motions that arise in the course of committee hearings and 145 is the only standing order dealing with dissent motions that arise in those circumstances. Therefore—
—Don't you agree with Senator Ray?

—I am agreeing with Senator Ray up to a point. But the end result is the same, and it is in support of the Chairman's ruling. In order to get the dissent motion resolved when it arises in committee, it has to be referred by the Chairman to the President.
—Well done!
—Brilliant!
—Order! Honourable senators know that clapping is disorderly.
—To that extent 145 is then expended, but then the Senate itself has to deal with the particular dissent motion. It has to deal with it in accordance with 198. The only way—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Resume your seat.
—Resume your seat.

—The only way that the matter can be taken forward in the context of the Senate as a whole, having been referred to the Senate as a whole by the Chairman, is in the context of 198. I am advised that the situation has often arisen in the 91 years that this relatively useless institution has been sitting. On the innumerable previous occasions—
—Point of order! Point of order!
—Order! Resume your seat, Senator Vanstone.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —On the innumerable previous occasions when this matter has arisen in this way, when a dissent motion has arisen in committee and has gone to the Senate as a whole under the provisions of 145, the way the matter has been dealt with is for the President of the day to make his own determination as to the particular matter, which is the nature of the advice the President was given on this occasion. That is the basis

INTERJECT.PARA: on which the matter is now being disposed of in terms of 145. We are having the matter disposed of under 145 by a procedure which has now been adopted by the President, which is correct. The next most appropriate thing to happen is for Senator McMullan to move his motion that the matter be immediately dealt with. Mr President, I ask that you rule accordingly in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not wish to put too much pressure on the advice that I have taken from the Clerk. However, what Senator Evans has just said is the advice that I have been given repeatedly. That is—
—Well, it is wrong. On a proper reading, it is wrong.

—There will be an opportunity for that. That is that I have to determine whether the Chairman's ruling is correct or not, and I have in accordance with standing order 145. If you wish, you can then move dissent from my ruling.

—Mr President, on a point of order, can I ask you a question? If your interpretation is correct, when then do honourable senators have the opportunity to address themselves to the issue under standing order 145?
—Order! You get that opportunity when you move dissent from my ruling.
—Mr President, if you are telling me that I move dissent from your ruling under 198—and there is another debate that might have to come—arguably we do not have a right to question that.
—Yes, you do, because I have made a ruling that the Chairman's ruling was correct.
—Mr President, may I inquire whether your ruling is meant to constitute a disposal of the matter pursuant to 145.
—It is a determination of the matter, unless the Senate dissents from my ruling.
—I am not asking that, Mr President. I am asking whether, in considering the terms of standing order 145—and we all agree, I think, that the matter has been laid before the President—
—The first step in discussing it is for the President to give a ruling.
—That is precisely what I disagree with.
—Okay, well move dissent.

—No. Just a moment. I do not want to get to that stage unless we have to. We only go to the court of appeal if we cannot get the court, in the first instance, to get it right. Mr President, I am seeking from you an elucidation of what is meant by the third sentence in standing order 145. We are agreed that the matter has been laid before you and we seem to be having it put from the other side of the chamber that you have proceeded to dispose of that matter.
—Bringing it within the scope of 198 will stuff it.

—You can do that later, mate. Mr President, I am asking you to consider the third sentence in standing order 145. It seems to me that we have dealt with stages 1 and 3, but we have skipped over stage 2. These are sequential requirements. The matter having been laid before you, the next step, which cannot be avoided by argumentation, is that the Senate must address it and then it has to be disposed of—and, I would argue, not by you but by the Senate itself, by resolution.
—Mr President, on the point of order—
—I am about to answer Senator Alston.
—I want to address that point of order, Mr President, because there is another link in the chain which has not been addressed.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order—
—Order! Senator Bishop was on her feet first.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go back to the precise ruling of standing order 145 and the steps that should be taken. We have dissented from the Chairman's ruling. The standing order then says `the Senate must resume'—that is in order for the dissent to be placed before you. If the Senate did not resume, there would not be a capacity to place it before you. Once it has been placed before you, in the words of the standing order:

INTERJECT.PARA: The matter having been laid before the President—
that is, the Senate first having resumed—
and Senators having addressed themselves to it . . .

We must be given that opportunity, that means of debate. After we have addressed the matter, it may be disposed of. Mr President, if we followed the course that you have suggested—I presume on the advice of the Clerk and the gaggle over here—then we would have the position where you could circumvent the right of senators to debate the matter, because under standing order 198 you virtually impose your own guillotine.

PARA.TAB: If we say that we are objecting to your ruling—which we are not because we are not entitled to get to that stage before we debate the issue—then you are circumventing the proper orders of this Senate. I simply put to you that the steps are: first, we dissent from the Chairman, and that has occurred; second, the Senate resumes—you take the chair back; third, we lay the dissent before you; and, fourth, we now must address it. That is where we are. You do not have the right at this stage to determine or dispose of the matter. We are entitled to debate it. I would ask you, Mr President, to follow standing order 145, which is exactly what I put to you was the case that Senator Robert Ray sensibly outlined before Senator Evans got into the act and tried to remember he was a lawyer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will speak to these various points of order and try to add something new, unlike the last contribution. I will make a suggestion as to how we might proceed today to resolve this problem without further undue delay. As I read the Standing Orders, it seems to me that the plain meaning of the words is consistent with that which Senator Ray, Senator Alston and others have read. It is, however, my advice that the whole body of rulings over the last 90 years is to the contrary. So we do have a dilemma.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that on this one occasion—notwithstanding the precedent—we should proceed to allow the literal interpretation of standing order 145 to apply and the debate to proceed, for as long as the Standing Orders provide, on the motion that Senator Alston has moved, and that the question of the proper interpretation of it and the conflict between the rulings and the apparent wording be referred to the Procedure Committee subsequently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—We don't need you, Boy Wonder.
—You stay out of it. You are gagging again!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I refer honourable senators to page 677 of Odgers Australian Senate Practice, which states:

PARA.TAB: After hearing the views of Senators, the President must give his decision. Unless objection is taken to that decision, it is binding, and the Committee resumes its work. But if objection is taken to the decision of the President, the debate upon his ruling is automatically adjourned till the next day of sitting, unless the Senate decides that the matter is one requiring immediate determination. In the meantime, the ruling of the President has to be accepted.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have determined that the Chairman's ruling was correct and you would have to move dissent from my ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Ha, ha!
—Order!
—There was no discussion.
—Order! If Senator McMullan then wants to move along the lines that he has suggested, he can.

—I invite Senator McMullan to move in that direction because I think there is general agreement, apart from Senator Evans's notable dissent, on both sides of the chamber that that is the appropriate course to follow. Having regard to the fact that Standing Orders have been rewritten fairly recently, one would have to say that overrides the body of accumulated wisdom to which Senator McMullan referred. We should therefore proceed on the literal interpretation that I think both sides regard as fair and reasonable. I therefore invite Senator McMullan to move accordingly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not proposing to put a motion. I do not understand why Senator Alston believes that it requires a motion from me. I was advising what I thought was an appropriate course of action for Senator Alston to take. If he feels it is required, I will move that the Senate consider the Chairman's ruling, that is, in accordance with standing order 145. That is all the motion requires.
—I thought that you were also going to refer it to the Procedure Committee.
—I was going to do that subsequently.
—Move that the President's ruling be upheld.
—No, wait a minute. I assure the Senate that I will refer the matter to the Procedure Committee, without the need for a resolution of the Senate. I will do that by letter to you, Mr President.
—Does Senator McMullan have leave to move that motion?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That the matter of the President's ruling be determined by consideration of the question: That the Senate dissent from the ruling of the Chairman of Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As a result of that motion being carried, we are now dealing with dissent from the Chairman's ruling.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I confirm, therefore, that what is before the Senate is Senator Alston's motion that the Chairman's ruling be—
—In effect.
—Not in effect—actually. Can I confirm that it is Senator Alston's motion that is before us?
—Yes.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Order! Senator Alston, you are not in the Chair—even though, at the moment, I might wish that you were. However, the motion has been moved and I put the question, as moved by Senator McMullan.
—What is it?
—That the question be put.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Chairman's ruling be dissented from.
—I think the Minister might have required the gag for the previous motion, but I don't think he has moved one for this yet. Why don't we get to debate this?
—Order! It has to be put immediately.
—Then I move the suspension of standing orders.
—Order!
—But he hasn't moved the gag on this one.
—Order! Resume your seat. There is no other procedure.
—What is your ruling?
—Resume your seat, Senator Harradine.
—I will, but tell me what your ruling is.
—I have no other option—no matter how much I would like to reply to you—but to now put the question that the Chairman's ruling be dissented from. Those of that opinion say aye.
—What is the ruling?
—I have a point of order, Mr President.
—There is no point of order. You cannot have a point of order. It is quite clear. Those of that opinion say aye, the contrary no, the noes have it.

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT—The question is that the Chairman's ruling be dissented from.
Senator Harradine—Mr President, the question is that the Chairman's ruling be upheld. Could I ask you, please, to repeat your ruling because it is of great importance to the rights of other senators.
The PRESIDENT—I have not got the words in front of me, but the ruling is that the contingent notice of motion, which I believe was moved by Senator Hill, can only be moved once.
Senator Harradine—By Senator Hill?
The PRESIDENT—It can only be used once by anyone.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Colston to take the Chair for the Committee.
—On a point of order, Mr President. Mr President!

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee—On a point of order, Mr Chairman—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would honourable senators please resume their seats or leave the chamber as is their wont. I am still waiting for honourable senators to take their seats.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: whilst the President was in the chair, Senator Evans described the Senate as a useless institution. That is quite clearly an improper reflection upon the Senate. It has long been the custom of this chamber that such remarks are unparliamentary and I would request you to call upon Senator Evans to withdraw his remark.
Senator Robert Ray—The defence rests.
Senator Lewis—A point of order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. If you wanted to raise that matter, you should have raised it at the time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lewis—Mr Chairman—
Senator Michael Baume—He tried. He did not get the call. He deliberately was not given the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume! I call Senator Lewis.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook—That is a dreadful thing to say.

Senator Lewis—Mr Chairman, I seek leave of the Senate to move, at a subsequent stage during the Committee debate, dissent from your ruling which denied Senator Harradine's right to use contingent notice of motion No. 23. I have written that out. I do not suggest that we debate it now, but I seek leave of the Senate to move it at a later stage.

Senator Michael Baume—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. You called attention to my name as if reprimanding me. I had said, and I repeat it: the President chose not to call Senator O'Chee deliberately. He was on his feet and your remark was therefore totally inappropriate. That is why I drew your attention to that fact.

The whole chamber saw Senator O'Chee on his feet and remarks were made by Labor members, including the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that he should put eight books on his head to get attention. I do not know what we have to do to get the call in this place on this sort of matter, but what is happening is totally unsatisfactory. It is a disgrace. The behaviour of the Government in this place is appalling. That kind of chairmanship is not acceptable to me and, I am certain, not acceptable to the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague—Mr Chairman—

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill has now expired—

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague—Mr Chairman—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the remaining amendments circulated by the Government be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague—Mr Chairman—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I intend to do what the Senate and the Committee require me to do and that is to put the questions that are before us.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague—Mr Chairman—

TALK.START.PARA: —If we have spurious points of order, I will deal with the senators concerned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—Oh, how do you know that?
Senator Michael Baume—There is a senator—an Acting Deputy President—seeking the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator Michael Baume—That is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Senator Teague tried to get the call. He didn't get a chance.
Senator Collins—Oh, come on!
Senator Michael Baume—He deliberately was not given the call. You saw him standing. Are you deliberately not calling him?
Senator MacGibbon—Are you blind?
Senator Michael Baume—It is a disgrace that you deliberately did not call him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—You are deliberately not calling the senator. This is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I invite you to withdraw that remark.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—No, I will not. It happens to be absolutely true.
Senator Michael Baume—It is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume, I do not care what you call me, but I do care what you call the Chair. I would ask you to withdraw. There are opportunities to put your point of view without making remarks like that about the Chair. I invite you to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Mr Chairman, if Senator Teague had been permitted to give his point of view this matter would not have arisen. Senator Teague sought to get the call. You are aware of that.
Government senators—Withdraw!
Senator Michael Baume—I would be happy to withdraw if you would call Senator Teague. If you refuse to call Senator Teague, I must stand by my position.
Opposition senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp—What about what Senator Evans said?
Senator Bishop—A point of view cannot be put if the senator is not recognised. What about the remarks from Senator Evans?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I am dealing with the remark made by Senator Baume. I have asked Senator Baume to withdraw the remark that he made about the Chair. I am asking him once again. I am not going to have any other business transpire before that is determined.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Mr Chairman, I am only too happy to withdraw that remark if you will call Senator Teague because you will then disprove my point. Until you call him, you are confirming the accuracy of my statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Circulated Government Amendments—

PARA.TAB: The following amendments having been circulated by the Government:
Clause 6, page 9, before proposed section 95E, insert the following heading:

INTERJECT.PARA: "'Division 4—Policy launches".

PARA.TAB: Clause 6, page 9, proposed paragraph 95E(1)(c), line 38, omit "political", substitute "policy".
Clause 6, page 9, proposed subsection 95E(1), line 40, omit "political", substitute "policy".
Clause 6, page 10, proposed paragraph 95E(2)(c), line 8, omit "political", substitute "policy".

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991 is indicative of the Government's failure to deliver a climate conducive to restructuring and long-term growth of the industry, in particular because it:

PARA.TAB: (a)fails to address the excessive tax burden on the industry;
(b)ignores the urgent need for industrial relations reform to promote genuine enterprise bargaining; and

(c)fails to deliver the generational changes in policies, attitudes and leadership which are needed to make Australian industry internationally competitive, as proposed in the Coalition's FIGHTBACK! program.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent Industry Commission annual report outlined the true impact of protection of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. The cost to consumers in terms of higher prices paid for clothing and footwear totalled some $2 billion in 1990-91. This amounts to an average of over $300 per household, with the taxing effect of the assistance being regressive across those households.

PARA.TAB: In other words, what I am saying is that the degree of protection given by way of tariffs to clothing and footwear amounts to a tax upon ordinary, struggling Australian families who are suffering under this Government's imposed recession. The continuing high levels of assistance to some textile, clothing and footwear industries mean that there is an effective rate of 176 per cent on clothing and footwear and that textiles attract a rate of 68 per cent. These rates are really out of step with the rest of the manufacturing industry sectors. The average effective rate of assistance for manufacturing is estimated at about 15 per cent for 1990-91.

By the end of the implementation of the Government's announced changes of the 12 March 1991 statement in 1996, the effective rate of assistance across manufacturing industries should have fallen to about 5 per cent. Looking at particular areas within the TCF industries, the precise extent of assistance becomes apparent. In 1990-91, for instance, the effective rates of assistance were 166 per cent for man-made fibre woven fabrics, 152 per cent for textile finishing, 139 per cent for household textiles, 142 per cent for textile floor coverings, 135 per cent for hosiery, 237 per cent for cardigans and pullovers, 201 per cent for men's trousers, 140 per cent for men's suits, 187 per cent for women's outwear, 187 per cent for foundation garments, and a massive 238 per cent for underwear and infants' clothing. In other words, there is imposed upon what the Government often refers to as the basic essentials of life a tax, by way of tariffs, of huge propositions.

It is important to realise that protection to manufacturing industries, whether it be in tariffs or other forms, not only increases the price of imported goods but also leads to an increase in the price of domestically produced goods. The broad measure of the additional amounts consumers pay as a result of assistance to domestic manufacturing industries is known as the consumer tax equivalent. It stood at $7.1 billion in 1990-91 across all manufacturing industries, of which $287m applied to textiles and over $2 billion applied solely to clothing and footwear.

A further problem which arises, particularly in the TCF industries, is associated with the disparities in the levels of assistance between and within industries. The larger the disparities in nominal and effective assistance levels, the greater the potential for resources to be used in activities which fail to maximise economic welfare. The Industry Commission uses the standard deviation as a measure of those disparities, such that the higher the standard deviation the larger the variation in rates of assistance.

The standard deviation for effective rates of assistance within the textiles industry was 57 percentage points in 1990-91, while it was 60 percentage points for the clothing and footwear industries. That gets put into perspective when one contrasts it with the standard deviation of 29 percentage points across the whole of manufacturing. By 1996, at the present rate under the present scheme, with the completion of the 1991 program, the TCF industries will have standard deviations for effective rates of assistance of more than double the next highest sector in manufacturing.

The bottom line is that the textiles, clothing and footwear plan that the Government has been so proud of and in which it has expressed its pride from time to time is in fact a plan that effectively works a tax on ordinary Australian families so that they can buy clothing and footwear at a price which is cheaper than that they are forced to pay now. But it is interesting that, despite the heaviest levels of protection for any of the manufacturing industries which TCF attracts, it has been on a downturn. If one drew a graph, it would show a continuing downturn. This, of course, reflects the recession but it is the continuance of a trend which shows that the industry, despite its protection, is not benefiting or lifting itself. Textiles, clothing and footwear have been on a downturn over a period of time: profits are down, production is down and employment is down. Historically, this has been the continuing pattern, but the most recent figures are really quite alarming.

Between November 1978 and November 1985, TCF employment fell by 16,000 people. That is, in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, 16,000 people lost their jobs. That is about 13 per cent of the work force. This is in spite of the fact that the effective assistance during the period was around 70 per cent for textiles, 170 per cent for clothing and almost 200 per cent for footwear. To try to describe the TCF industry as being the sunrise industry and in need of help so that it can get on its feet—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senators are not supposed to read their speeches.

—On the point of order: because I am dealing with complicated figures—and I know the Minister is always interested to get those figures on the record in an accurate form—and as I have noticed that the Minister is himself incapable of carrying complicated figures around with any degree of accuracy, I would put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I am simply using copious notes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you are reading from.
—I will tell the Minister what I am reading from: I am reading from my copious notes.
—No, you are not.

—Indeed, I am. I have just set out in some detail, for the Minister's elucidation as much as anybody else's, the enormous levels of protection. I have noticed over time that he does not seem to have a great deal of contact with his Department. I have noticed that, when officers from his Department have attended before us in Estimates hearings and he has tried to answer questions without their assistance, we have had a great wall of silence because he simply does not have the information. Perhaps, as well as listening to his departmental people—which I recommend to him—he will also listen attentively today because he might learn something.

PARA.TAB: Let me get back to the state of the industry, the one which during the period Senator Button has presided over it has gone into decline. The Minister may or may not take that as a personal vote on his ability, as he sees fit; or, perhaps more particularly, the Australian people will. Indeed, while I am about it, maybe that is the reason why his colleagues are trying to get him to stand down—so that they can bring back Mr Keating. Maybe they are right.

I go back to the state of the industry, the one that the Minister has been presiding over during its downfall. In the time that I was dealing with—that is, 1978 to 1985, just so the Minister can remember those dates—employment in the TCF industry dropped by 16,000 people. TCF has been hit even harder by this recession—that is, the one organised by the Minister and his colleagues. Senator Button was one of the organisers of this recession. Now that we have the recession, the figures for the last three months have fallen by a further 10 per cent, or another 13,000 people.

But I do not suppose that the Minister would worry about that. After all, he kept telling us the other day in Question Time what a great job the members of the Government were all doing and how brilliant they all were. The Minister criticised our plan of action, which is designed to put two million jobs back into the workplace. All he could do was stand there and say, `At page such and such of your report' and then misread it. As I said in answering, it is a great shame that the Minister, in his ageing process, is losing not only his ability to read but also his ability to reason.

One reason for the terrible impact of the recession on the TCF industries is the inward looking nature of them. Despite the recent increase in exports amongst manufacturing industries generally, the export-import ratio for TCF remains at 10 per cent. This means that the industries have been virtually unable to cope with domestic economic fluctuations during this period. We can see a very good example of this in Victoria, the Minister's State. The capital is `Bleak City', Melbourne. Another Labor Government put that State virtually into liquidation. If it were possible to put a State into receivership, my gosh, a receiver would have been appointed in Victoria.

Let us look at Victoria. In the leisure wear industry, Sportscraft—a most efficient Australian company—announced the closure of its Bendigo factory last week. In 1989, the Bendigo operation employed more than 200 staff. Last week, it announced the lay-off of its last 34 workers and its intention to try to sell that factory. The view of the workers and the works manager at the Bendigo plant was that many of those who had been laid off would find it very difficult to get another job. That is just part of the continuing story of the bleak hope for the State of Victoria as a whole, which has been compounded by the Government putting a recession in place, as well.

As I said, the production of the TCF industry is in decline. According to the ABS industrial index, clothing and footwear production slumped by 23 per cent in 1989-90, compared with the manufacturing industry's average increase of 3 per cent. Even in the boom times of 1987 and 1988, clothing and footwear production was third of the manufacturing average of 6 per cent.

Against that background, we have introduced the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991, to which I have formally moved an amendment. It is such a good amendment that I think I ought to read it again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991 is indicative of the Government's failure to deliver a climate conducive to restructuring and long-term growth of the industry, in particular because it:

PARA.TAB: (a)fails to address the excessive tax burden on the industry;
(b)ignores the urgent need for industrial relations reform to promote genuine enterprise bargaining; and

(c)fails to deliver the generational changes in policies, attitudes and leadership which are needed to make Australian industry internationally competitive, as proposed in the Coalition's FIGHTBACK! program.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, we are asking—as we have on many occasions since we have introduced the Fightback package—where is the Government's plan? Everybody in Australia knows that this country is in a serious plight; everybody knows that we need leadership to get out of the mire which we are presently in.

PARA.TAB: The way that the Government conducts the business of government, through the Parliament and the nation, remains constant—it is in as great a shambles as was this chamber earlier today. The Government applied the gag to stop freedom of speech in this chamber; it applied the gag to advertising on television and forced shareholders of the television stations to bear the cost—$18m of property expropriated without just terms; it is getting rid of the right of ordinary Australians to speak out and criticise and let people know the true facts of what the Government has done to this nation. The really sad part is that the Australian Democrats have acquiesced in what the Government has done because they get an advantage out of it—$1.8m worth of advantage. They shut out any other potential political party from getting a slice of the action.

What a shoddy performance we have seen in this place today. The Presiding Officer and the Chairman sat there not acknowledging the right of individual senators to speak; applying the gag to end a debate by trickery. We have seen every trick in the book today. The Australian people are beginning to see what the Government is like because it has pulled dirty, mean tricks on the Australian people, too. There are one million unemployed, with some of them having no hope of finding a job—such as the people sacked in Bendigo.

The Opposition will not vote against this Bill, but we seek to amend it. As a strong matter of principle, it is the Opposition's policies in the TCF area which will give people who are employed in the industry some chance. That is why I strongly urge even the Democrats to support our motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991 contains amendments resulting from the changes in assistance announced in the 12 March industry statement of this year. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill without amendment.

PARA.TAB: The Bill amends the Act which established the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which has a brief to alleviate restructuring problems likely to occur whilst making TCF industries more competitive. The Bill repeals provisions relating to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority—or TCFDA—raw materials processing and plant and equipment modernisation programs and repeals the requirement that the TCFDA review and report to the Minister by 30 June 1992 on the operation and effectiveness of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan.

The Bill will set in motion two programs which will be, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) announced, stronger and more flexible than the original programs and which will help potentially competitive firms survive the pressure of protection cuts. These programs are: the new incentives for international competitiveness program, which provides assistance to specific companies, and the infrastructure support program. The Government is providing an increase of $15m per annum for support to these programs.

In the 12 March industry statement, Building a Competitive Australia, the Government announced that it would revise four main programs: the two that I have previously mentioned, plus the import credits program and the capitalisation grants program. Although all four of these programs will be administered by the TCFDA, the capitalisation grants program and the import credits scheme will be managed in cooperation with the Australian Customs Service.

The TCF Development Authority reported in 1990 that these industries, despite adjustments being made, still remain some of the most highly protected industries in Australia; indeed, up to 12 times higher than those applying to industry in general, and that more adjustments are required if TCF industries are to become internationally competitive.

The Government has announced that reductions in protection for TCF industries will be accelerated; tariffs will be phased down to a maximum of 25 per cent by the year 2000; quotas will be terminated by March 1993; and bounties will be abolished by June 1995. Therefore, these two programs have far-reaching implications for a very large sector of the Australian work force—those thousands of people employed in the textile, clothing and footwear industry whose livelihoods depend on their company's economic survival in the light of the reduction in the protection that they have formerly enjoyed. The Australian Democrats have already made it plain that we support the provision of tariffs and bounties to Australian business so that it can compete with international companies that enjoy a number of generous subsidies and other economic advantages.

A vibrant manufacturing sector able to compete internationally is vital to the economic health of the nation. Nevertheless, the economic rationalists inform us that the tariff reduction program is having its desired effect and that inefficient Australian manufacturers are being subjected to market forces. Tell that to the many thousands of people who are losing their jobs in this area. However, the concept of a level playing field, on which these tariff reductions appear to be based, is not a panacea for Australia's economic woes. There are numerous countries that provide enormous protection to their own industries—the United States being a case in point.

The Metal Trades Industry Association has consistently questioned the need for Australia to adopt this kind of flat earth restructuring program with such haste. Mr M.A. Besley, AM, National President of the MTIA, in a recent speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: What an increasing number of Australians are beginning to question is why this country should pursue a policy which gives a high unilateral trade concession to manufacturers overseas.

This Government is seeking to establish a level playing field of Australian industry in an international climate which is not fair and is riddled with protectionism, tariffs and quotas, as other countries seek to defend their jobs and industries.

PARA.TAB: However, the manufacturing sector complains that the Government's industry restructuring policies have happened too quickly, without a reciprocal speed up in the micro-economic reform process. Despite gains, there are still massive inefficiencies on the waterfront, in transport, and in the overlap of Commonwealth, State and local government regulations, which must be dealt with to help increase the competitive nature of Australian industry.

The Australian Democrats fully recognise the need to invest in new plant and equipment, value add our primary products and engage in wide-ranging micro-economic reform to assist industry. However, the Government's commitment to lowering protection levels throughout manufacturing and acceleration of reductions to protection may confer more problems than it solves at this point.

It is obvious that TCF companies desperately need to be more competitive internationally. The new incentives for the international competitiveness program will extend assistance for capital re-equipment and rationalisation projects, investment in manufacturing systems and raw materials processing projects by broadening the eligibility criteria so that more firms can benefit.

I note that applicants will be required to submit their business objectives in relation to production of TCF products in Australia, their plans for achieving those objectives in terms of certain matters, including organisational restructuring, investment, export development, raw materials processing and other matters, plus information regarding their international competitiveness at the time when government assistance ceases. This will help ensure that, where government assistance is to be given, companies will have a clear vision of what they seek to achieve and how to get there.

The TCF industries themselves must make a commitment to improve their efficiency and reduce dependence on government support. It is only right that support provided under the industries development strategy will be conditional upon TCF industries making a commitment, both financially and by addressing those problems which have inhibited their competitiveness or restrained development. Changes in attitude within the TCF industries will be essential to ensuring the success of the new plan.

I draw honourable senators' attention to the recent closure of the Rocklea spinning mills at Kotara near Newcastle. When the Authority was established in 1988 the Minister advised that `where employment reductions are involved, support will be conditional upon recipients adopting a responsible labour management plan and minimising involuntary employment reductions'. Despite this clear direction, 327 workers lost their jobs in an area already suffering from a severely depressed job market without any of the required consultation.

Senator Button criticised Rocklea for this omission but it was far too late. So much for the highly touted labour management plan. The deed had been done and the workers became instant unemployment statistics. To compound this appalling episode, Rocklea received a bounty of $15.9m which it promptly allocated to its Bendigo plant. This is an example of the Government's failure to check the conditions under which its grants will be spent. Taxpayers' money must have strings and accountability attaching to its use. The Government has said that it will ensure that appropriate consultative measures will be put in place to ensure that the Rocklea fiasco will not happen again, but that is a bit late for those workers who will lose their jobs. The Australian Democrats would still like to see, however, an overhaul of the guidelines for administration of the bounty system.

TCF industries are still geared only to the Australian market. Apart from scoured wool and wool tops, they export less than 5 per cent of sales. The TCFDA advises that restructuring has begun in some sectors but that the restructuring needed to become internationally competitive was being inhibited by continued high protection. In other words, if we remove the protection, companies will be forced to become internationally competitive to survive. Some will survive, but how many will go to the wall? Why is Australia, almost alone, pursuing a policy which gives a huge unilateral trade concession to manufacturers overseas?

Australians must look at their own business environment. This headlong charge towards tariff reform must be countered by the implementation of macro-economic and micro-economic reform. We are burdened by entrenched inefficiencies and infrastructure and the high value of the Australian dollar. These problems must be seriously addressed if Australia is to regain a sound economic footing. The Australian Democrats commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition accepts the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill because it is an indication that the Labor Government is heading, albeit too slowly, in the right direction in dismantling protectionism in the textile, clothing and footwear industries.
