However, as we have come to expect from this Government, it has failed to provide the full range of supporting structural reforms in industrial relations, taxation, transport and the public sector that will allow the textile, clothing and footwear industries to remain viable in a more competitive environment. Instead, the failings of the industry and its precarious position at present are in large measure due to the Labor Government's failure to tackle full scale reform of the structure of our economy—the so-called micro-economic reform—right across the board. This failure has contributed greatly to the devastating billion dollar plus current account deficits Australia is racking up month on month. We heard a couple of days ago that the figure for the October current account deficit is a disastrous $1.3 billion.

PARA.TAB: The textile, clothing and footwear industries in Australia have existed since Federation on a foundation of protection of one form or another. These have consisted of bounties, tariffs and quotas which have effectively shielded the industry from international competition. Internally, this artificial protection resulted in the 1980s in a concentration of productive and financial resources through mergers and acquisitions. The adage `big is beautiful' became the byword, as it did elsewhere in the Australian business world. This was in stark contrast to the developments in the leading textile industry countries of Germany, Italy and Japan where industry integration in large scale firms has been largely dismantled.

Concentration has been removed from the textile industry in these countries and has been replaced with a large number of smaller specialised firms. This has allowed much greater flexibility to enable firms to concentrate on niche markets in the fast changing fashion world. This sort of flexibility is impossible in large companies. The Prato region in Italy is a case in point. Woollen fabric has been made in the Prato area for some 600 years. In 1975 there were 750 firms there, but by 1985 there were 14,000 firms employing some 60,000 people. Firms have become smaller but more numerous under a public policy strategy that provides a framework and environment for them to develop and to make their decisions. There are no cash hand-outs. Instead, there is infrastructure support and group services for marketing and exchange of information on products and technologies which have resulted in a high quality, high value added product and high wages.

By comparison, the Australian textile industry during the 1980s under the Labor Government's textile, clothing and footwear plan received contradictory signals. There was nothing for small firms; everything was large scale, without strategy and with no framework of support. The only support was overwhelmingly protectionist with cash hand-outs—this is all that bounties are—$30m of which went to only three firms. However, in 1988 the Labor Government announced the textile, clothing and footwear assistance reduction plan and allocated $120m until 1995 to assist firms to restructure. This assistance is aimed at cutting out quotas by 1993, bounties by 1995 and reducing tariffs to 25 per cent by the year 2000.

So far, the annual Budget allocations have been consistently underspent. For example, in 1990-91, of a total allocation of $9.9m, only $4.9m was spent and no projects were funded under the raw materials processing program. So much for the concept of developing value added to Australia's primary industries—in this case, the wool industry. No projects at all were funded under the raw materials processing program.

While the Opposition will accept this legislation, the Liberal and National parties are totally committed to accelerating reductions in protectionism, with the aim of achieving negligible levels by the year 2000. This is in line with our overall policy for all manufacturing industry in Australia, including the motor vehicle industry.

However, the major difference between the Liberal and Nationals parties' Fightback policy and the bumblings of the current Labor Government is that we do not see the reduction of protectionism in isolation. Rather, it is just part of a total integrated package of reform as announced in our Fightback program. Because of its long history of protectionism, these industries have become uncompetitive and are in a very parlous state. The industry will not survive with or without assistance unless there are some major modifications made across the board.

Profits, production and employment have declined markedly in recent years in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, despite effective levels of assistance of around 70 per cent for textile manufacturing, 170 per cent for clothing and almost 200 per cent for footwear. So when we hear Senator Sowada talk about the impact of reduced protection on employment, as she did on behalf of the Democrats a few moments ago, let us remember that reduced protection has had nothing to do with reductions in employment in this industry. For a long time now, because of their inefficiencies, these industries have been unable to maintain their employment levels in spite of these excessively high levels of protection. For example, in just three months last year employment fell by some 13,000—about 10 per cent. As I have said, so much for the flawed argument that protection saves jobs.

The textiles, clothing and footwear industries have fared badly compared with other Australian manufacturing industries, despite these much higher levels of protection. For example, clothing and footwear production slumped by a massive 23 per cent in 1989-90, while manufacturing industry overall averaged a modest 3 per cent increase. It is obvious that high protection has not solved the industry's problems; rather, it has exacerbated them.

We must not forget that assistance to one industry has to be paid for by someone else. There is no such thing as a free lunch. Again, I ask Senator Sowada to remember that: wherever protection continues in this country, someone else in this country is paying for it. In the main, it is our efficient export industries—those industries that we want to encourage, that we want to see grow and develop because they earn the very necessary overseas exchange—that are penalised when protection continues for these other industries. That is now at long last recognised on both major sides of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is our largest export sector at the moment?
—Our largest export sector?
—Yes.
—I would expect it to be the mining sector.
—Which are the largest export industries?

—The largest export industries in general would be the mining industries, the rural industries and tourism, in terms of earning export dollars. As I said, both sides of politics now recognise that protectionism is not the way to go—and, fortunately, that is also recognised among most industries. It is time that the Democrats came to recognise that.

PARA.TAB: The Government itself, of course, is moving in that direction, however slowly. Even the Metal Trades Industry Association has now accepted that tariff protection must go. As I have already said, there is not much point in removing tariffs if one is not going to remove all of the other impediments to making industry competitive. Fortunately, Senator Sowada did make some comments with regard to needs in that area.

Firstly, let us look at the tax system, which is one of the major impositions on manufacturing industry and business in general. Business is subject to a whole range of taxes: wholesale sales taxes of $9.4 billion, payroll tax of $5.8 billion, fuel excise of $6.6 billion, customs duties of $3.3 billion and the training guarantee levy. The next Liberal-National government, which now is not far away, will abolish all of these and reduce the tax on exports by $1.7 billion. The capital gains tax will be revised and lowered and the present depreciation allowance arrangements will be reviewed. Our overall reform package will drastically reduce business costs, some by as much as 50 per cent.

But the key to economic recovery in this country is reform of the industrial relations system and the introduction of genuine enterprise bargaining. Only by giving employers and employees a choice and the ability to be flexible in their work arrangements can we ensure real increases in productivity. The Liberal-National policies for industrial reform have been well documented, so I will not dwell on them here today, other than to say that they are based on the fundamentals of enterprise bargaining, voluntary agreements and voluntary unionism. Workplace reform will not only benefit the textiles, clothing and footwear industries directly, but also make huge improvements in the efficiency and the costs of road and rail transport and the waterfront, which will have a direct contributory effect on industry's international competitiveness.

For too long this country has been too complacent, too content to be the lucky country, without realising that the rest of the world was leaving us behind. Hiding behind our tariff walls, we did not notice that our manufacturing industries had become inefficient, uncompetitive and outdated, while we continued to pay ourselves higher and higher wages for less and less production, living farther and farther beyond our means. From being one of the wealthiest nations in the early years of this century, we have declined now and are in just fifteenth place among the industrialised countries of the world.

The Labor Government has begun to get a glimmer of this. Indeed, it could hardly miss the signs with an unemployment rate of more than 10 per cent, but it has not had the guts or stamina to stand up to its union consorts and do something about the situation. Instead, it has made token gestures which have succeeded only in tinkering around the edges of what really ails us. In marked contrast, the Liberal and National parties offer insight for the future—a program for leadership that will face up to the hard issues and make the necessary decisions to tackle our underlying problems.

Our Fightback package will restore incentive, increase national production and build a dynamic economy. It is built on a foundation of individual determination, self-sufficiency, equality of opportunity and freedom of choice. This applies equally to companies as to individuals. This is why the outmoded and unfair philosophy of protection for the favoured few must be dismantled as quickly as possible. It is nothing more than a welfare mentality for business, which in the end destroys incentive and puts an additional impost on others to pay. The coalition is committed to achieving these changes because, unless it does, this country is doomed.
I conclude by indicating my strong support for the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion, which at the end of the motion for the second reading adds:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but the Senate is of the opinion that the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991 is indicative of the Government's failure to deliver a climate conducive to restructuring and long-term growth of the industry, in particular because it:

PARA.TAB: (a)fails to address the excessive tax burden on the industry;
(b)ignores the urgent need for industrial relations reform to promote genuine enterprise bargaining; and

(c)fails to deliver the generational changes in policies, attitudes and leadership which are needed to make Australian industry internationally competitive, as proposed in the Coalition's FIGHTBACK! program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to say a few words about the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill 1991. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) well knows, for many years I have supported reductions in protection in this industry, but I have always been of the view that, at the same time as those reductions in protection are implemented, there should be a reduction in the burdens imposed on this industry. I refer to the taxation burdens, in particular the burdens created by the current industrial relations system which, as the Minister would know, have in fact guaranteed increases in real wages during the term of this depression.

PARA.TAB: I have been encouraged to join in this debate mainly because of the views expressed by the Victorian Minister for Manufacturing and Industry Development. That is an interesting title for a Victorian Minister—industry development. As a result of the way that the Victorian Ministry has been behaving in the last three, four or five years, there has been no development going on in Victoria in any way. The Victorian Minister for Manufacturing and Industry Development, Mr David White, a colleague of Senator Button, said that the Federal Government's adoption of Federal Treasury policy towards manufacturing industry is flyblown—that was his word—and is driving manufacturers offshore.

He suggested that the Government adopt policies to stimulate industry, including accelerated depreciation allowances for manufacturing plant and equipment and other such proposals. During the course of his response to the second reading debate, would the Minister tell the Senate whether the Government intends to adopt any of Mr White's proposals?

I put it to the Minister that the task he and his Government face is to generate sufficient economic growth to create jobs for new entrants to the labour market and some of those in the unemployment pool while, at the same time, not rekindling inflationary pressures. Indeed, I put it to the Minister that the Government will have to be very careful to ensure that there is no short term gain in unemployment figures at the cost of greater economic dislocation in the medium term, so that lower inflation is then locked in and the balance of payments problems of the nation get worse.
I conclude these brief remarks by asking the Minister what it is that the Government proposes to do with regard to the present employment difficulties of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Lewis and Senator Sowada for their thoughtful contributions to this debate. I want to concentrate my remarks on the thoughtless contributions to the debate which came from the other two speakers because there is some importance in doing that. I have to begin by saying, lest a sense of perspective is lost, that for 27 years of conservative government in this country we were busy building a structure of protectionism around industries.
—Before my time.

—Yes, I know—before Senator Bishop's time but not before some of her colleagues' time. She is getting younger every day. I congratulate her. Between the readings there was a bit of vitriol, of course, which I suppose I do not have to bother to address, but I will deal with the written material which Senator Bishop read to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop cannot have it all possible ways. She cannot come in here, as people on the Senate Opposition side do, saying, `What a dreadful outrage' about a factory closing and people losing their employment, the pretence being that if the Liberal Party was in government these things would not happen. I remind Senator Bishop of John Hewson's employment scenarios which show that unemployment will get worse under a Liberal government. That is admitted. Even if Senator Bishop does not believe in the Syntec analysis of the Opposition's document, it is agreed by her own Leader that unemployment will get worse. She should not come in here spinning a different line on that.

What this Government has been about in nine years is restructuring the Australian economy. We have taken on tariff reductions across this economy. We have taken on deregulation of the financial sector. We have taken on a whole lot of regulatory reform which those opposite, when in government, ran away from. They had their chance in 1978 when their then Minister for industry, John Howard, had a report from the Industries Commission recommending general reductions in tariffs throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not me, I wasn't here.

—So Senator Bishop is innocent—she was not here. Dear Senator innocent Bish, is that not wonderful? In 1978, as a government, the Opposition had all these chances. The point I am making is that we inherited these problems and we have tackled them. That is a painful and difficult process.

PARA.TAB: The second thing those opposite should not kid themselves about is that with growing technological change in industry, it is a mark of success in an industry if employment grows. They should not kid themselves or the Australian people about that, as they try to do in their Fightback! document.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have just criticised Hewson for saying what you are saying.
—I am talking about manufacturing. Look at the section on manufacturing. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the motor vehicle industry has been in decline for more than a decade, shedding more than 20,000 jobs and steadily losing market share.
Factually, quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right!
—Quite wrong. It has not been steadily losing market share.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! The Minister is speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in this debate and if, again, Senator Bishop does not like what I say, she should be quiet and listen, and she can have another go later. Every time I speak, Senator Bishop interrupts me because she does not like what I say. She does not like facts. She likes to be able to read from a document in a debate in the Senate, interpolated with a bit of personal vitriol and that, according to Senator Bishop, is a debate. So on she goes, chat, chat, chat, like Elmer Fudd, the honourable senator who sits next to her, baa, baa, baa, all day and that is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The document is misleading in this sense: it tries to pretend that industry restructuring can be achieved without any difficulty at all. All we have to do is change the tax system—have a tax led recovery. According to John Hewson and his merry men, a tax led recovery will fix up all these problems.

Listen to Senator Chapman in here. He might as well have been in an echo chamber. He came in here and said, `There is no such thing as a free lunch'. Where did we hear all that stuff? That slogan belonged in the early 1970s—Milton Friedman: `No such thing as a free lunch'. Here was Senator Chapman, in 1991, with all the sophistication that the Liberal Party could muster, and he started off by telling us that there was no such thing as a free lunch.

Then he went on to reveal, as Senator Bishop did, total ignorance about this particular industry. He talked a lot about efficient export industries. I asked him what our most successful export industries were at the present time. He ought to go away and look it up. Last year, manufacturing exports exceeded total rural exports. He came in here like a chatterbox, repeating the slogans of the 1980s when the Opposition was in government—`The rural industries are our most successful exporters'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said mining, and you know it.

—He said the rural industries; he went through them all. In 1990-91 manufacturing exports exceeded coal in value. All I am trying to do is help Senator Bishop get up-to-date and I cannot do it with a bit of cosmetics or anything like that; I have to do it much more painfully.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Just to be helpful to the Minister, because he sometimes loses track of things, if he would like to get

INTERJECT.PARA: his Bill through he had better hurry up, because we have only got until 4.39 p.m., I think. So if he wants his Bill, he had just better hurry up with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order, Senator Bishop. I am sure the Minister is keeping his eye on the clock.

—There is no point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is the same point Senator Bishop always makes. She does not want to hear some facts. She wants to come in here, do a bit of reading and put a bit of vitriol into the debate, and that is a substitute for what should be an intelligent discussion on very important issues which face manufacturers in Australia. She should not start these debates on the basis of total misinformation, like the employment figures which she gave, which are quite wrong. The employment figures for this industry in August 1991 show 101,000 people. In May 1991 it was a bit lower than that.
—Are you sure you're reading them correctly?

—I am reading a couple of figures; I am not reading my argument because I understand my argument. I do not have to get it out of somebody else's office and come into the Senate and read it as if it were totally new to me. I understand the argument. I am just giving Senator Bishop those figures.

PARA.TAB: So Senator Bishop should not come in here trying to mislead this place with false figures about employment, false aspirations and false hopes. Those opposite say that, if the Liberal Party were in office, the Bendigo factory of David Bardas Sportscraft would not have closed—that all the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in this country need is the trains to run on time and a bit of structural adjustment. Some of these industries have labour disabilities of 100 per cent. Senator Bishop ought to understand that OECD countries recognise that fact. Some of these industries have disabilities of 100 per cent in terms of labour costs. That is why we are lowering protection. Throughout the world, other countries do exactly the same thing.

The whole of the European group and North American countries belong to the international multifibre agreement, as it is called, which accords those industries just as much protection as these much maligned industries in Australia are accorded. The multifibre agreement is being renegotiated in the GATT at the present time and it is likely to bring down a regime of assistance for those industries very much akin to the regime which exists in Australia as a result of what we did in March of this year.

This question of industry restructuring is a careful art, in my view. We have to take a number of things into account and we have to do it in a way which allows industries, as much as possible, to adjust in a sensible way to a regime in which employment will be less and in which the competitive advantages which we have in Australia can be best enhanced. Those areas where we have no competitive advantage because of total labour cost disabilities, or for some other reason, should be phased out.

It is a process which requires intelligence, a degree of pragmatism and thought. And, in a sense, that is what this Bill is about, in that it is trying to allow the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to help these industries through a process of adjustment. That does not mean that some of them will not close; some of them will close. The sad fact is that they ought to, because they are not capable of competing on the international market.

To come in here and say, as Senator Chapman and Senator Bishop have, `We will do away with all the protection of these industries; we will just get rid of that overnight' is the lazy person's way of doing it. That is the way which does not require the thought and the adjustment processes which I have just referred to. That is the lazy way to go about it. That is why Fightback! is such a lazy, sloppy document in relation to the motor vehicle industry. In order to make a case about protection, it says that market share of the Australian motor vehicle industry has been steadily declining over the years. That is untrue—a deliberate distortion of the facts, I assume. It is an argument which relates very much to Senator Chapman's bullish allegation that `there is no such thing as a free lunch'. It is a false argument.

I know that Senator Bishop is anxious not to hear any of these things. She would like the debate to be carried on in her own fashion—with a bit of windy rhetoric, a bit of vitriol and the belief that what it is all about is being up here in the big league. Well, it is not all about being up here in the big league; we have to think about a few issues.

Senator Lewis raised a few questions. I do not like Mr White, the Victorian Minister for manufacturing, describing any government's policies as flyblown. I must say that that is a bit offensive. He would not be allowed to talk like that in the Senate. He has his own agenda and his own concerns down there, and I think he ought to get on with them. As far as I am concerned, I will get on with mine. I would like to see this Bill pass through the Senate. I commend it to the Senate and I thank those two senators who made thoughtful speeches for their contributions to the debate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bishop's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 8 of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Amendment Bill amends section 42 of the principal Act, which enables the Authority to enter into arrangements with other bodies. The proposed new subsection 42(2) broadens the scope of these arrangements with the other bodies with which the TCFDA may do business. Nowhere in the second reading speech or in the explanatory memorandum can I find any reason for this increased scope. I would like the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to tell me what is the purpose of it and why it is required.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That sort of provision was in the previous legislation in relation to the raw material processing program, which has now been abolished. `Other bodies' embraces organisations such as the AIDC or a bank, and it would, for example, enable some different forms of financial assistance to be made available to a firm when it is restructuring.

—I do not quite follow that because, as I understand it, the Budget allocation for assistance in the area that the Minister is referring to was underspent. The Minister says that sort of provision was in previous legislation. What is the previous legislation to which he is referring?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation here. The amendment removes two programs from the parent legislation. One of the programs that was removed was the raw material processing program, which used similar language. The purpose of the amendment to this Bill is to give the Authority greater flexibility in providing financial assistance, perhaps through an intermediary such as the AIDC, to a particular firm which is being restructured.
—Is the answer to my question then specifically the AIDC; and is that the Corporation, AIDC Ltd or both?
—In the normal course of events it would be AIDC Ltd, of course, because the Corporation does not normally engage in that sort of activity.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on questions without notice, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished senator, Gordon McIntosh, whom we wish well on his visit to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the September quarter national accounts figures released today showing a further fall in gross domestic product, the fifth such fall in succession and the seventh in the last eight quarters. I also refer the Minister to the further fall in private investment, the eighth such fall in the last nine quarters, and to the massive fall in stocks, reflecting a further major loss of business confidence. What does the Government plan to do to correct this disastrous rolling recession?

—This is an appropriate time to comment on the September quarter GDP numbers. Of course they are weaker than the forecasts which have been made by the Government or most private sector commentators. But before Elmer Fudd over here goes off and the Opposition starts getting too excited about a bit of bad news, I should point out that the overall figures are heavily influenced by the continuing poor conditions in the rural sector.

PARA.TAB: GDP declined in the September quarter by 0.3 per cent—that is seasonally adjusted and in real terms—to be 1.9 per cent below the September quarter 1990. The main reasons for these quarterly numbers are, firstly, that both private and government consumption are up moderately, contributing 1.2 percentage points to GDP; secondly, investment—which Senator Short referred to—is down moderately, detracting from growth by 0.1 per cent; and stocks detracted strongly from growth. And I agree with Senator Short's implicit comment about the causes for that. On the other hand, net exports were very positive, adding 0.3 per cent to GDP, and the farm sector detracted from growth by a large 0.6 percentage points. There is no comfort or joy for the Government or industry in these figures. I suppose if there is comfort it should be seen in the continuation of the strong growth of net exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say, `There is no comfort'?

—No, I did not say that. I said if there is comfort it can be taken from the strong growth in net exports and from the modest 0.4 per cent growth in the non-farm sector, which sets aside the influence on growth of a deeply recessed rural sector. I should also point to the continuing improvement in inflation. The change in the non-farm GDP deflator is now down to 2.4 per cent, and I think it is instructive to look at the annualised trade figures which show net exports for the year contributing a massive 3.2 percentage points to growth. Those are the sets of figures in respect of trade performance which are vitally important to the future of this country. Any policies which increased inflation or increased interest rates, which would be very detrimental to that trade performance, should of course be avoided.
—You are the world champions on interest rates—about eight years of high interest rates.
—No, we are not. Any policies which changed those indicators would be very damaging to the Australian economy, and we ought to have a look at the figures before we are misled by Elmer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer and his lack of denial that there is a continuing rolling recession, will the Government now adopt the proposals contained in the coalition's Fightback program of economic reform which do address the underlying problems facing the Australian economy and which do provide the leadership, the vision and, more particularly, the hope that all Australians are so desperately seeking?

—The answer to that question is no—and I want to tell Senator Short, as he has asked the question, why it is no. Firstly, on any objective analysis which is freed from these mindless assumptions which clutter the heads of people like Senator Short, there is a clear message in the so-called Opposition Fightback program. As to the export figures which Senator Short has just asked me about, the message is particularly clear for Australian exporters that, under an Opposition coalition Government, inflation would rise, interest rates would rise, and the only thing that we could say with confidence would fall would be tax for people on $90,000 or more a year. We can say with certainty that they would benefit from a package like that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the same point exactly. As usual, the Opposition does not want to hear these unpalatable figures because its policy—which we reject—is a mixture of false assumptions, misleading information and conjecture, and has been put together as a tax led recovery for this country. One element of a tax led recovery is, of course, that everybody in this country will pay 15 per cent more for everything they buy. The Opposition package is filled with columns of things which are called `compensation'. Why are they called compensation? Because they would compensate for that burden which would be imposed on everybody in this country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the Opposition's sudden interest in human rights in Burma, as expressed during the debate on the political ad ban and disclosures Bill, can the Minister indicate what the Government is doing about the Burmese regime which has now been condemned by the United Nations General Assembly for its refusal to end human rights abuses and introduce democratic reforms, and what can be done about the continued detention of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner?

—We are very encouraged—and I would hope the Opposition is too—by the UN General Assembly's resolution on 30 November which expressed concern over `the grave human rights situation in Burma' and which called for early improvement in the situation. The resolution also welcomed the Secretary-General's appeals for the early release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and will help to maintain, obviously, international pressure on the Burmese regime to release her unconditionally.

PARA.TAB: Australia was very active in the UN exercise to ensure maximum support for that resolution, in cooperation with a number of other countries—in particular, Sweden, which played a very valuable role. The important thing to appreciate is that the resolution was a consensus one which attracted very widespread support from the international community—in particular, from Burma's regional neighbours who, I think for the first time, went on the public record in this way to indicate through this resolution their concern for the human rights situation in Burma.

The Burmese delegation opposed the resolution in debate but, in the light of the country's isolation on the issue, did not in fact call for a vote. The resolution does send a strong and unequivocal message to the regime. Concern about the country has now been expressed in the clearest possible terms by the international community, and I do not think anyone in Burma can be in any doubt now about the steps which it should take.

As to the particular situation with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, I am pleased to be able to say—because it did not get very much publicity—that the Thai Foreign Minister recently announced that there had been confirmation from the Burmese regime in response to a request from Thailand, which is itself encouraging, that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is alive and well. They also said—and this was reported—that she will now be able to receive letters from her husband.

In concert with the US, Sweden, Norway and New Zealand, Australia initiated a joint demarche in Rangoon three weeks ago concerning Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. It expressed concern over reports that she was ill and called for visiting rights to be accorded to her, and it condemned the regime's refusal to take any meaningful step to respond to the clear wishes of the Burmese people expressed last year for a transfer of power to a democratically elected government. We called in the Ambassador to Burma on that same day and presented him with the points contained in the demarche. I personally made it very clear to him in a conversation a little earlier that the feeling of the Australian community and Parliament was absolutely unanimous on this issue. Australia was also associated with a further demarche coordinated by the European Community to similar effect.

Australia will continue to play an active role through these international institutions and mechanisms and processes to focus international attention on the human rights situation in Burma and to bring pressure to bear. We will do so at our next available opportunity, the meeting of the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva early in the New Year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister arrange to have the resolution which was carried by the UN incorporated in Hansard, or at least tabled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will incorporate the document in Hansard at the conclusion of the answer if I have the leave of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Distr.
Limited
25 November 1991
Original: English

ANSWER.PARA: HUMAN RIGHTS QUESTIONS: HUMAN RIGHTS SITUATIONS AND REPORTS OF SPECIAL RAPPORTEURS AND REPRESENTATIVES

Albania, Argentina, Australia, Austria, Bulgaria, Canada, Chile, Costa Rica, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, India, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Mauritius, Norway, Panama, Poland, Romania, Samoa, Sweden, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and United States of America: draft resolution

PARA.TAB: The General Assembly,

Reaffirming that all Member States have an obligation to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms stated in the Charter of the United Nations and elaborated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1/ and the International Covenants on Human Rights 2/ and other applicable human rights instruments,

Aware that, in accordance with the Charter, the Organisation promotes and encourages respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms for all and that the Universal Declarations of Human Rights states that "the will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government",

Recalling that the Government of Myanmar has assured the General Assembly and other United Nations bodies of its intention to take all necessary steps towards democracy in the light of the elections held in 1990,
Noting with concern substantive available information indicating a grave human rights situation in Myanmar,
Welcoming the Secretary-General's statement on the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Aung Sang Suu Kyi and his repeated appeals for her early release from house arrest,
1.Takes note of the assurances of the Government of Myanmar to take firm steps towards the establishment of a democratic State and looks forward to the early implementation of this commitment;
2.Expresses its concern at the information on the grave human rights situation and stresses the need for an early improvement of this situation;
3.Urges the Government of Myanmar to allow all citizens to participate freely in the political process in accordance with the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights;
4.Decides to continue its consideration of this question at its forty-seventh session.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's statement today that the 1991-92 Budget forecasts will be reviewed following the release of the September quarter national accounts figures which, as has been said, show the fifth consecutive fall in GDP. Why has it taken the Government so long to respond to the coalition's continual demands for such a review, the need for which has been so obvious for so long?

—That question is founded on a monumental ignorance of the Budget process. The Budget was brought down in August. The forecasts in the Budget, with regard to most of the major indicators, were that employment would continue to decline in the first half of the financial year and would then improve, and that activity would be very sluggish in the first half of the financial year and then improve.
—Everyone knew the forecasts were wrong before the ink was dry.
—Dr Know-all has been sitting on back benches all over the country for years. No doubt, he knows all of these things; but none of the forecasters did.
—What about a serious answer?
—Senator Short cannot answer a question or make an interjection; he comes in here after Question Time each day and takes note of answers and makes vacuous statements which are usually wrong.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the interjection and in respect of the clamour by people in the Opposition, let me say that it is not appropriate to review the Budget forecasts every month or every week, as Senator Hill implies in his question, since the Budget was delivered. But, from time to time, it is appropriate that forecasts be reviewed. One forecast which I do not think needs to be reviewed is that for the current account, which is quite clearly in good shape and is totally consistent with the—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got one right.

—No, I am not saying that. The employment figure is pretty consistent with the Budget forecast and each of the ones I mentioned a moment ago is pretty consistent with the Budget forecast. The Opposition may have invented this idea of revising forecasts when it happens to suit it; I am sorry, but it is not something the Government will be doing.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If that is so, why has the Treasurer now decided to conduct such a review?
—The burden of the original question and my answer to it is simply this: not because the Opposition suggested it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and it refers to the ongoing tragedy of the Yugoslav civil war. Can the Minister advise the Senate what the current situation is in Yugoslavia and what the prospects are for a peaceful settlement? Can the Minister also advise what the situation is regarding the economic measures taken by Australia against Yugoslavia in support of the international community's peace efforts?

—Although, as honourable senators will obviously be aware from following news broadcasts, the situation in Yugoslavia remains very tense, there are encouraging signs that the cease-fire that has been brokered by the UN envoy, Mr Cy Vance, is still holding in most areas. There is, however, particular continuing concern over the fate of the Croatian town of Osijek, which is surrounded by units of the Yugoslav national army. The prospects for a peaceful settlement do obviously rest on the maintenance of this cease-fire and the possibility flowing from that of the dispatch of a UN peacekeeping force.

PARA.TAB: On 27 November, the UN Security Council unanimously adopted resolution 721, which responded to a request from Yugoslavia for the establishment of a UN peacekeeping operation. That resolution approved the activities of Mr Vance and foreshadowed a willingness to consider the establishment of a peacekeeping operation as requested. Mr Vance is now still in Yugoslavia negotiating with the parties. He has called for more progress to be made in implementing a general cease-fire and in lifting the siege of the Yugoslav national army barracks in Croatia. He is expected to make some recommendations to the Secretary-General quite soon, whereupon the Security Council will reconvene to consider the question. What is being looked at seems to be a peacekeeping force numbering around 9,000 to 10,000 troops, at a cost of no less than $US200m.

As to Australia's continued involvement in this, Mr Duffy, as acting Foreign Minister, in mid-November announced the economic measures we would take and explained that Australia did propose to follow the European Community's practice of exempting the republics of Yugoslavia which cooperate in the peace process. The European Community has now decided to restore trade and aid concessions to the republics of Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, thus retaining the measures against the republics of Serbia and Montenegro—although the case of Montenegro is subject to review.

I am able to say today that the Australian Government will adopt the same position as the EC. The benefits of the Australian system of tariff preferences will be withdrawn from Yugoslavia and instead extended, selectively, to the republics of Croatia, Slovenia, Macedonia and Bosnia-Herzegovina. The date of effect of this will be 1 January next year. Training assistance under the Australian program of training for eastern Europe—or APTEE—for the 1992 academic year will, again, be provided only to students from the four republics designated as cooperating republics.

In our judgment, it would be wrong for the international community to decrease the pressure on parties at this crucial stage. I understand that the UN Security Council still has under consideration the possibility of an oil embargo, should progress on peace not be sustained. I simply say that in this respect, too, the Australian Government stands ready to implement any sanctions which are imposed upon Yugoslavia by the Security Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It refers to the statement made by the Prime Minister on the Sunday program last weekend that it was too early to judge whether there should be a referendum on self-determination in East Timor. I ask the Minister: firstly, does Mr Hawke's statement indicate that the Government regards a self-determination referendum as a future possibility; secondly, when will the time be right to judge that a referendum should or should not occur; finally, does the Minister accept the view put by Fretilin representative Jose Ramos Horta that the legacy of 16 years of Indonesian military occupation is that proposals for an East Timorese accommodation of Indonesian rule are unrealistic?

—The Prime Minister on the Sunday program was simply re-stating what has been clearly articulated Australian Government policy—that is, no policy change at all at the moment. We still recognise Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor, for reasons which have been amply explained previously. But the whole combination of our policies towards Indonesia as they impact on East Timor will be subject to review and reconsideration if the process of the present inquiry—the national commission of investigation—proves to be manifestly unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the question of a referendum on self-determination arises only in the context of a pretty fundamental reversal of Australian and international policy which, so far as the majority of nations is concerned, has been clearly unwilling to go down that path, recognising Indonesian sovereignty as an irreversible reality since the 1970s. But it remains one of the policy issues that we will be prepared to have a look at along with everything else if the process which is presently under way does prove to be unsatisfactory.

Of course, we very much hope that that process will be transparent and credible and will expose the nature of the horrifying incident which did occur, and that further processes will be put in train immediately thereafter to punish those responsible—who are guilty either of criminal acts or of other forms of excessive behaviour. But until that particular process has worked itself out, or not worked itself out as the case may be, it would be premature to make any other judgment.

As has been announced, I, of course, will be going to Indonesia in a few days time—on 19 and 20 December. I will be putting our very strong concerns to the Indonesian Government, including our concern not only that the process be a credible one but also that steps be taken towards achieving an effective reconciliation and resolution of the East Timorese conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an analysis conducted by Syntec which describes the outlook for inflation through the 1990s? What would be the implication for interest rates and, particularly, mortgage rates and repayments should there be a marked increase in inflation?

—A number of questions are implicit in what Senator Beahan had to say, and I want to deal with them one by one. I have seen newspaper reports of the Syntec document. It is very important for a number of reasons. First of all, let me say that it indicates that the policies of the Government are likely to deliver a sustainable fall in inflation both through the coming year and, if we are re-elected at the next election, through the years ahead.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it indicates that this Government could firm private sector asset markets in Australia such as commercial, industrial and residential property and share capital. The contrast, Mr President, is bleak in terms of the documents which are available in the public debate which Senator Beahan referred to in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is that Treasury analysis going, Johnny?

—Syntec says that in a perfect world, assumed by Dr Hewson, for example, in the visionary world which is conceived through a keyhole by the Opposition, inflation would increase to a minimum of 9.5 per cent in 1994 and interest rates would increase up to 16 per cent in that period. Of course that would be necessary to contain some of the wilder assumptions which are inherent in the Opposition document.
—What about the effect on mortgages?

—Senator Kemp is asking me what would be the effect on mortgages. I have said on a number of occasions in the Senate that, because the figures are published in the document, the effects on the taxation income of various groups in the community would be very different. For example, the income level of $30,000 a year would receive a tax cut per week of $30 and an income level of $75,000 a year would receive a tax benefit of $135 a week—all, as the package says, as compensation to buy the goods and services which would have a 15 per cent tax imposed on them at the value added level.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I have been asked what these figures mean in terms of mortgages. They are exactly the same pattern in terms of mortgages as is seen from the tax cuts themselves. The effects on people who have mortgages are exactly the same. For example, Senator Kemp, mouth open as usual, was asking for the Treasury figures on this. Let me tell him. A 4 per cent increase in interest rates would have this effect on mortgages: $82.50 would still be the benefit from the tax cut available to somebody on an income of $75,000 a year; and a person on $30,000 a year would be $22.40 worse off per week. The person on the $75,000 income and above would still be $82.50 better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —When do we get to see this Treasury report?

—I was asked first by Senator Beahan, and again by interjection, what the effects would be on mortgage holders throughout Australia. That is the answer. I was asked to give some Treasury figures. Those figures are Treasury figures, and that is the answer. So the fact of the matter is that, even if one-quarter of the projections in the Syntec analysis was realised in terms of inflation effect and interest rate effect, then those sorts of results would follow. We would get a further huge differential growing up between the rich in this country, those people this package is mainly designed to give succour to, and those people on medium incomes and low incomes.
—That is not true.
—Senator Short interjects as usual and says that is untrue because he does not want to believe that any group which put forward a package like this would really have those intended consequences.
—You know it is not true.

—Senator Short wants to think he is not embracing a package which is a beautiful present for the rich of this country but very detrimental in terms of tax scales and mortgage costs to ordinary people in this community.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I note that he has seen the paper, but I wonder whether the Minister has seen the views of his colleague and counterpart in Victoria, Mr White, that the Federal Government's adoption of Federal Treasury policy towards manufacturing industry is `flyblown'. I know the Minister knew about that. But Mr White went on to say that the policy is `like maggots descending on a carcass', and that it is driving manufacturers offshore. Is the Minister also aware that the Victorian Premier, Joan Kirner, then jumped to the support of Mr White and immediately backed his criticisms? I ask what the Government is doing, or is proposing to do, to change this situation.

—Mr President, I do not normally read the populist evening press in Melbourne but I did see it yesterday. In fact it was drawn to my attention by a Minister sitting here. I did see what Mr White had to say. I think they have their own anxieties. I think Mr White himself has some anxieties. I think they have their own agendas, and that is understandable in State politics, as Senator Lewis well knows.

PARA.TAB: I think there is some confusion in Mr White's comments about some suggestions of manufacturers moving in droves offshore. That is a bit of rhetoric. It is not supported by reality, I am afraid. But, apart from that, I hope Mr White will have great success in solving his problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the delegation led by Senator Schacht and the report of the Australian human rights delegation to China which was tabled by the Minister in the Senate. On page 48 of that report the delegation said that it was assured that abortion is never mandatory in Sichuan Province and that this policy appeared to be confirmed by statistics relating to the Sichuan Province. Prior to going to China, why was the delegation not informed of the Sichuan Province family planning regulations which in fact make it mandatory for particular women to submit to compulsory abortions and sterilisations? I refer specifically to articles 13, 14, 23 and 27. Who was responsible for the delegation being so poorly briefed in respect of these gross violations of human rights in China, and is the Government considering paying taxpayers' money directly or indirectly to the PRC population control program while such gross violations of human rights are contained in regulations and remain unpunished?

—Mr President, as I recall, much of this was debated in the Estimates Committee hearings in recent times. I think the particular question of provincial family planning regulations has been pretty exhaustively canvassed by Senator Harradine in that context. If there was any regulation that he knew about that we did not, I am sure he would have drawn it to our attention in that context.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that I can accept the premise of his question about the nature of the regulations in question, nor their proper interpretation, nor the circumstances in which they may or may not have been drawn to the attention of the delegation. I will have to seek information on all those matters and I will do my best to inform him accordingly.

The Australian Government's position on these policy issues, as Senator Harradine well knows, is not one of support for coercive or mandatory techniques and certainly not for abortions in those circumstances. We have done our constant best to ensure that does not happen and have made it clear that the disposition of our aid funds ought not to go to agencies which are responsible for perpetrating coercive activities of that kind. There are some problems of interpretation at the margin, as Senator Harradine well knows. However, I will see what further comment it is possible to make after I have had a chance to look at the particular issue that Senator Harradine has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister knows full well that I referred to those articles specifically by name and gave the details of the articles which clearly mandate abortions and sterilisation. It is a fact that this report contains certain parts of the Sichuan Province family planning regulations. If the Government and the delegation had the full regulations, why did they not condemn those regulations because they involved such gross violations of human rights?

—Senator Harradine will have to ask the delegation. One of the members who knows something about this issue is sitting on his right and another, Senator Schacht, when he turns up will be sitting to Senator Harradine's left. They will be in a much better position than I am to give him an analysis of the substantive issues that he raises. The delegation shares the Government's concern about coercive or mandatory contraception or abortion being applied in China or anywhere else. I am sure that members of the delegation will communicate that at an appropriate time if there is any issue that needs to be responded to.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's statement today blaming the drought for dragging out Australia's recession to cover five consecutive falls in gross domestic product, making it more protracted than the 1982-83 recession of four consecutive falls. If the Treasurer now intends to use non-farm GDP to measure recessions by excluding droughts—which, by the way, in 1982-83 cut gross farm product by 33 per cent over five quarters but only by 16 per cent in the latest quarter or 8 per cent over the latest five quarters—does this mean that, even without the drought, this recession is still more protracted with four consecutive non-farm GDP falls than the recession in 1982-83 when there were only three?

—I am not a highly numerate person, but I think I can do those mathematics. Four quarters of negative growth is worse than three and five quarters is worse than four. I appreciate Senator Brownhill's helpful calculations. They are probably right arithmetically. In answer to the earlier part of Senator Brownhill's question, the non-farm growth figures in the national accounts for the September quarter were not out of line with the Budget forecast and with the sort of figures one would expect. It is certainly true that the fall in farm growth pulled down those figures. While the drought may have contributed to that fall in farm growth, I think it has been on a downward trend for some period earlier than the effects of the drought would indicate. For example, wool sales, sales of a number of other rural commodities and so on, both in terms of prices and volumes, have been down, mostly related to questions of access to international markets for exports. The drought and the effects of the drought will certainly exacerbate what has already been a difficult situation for rural sector growth.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the answer that the Minister counts farm product in the recession? If that is the case, when does he now expect the recession to end in view of the continuing rural crisis?

—In a number of matters, such as total export activity, the farm sector is less significant than it was. Historically, the rural sector has been enormously important in Australian export activity. In the past two or three years manufacturing exports, for example, have exceeded rural exports in value. That has been for a number of reasons: the very high growth in manufacturing exports and a decline in the value of exports such as wool. Of course, the rural sector is, and will remain, a huge contributor to total GDP in Australia. I suspect that nobody in his right mind would argue with that point of view.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the periodical Price Probe which claims that since 1986 coffee bean prices have fallen by 72 per cent but retail prices have fallen only marginally? Has the Prices Surveillance Authority entered into negotiations with Nestle Australia Ltd, which supplies 68 per cent of Australia's instant coffee market, to encourage it to lower its prices? If so, can the Minister inform the Senate whether there are any prospects for a fall in the price of coffee?

—Senator Colston was kind enough to give me some notice of this question. I have to tell him that the answer given to me commences by stating that the Prices Surveillance Authority has been `watching coffee beans since 1986'. I think it was T. S. Eliot who used the great line that he measured out his life with coffee spoons. The Prices Surveillance Authority has been doing that to ensure there is no delay in passing on those price reductions to consumers.

PARA.TAB: I am told that prices of instant coffee, the product of companies such as Nestle, were reduced in 1986, 1987 and 1989. There was a further reduction from Nestle in April 1990. The extent and timing of coffee price reductions will, of course, not be identical to movements in the world price of coffee beans; there are always lags and so on. But the Authority understands that further price reductions are probably warranted at the present time and this view has been indicated to the manufacturers. Of course, the Government expects to be advised by the Authority of developments in respect of this and the relevant Minister will request the Authority to take what action is available to it at the appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister agree that a sustainable improvement in Australia's trade in services can be achieved only by the development of comparative advantage in our service sector? Does he agree that one of the central features of those economies that have developed this advantage is a high level of private provision of public services and privatisation? Would he also agree that many of the nations in the South East Asian region have been making rapid progress with privatisation, leaving Australia years behind? Finally, will the doctrinaire, anti-privatisation mindset of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party ensure that Australia misses the opportunity to develop comparative advantage in services, or will the Government pursue a privatisation program to expand opportunities for Australians to develop world competitive service industries?
—I would not get too excited about what Senator Campbell called the mindless mindset of left wing members of the Labor Party. I think he ought to be concerned about—
—I didn't call it mindless; you did.

—That was the word I was just about to apply to the honourable senator's question. I think he ought to be a bit more concerned about some of the rhetoric inherent in his own question. I will tell the honourable senator what I will do for him: I will provide him as soon as possible with a comparative table of the public sector share of GDP in a number of OECD countries—all OECD countries, if he likes. He will find that the Australian public sector share of GDP is relatively low—in fact, very low—compared with most of those countries.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell asked a question in relation to a number of unspecified countries in the Asia-Pacific region. I will try to provide him with some figures on those countries, too. All of those countries are essentially mixed economies. Most of them are what we used to call command economics still in terms of their economic management. I do not think one can draw a great deal of comfort from that in seeking to establish a sort of ideological point in this debate. The facts do not support the honourable senator.

There is a different question as to what ought to be done about privatisation issues in Australia. That is the subject of a different debate. The point is that the public sector as a share of GDP here is not, as the question implies, very significant compared with other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. At a recent public hearing of veterans on the Gold Coast, it was claimed that medical specialists were declining to treat veterans because it was taking the Department of Veterans' Affairs at least a month to process their claims compared with two weeks for Medicare. Is it usual for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to take four weeks? Apart from shopping around, what would the Minister advise veterans to do, because it is not easy for them to shop around in places like the Gold Coast?

—The first thing I would say is that I would be shocked—and I am sure Senator Herron would be also—if medical specialists were refusing to give their attention to veterans, who served this country under combat conditions and overseas in very stressful situations, because they were not paid for about a fortnight longer than they anticipated being paid. If that were true, I would find it absolutely horrifying to think that there could be such greed in the profession of the practice of medicine that would lead to that situation.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Veterans' Affairs is not aware of any such problem in the payment to specialists on the Gold Coast of Queensland. If a provider of services has a problem, then they should contact the Brisbane office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It may be that Senator Kernot is referring to the situation that arose out of the recent dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with the dispute.

—Senator Kernot said that it had nothing to do with the dispute. I do have some figures: at the end of the recent dispute, there were 17,758 claims outstanding in Queensland. As at last night, there were 11,469 claims outstanding. That is a 35 per cent reduction in the backlog in 10 working days. I believe that is a great effort by DVA staff to return the claims processing to what I am informed is a normal processing period of seven to 10 working days—a fortnight. Certainly, it is hoped that the backlog will be cleared by 20 December in Queensland. I would think that the specialists who communicated their concern to Senator Kernot may have been caught up in the dispute, although she says that that is not so. But if there was a problem, they should communicate with the Brisbane office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and have the matter resolved that way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. When will the Minister ask his Department to investigate the anomalies still present with regard to war widows pensions? There are some 34,000 war widows aged over 60 receiving up to $53.75 per fortnight less than those who have other income equivalent to a war widows pension. There are 8,000 war widows who have rental assistance receiving up to $113.75 per fortnight less than other comparable pensioners. Some 630 war widows with dependent children receive less than comparable civilian widows or single parents. In effect, they receive no compensation for the war caused deaths of their husbands, most of whom served in Vietnam. The social security age pension available to war widows was frozen in 1986, as the Minister would know, at $60.05 per week. This has been whittled away by inflation. Other similar economy measures in the 1986 Budget have since been reversed—
—Is this a speech?
—This is a very long question, Senator Calvert.
—I am concluding now. I ask the Minister again: when does the Government intend to correct these anomalies?

—I recently had quite lengthy discussions with Brigadier Garland and some representatives of the war widows in which we looked at a number of options that they had sought to have me examine. I would have to concede that they do have a case for the Government redressing what I would see as an imbalance. I did not accept then, nor do I accept now, all of the assertions that the honourable senator has made about war widows and their position as against other women receiving social security benefits, but certainly I do believe they have got a case. I have agreed to take a number of options to the Government. I will be doing so in the new year. However, I am not in a position to announce to Senator Calvert what I am likely to take to Cabinet. I am confident that by March I will be able to report to him on some progress.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Government examined the effects of gap insurance for medical services? Is the Government likely to introduce gap insurance for medical services? Can the Minister say what would be the effect on the price of a service and the effect on the total national health costs from introducing gap insurance? What is the effect of gap insurance on inflation?

—Quite simply, there would be quite an effect on inflation by the introduction of gap insurance because patient charges and gap insurance are taken into account when compiling the CPI; whereas, where services are bulkbilled and insurance is effected through the taxation system, those matters do not enter into the components that are assessed for CPI purposes. We can be quite sure that the introduction of gap insurance will have an impact on the CPI and will feed into the increases, with all the disastrous consequences which will flow to the Australian community from an increase in the cost of living, in the CPI. I am sure that Senator Short would agree that that is the impact and that it will have that increasing effect.
—No, not necessarily at all.

—It must be the case that, if one takes into account private insurance—which one does not have to do in relation to insurance effected through the tax system—it must have an effect on the CPI. I do not think Senator Short is right there.

PARA.TAB: The Government will not be contemplating introduction of gap insurance because, quite clearly, it will increase the health care bills for ordinary Australian households—for all Australians, in effect. Not only will they have to pay the levy of 1.25 per cent on their income; they will also be put in a situation where they virtually have to take out this private gap insurance, because all the pressures will be there to enable people to make a payment when they go to see their doctor, their primary health care giver, their GP, because he will be charging the benchmark AMA schedule fee. There is no doubt about that. The reason he will be charging that AMA schedule fee is that those opposite want to take away the competition—they will be forbidding, prohibiting, not permitting, a GP to choose to bulkbill those who are not pensioners or card holders.

In that situation, without that competitive pressure which should come through the marketplace in the provision of services given by GPs, the Australian Medical Association schedule fee will become the benchmark. That particular fee of course will be set by the AMA in association with the private health insurance firms. That is the cosy deal which will be done. Gap insurance is designed to ensure that there is a transfer of money from the pockets of Australians seeking medical help and attention into the pockets of the doctors. Some $900m will be transferred in that way. For those reasons, of course, the Government will not be contemplating the introduction of gap insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In accordance with his previous directive that he will answer questions with respect to boards of inquiry which have been held, I ask: is it a fact that the board of inquiry into the fatal accident of an RAAF Nomad on 12 March 1990 found that at the start of the last flight of the aircraft, firstly, there was cracking of the horizontal stabiliser box beam of the tail plane; secondly, the horizontal stabiliser box beam failed under normal in-flight loads because of those cracks; thirdly, the customary inspection was not performed when this used aircraft was accepted from GAF/ASTA; and, finally, the servicing check—S17—due on 6 March was not performed? In view of these extraordinary circumstances, why was the board's conclusion that `Disciplinary action against any person or persons is not warranted' accepted?

—The general facts contained in Senator MacGibbon's question are correct. I am not aware of what was in the board's mind with respect to that particular factor. That is why we have boards of inquiry. I cannot go into the mind of the board as to why that recommendation was made, given the other acknowledgments in the report. If I can find anything further on that, I will let Senator MacGibbon know. I stress that I cannot go into the mind of a board of inquiry.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There must have been some concern. There was not only a board of inquiry, but there was also an independent engineering assessment made by the Department of Defence of the board of inquiry's findings. I assume that that demonstrated some concern at the findings of the board; am I right or am I wrong?

—Senator MacGibbon is right about the concern. Unfortunately, the essence of his question was: why did the board recommend in such a way? As I said, I cannot go into the mind of the board to answer that. No-one is suggesting that there has been no problem in this regard; there has been. A series of steps have been taken to try to rectify it. Those steps did not involve, as I understand it, disciplinary action.

—I direct my question to you, Mr President. Has there been an increase, over recent weeks, in the taking of points of order, particularly meaningless points of order? If so, is this having a detrimental effect on the operation of the Senate? Is this practice, for example, reducing the number of questions that are able to be asked in the hour allocated for Question Time each day?

—Order! In reply to Senator McKiernan, it is my impression that there has been a recent increase in the taking of points of order. It is hard to say whether that has a detrimental effect. I will undertake to look at the issue and get some relevant figures on it. I will give those figures to Senator McKiernan.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. My question is simple: why has the Government decided not to go ahead with the intrusive pharmacy based black box eligibility system?

—I have not seen the full brief to the Minister responsible for pharmacy matters, Mr Peter Staples. I have not had a chance to peruse a press release which Senator Patterson apparently refers to. I understand that the reason is that the figures which were first thought to be correct were not a sound foundation for the decision that was taken. The Audit Office, which made certain assessments, on better reflection and on looking at the figures in a much more professional way, decided that the figures on which policy was formally and correctly based were not correct.

PARA.TAB: In other words, this Government has done what all good governments should do—when an assessment is made which indicates that the basic facts upon which a policy was structured are not, in fact, the case, it is quite open about it and changes the policy. I think that is a very good way to govern. It indicates a very good response to the newly recognised facts in this matter.

Senator Patterson referred to the privacy intrusive black box. It is very interesting. Under the Fightback program announced by the Opposition, the Opposition intends to ensure that community pharmacies are entitled to make Medicare payments to people who present their bills for payment, their receipts from services that they have had at a GP. In that situation, the chemists would need to have a black box in order to check with the Health Insurance Commission as to the eligibility of the person asking for a payment. I would have thought that that is a very privacy intrusive matter. Where there are persons who have had a service and want to be paid by Medicare at the community pharmacy, pharmacists will be in a position to get hold of all of the information relating to the type of service which was provided to them. I believe that that is very privacy intrusive. I will be quite happy to do battle with Senator Patterson on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister admit that the Government revised those figures because this chamber referred them to the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's Department? Will the Minister also agree that the Health Insurance Commission made a very serious error in estimating the average savings in these figures, instead of totally blaming the Auditor-General's Department? I think that admission should come in this chamber now.
—I have already indicated that it is always sound government policy to change policy if figures prove to be unsound; in fact, that has been the case here. I have made that statement very clearly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Minister will remember that last Monday Senator O'Chee complained that if freight on goods dispatched to country towns is paid by the wholesaler who dispatches the goods, sales tax is added to freight on the goods subject to sales tax. If the Opposition's value added tax, which it labels a goods and services tax, is introduced, will freight on all goods—not just those currently liable to sales tax—be taxed at a rate of 15 per cent?

—This question goes to the heart of how a goods and services tax would work, which is clearly something which Opposition senators such as Senator O'Chee do not understand. The goods and services tax would impose a charge of 15 per cent on the total price of every good and service purchased by consumers, with a very few limited exceptions.

PARA.TAB: This compares with the existing wholesale sales tax system where a wide range of goods, including most foods, are exempt; services are not directly taxed. For example, if a truck load of goods which included food or clothing was taken to an outback town in Queensland, there is no current wholesale sales tax on the cargo. I will also say a few words about how the current wholesale sales tax regime bears on the operation of the freight service. With a consumption tax, there is a 15 per cent tax on the value added at each stage before the good is received by the consumer. The existing wholesale sales tax system has some effects on transport costs. I refer to them briefly. First, they are comparatively small.

TALK.START.PARA: —Massive.
—Senator O'Chee says that they are massive—he is wrong again.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Mr President, your ruling of recent times has been that questions can be asked if they relate to Government policy.
—You just asked two questions about your package.

—I am not interested in what others might have asked; I am dealing with Senator Walsh's question. Senator Walsh's question made no attempt to inquire as to whether the Government was proposing to introduce any form of additional tax, let alone a value added tax, as he chose to describe it. It was simply an invitation to Senator Button to talk about the operation of a GST. The Government is not proposing to introduce a GST; Senator Button has not been asked anything along those lines. Mr President, I invite you to rule the question out of order.
—It is clearly in order because he was asked what would be the effect of a certain tax if it were introduced. So far as I have heard the answer, that is exactly what he has been answering.

—Further on the point of order, Mr President: the point is that it is utterly hypothetical. Either he is being asked about our GST proposal—if he is, he ought to deal with all the elements of it; the rebates and the various concessions—or he is talking academically about some form of value added tax. That has nothing to do with his responsibility.
