—I cannot instruct the Minister how to answer a particular question.

—On a point of order, Mr President: if it is in relation to the introduction of a tax, is this a confirmation of Max Walsh's report in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning that Labor will be considering introducing its own GST when Paul Keating is made Prime Minister?
—That is no point of order and Senator Campbell knows it.
—I was asked a question by Senator Walsh and I propose to answer it. Senator Hill can stop rabbiting on—

—On a point of order, Mr President: there are Ministers leaving the chamber while Question Time is continuing. I thought it had been cleared up previously that Ministers should be present during Question Time and remain till the end of it. There may well be questions of Ministers relating to unanswered questions and things of that nature.
—Order! There is no point of order, because I do not have control over who does or does not leave the chamber.

—Senator Alston—keen to get his mouth working again—rose to take a point of order at precisely the wrong time. I was talking about the effects of the wholesale sales tax on the transport sector. If he thinks that has nothing to do with Government policy, then his argument is totally upset.
—You were asked about a value added tax.

—I was talking about the wholesale sales tax system when Senator Alston got up and took a point of order, just because at all times he is concerned to display his ignorance in public in the noisiest possible way. That is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The wholesale sales tax has some effects on transport costs and I want to say what they are. Firstly, they are comparatively small. Recent estimates are that, in effect, the wholesale sales tax system adds about 2.8 percentage points to the cost of road transport, 0.8 per cent to the cost of rail transport and 1.1 per cent to the cost of air transport. Next time the Opposition and people such as Senator O'Chee in the alleged interests of their rural constituents talk about the burden which the wholesale sales tax system imposes on the transport sector and the effects of their policies, they should admit that it is imposing a 15 per cent tax on the cost of transport.

I understand that there are all sorts of little spookies in the Opposition's document. The answer to the argument about massive benefit to the rich which is given in the Opposition's tax scales is `we are going to avoid bracket creep'. It is tucked away in the fine print. In the total economy which is presented by the Hewson document the Opposition could not avoid bracket creep in effect, just as Malcolm Fraser won an election on the promise of tax indexation and could not deliver.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President—
—Malcolm Fraser delivered it for about three months then could deliver it for no longer. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On a point of order, Mr President: before Senator Button asked that further questions be placed on notice, I asked for your attention to take a point of order. Senator Walsh's question is a very important one to the one-third of Australians who live in rural areas. I have not heard Senator Button's answer because of the rabble opposite. I ask that Senator Button be allowed to continue.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Reynolds called this side of the House a lot of rabble. I think that is unparliamentary, and she should withdraw it.
—I did not hear that comment.
—Well, I heard it.
—I heard a number of comments that I thought were unparliamentary and I tended to ignore them.
—The problem with all of this is that—
—Mr President, he asked that further questions be put on notice. So how can he continue?
—Senator Button, I thought you had finished your answer.

—I was going to say that the problem with all of this is that my request for further questions to be put on notice was not heard in the chamber because of the hubbub that was going on. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Earlier at Question Time Senator Campbell asked me a question.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President.
—It's too late.
—I clearly heard the Minister—twice—ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—In Question Time Senator Campbell asked me a question. I said I would try to provide him with some figures about the public sector share of GDP in Australia. I have not been able to get those figures for him now, but I will send them to him as soon as possible. In terms of total tax take, Australia's figure is very low.
—What's it got to do with privatisation?
—Order! Senator Short, it was not even your question.

—Poor old Senator Short. The size of the public revenue is vastly relevant to the size of the public sector we operate. If Senator Short does not understand that simple fact, he should keep his mouth shut for a while. I will give Senator Campbell the figures which he wants. It is so sad to hear Senator Short. No wonder in all those years of Liberal Government, with Senator Short in the Treasury, the economy was in total decay.

—Earlier today I was asked a question by Senator Reid relating to dead birds that had been found at Parliament House. I have a very long answer. I would like to incorporate it but I do not believe I will get the leave, so I will read it.

PARA.TAB: The Secretary to the Joint House Department has provided me with the following information. It is a fact that some dead magpies and other birds were found on the weekend, 10 in all, with a further two dead birds found on Wednesday. So as to avoid inconvenience to building users and at a time of low activity, spraying of Malathion and Pennside chemicals, mixed with water, was carried out at 5.30 a.m. last Saturday in the Parliament House courtyards. The building's air-conditioning system is shut down, all intakes and exhausts into the building are covered and the chemicals are mixed with water before spraying. Within 15 minutes of spraying the courtyard, watering systems are turned on to water the chemicals down into the soil to attack the major grass pest—the Argentine stem weevil.

Immediately the spraying occurs, insect activity takes place in the grass and thatch layers. Last Saturday morning this activity attracted a number of birds, probably because another major infestation of bogong moths occurred last Friday night. The procedure outlined above has been followed in the past without any noticeable harmful effects.

When dead birds were found later in the weekend, the Parliament House gardening staff collected the birds and sought the assistance of the ACT Parks and Conservation Service. Autopsies carried out on the birds suggest that they died as a result of eating black beetles stirred up to the surface of the grass layer by the spraying.

The Secretary to the Joint House Department is most concerned about what has happened and has directed that all steps be taken to prevent a recurrence. To this end, the Parliament House gardening section is investigating all aspects of the matter with the CSIRO, the Australian Turf Grass Research Institute and the ACT Parks and Conservation Service.

The Secretary has also pointed out that the Department has a strong record in terms of environmental protection. In fact, in the peripheral landscape zone of the building—that is, outside Parliament Drive—no spraying takes place at all and the area is left to natural controls even though at times considerable damage is caused in the area by insect pests.

Spraying does take place, however, in the grass areas of the landscape with the principal pest being the Argentine stem weevil which can destroy hectares of grass in a few weeks. However, spraying for this pest is done only on demand. That is, it is carried out only when testing shows that the weevil is becoming active. The chemicals used, malathion and pennside, are two of the registered chemicals for control of the weevil and are of a lower toxicity than a number of other chemicals that can be used. All spraying is done in accordance with the ACT Pesticides Act and the Dangerous Goods Act of the ACT. These chemicals are used throughout the Canberra environment to control the weevil.

The Joint House Department has for the last couple of months, in conjunction with expert consultants, been carrying out an environmental audit of its activities in Parliament House. That report is soon to be presented to the Department. The Secretary informs me that in a briefing from the consultants he was advised that the Department already had in place very good environmental controls. Nevertheless, this incident and anything arising from the environmental audit will be examined very closely to ensure as far as possible that Parliament House and its environs are safe, not only for humans but also for birds, animal and plant life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the statement that you have made is interesting and, in one particular respect at least, seems very different from the stories that many of us have heard about what occurred last weekend in relation to the number of birds which have been found dead. Certainly the advice that I have received is that it was considerably more than 12, but I do not challenge that as the figure you have been given.

PARA.TAB: I am told that, if 12 birds were found dead within the courtyards of this building, it is nothing compared with the number that would be found dead further away from the building as being birds that have been here and have left the area. Those that have died and have been found here are obviously those that lived in the courtyards. For that reason I find it absolutely astonishing that it is only 12, because everybody knows that far more than that have been living around the internal courtyards of this building.

Where are the rest of them? They are not there now. None of us have seen birds there this week and we are very conscious of the fact that they have gone. I am told that, depending on the substance used, it could be up to three months before its effects have gone. Any birds that do come back now risk the same thing.

The question I would like to ask is: why do they not concentrate on using more natural remedies for dealing with the Argentine beetle at the weevil stage? If the lawns were sprayed with a mixture of eucalyptus, sawdust and molasses, the weevil would come to the surface of the lawn to eat that substance and then would be devoured by the magpies which are their greatest natural predator—if the magpies were there. We should be encouraging the magpies to come into the area so that these pests would be destroyed.

The other thing is that most of us cannot see all the other predators of the weevil that have also been killed as a result of this method of treating the Argentine weevil. Other insects and creatures around the lawn would also have been killed, which we cannot see and which cannot be collected in the same way as a dead magpie. There are other remedies as well—a mixture of one part molasses to 10 parts water is one. It is not a permanent cure, but it does have an effect on the beetles.

Mr President, you have referred to a number of things. I wonder whether we can be told of the chemicals which are used around this building and whether the audit report you referred to will be tabled.

One disturbing aspect was that I am told there was a Christmas party held on the lawns near the staff cafeteria on Saturday afternoon of last week, and those who partook of that were not informed that this chemical had been sprayed on those lawns earlier the same day.

I feel that we ought to take a much greater interest in the chemicals that are used around here, especially in the courtyards. It may well be that the doors were closed and the air intakes for the air-conditioners were covered for that period of time, but do we have an assurance that that period of time is adequate for the effects of this chemical to dissipate? Why not put in feeder tables to encourage more birds so that the weevils will be eaten by them?

A lot of people are disturbed by this. The birds in the courtyard are a significant part of the building and the ecology of the area, and I think this is regrettable, to say the least. I am not for a minute suggesting that what was done was deliberate or that anybody set out to kill the birds, but it is a consequence that we should take notice of and we should look to finding other means of controlling this and other pests. One often sees spraying going on around this place and I would like to know what chemicals are being used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Continuing with the remarks by Senator Reid, I am reminded that it was in 1963, I think, when Rachel Carson wrote her book Silent Spring, a very prophetic title, when one recognises the quietness in the courtyards around Parliament House in the last few days, compared with the carolling of magpies and the calls of other birds with which we are familiar.

PARA.TAB: I am certainly distressed to learn that so long after the publication of that book—which, of course, referred specifically to organochlorin pesticides in those days—other pesticides are now being used without an adequate understanding of their more distant consequences. While I have no knowledge of the particular remedies to which Senator Reid referred, certainly there are more natural pesticides which could be used than these quite toxic pesticides—malathion, being an organo-phosphate pesticide, is an acutely toxic agent.

I simply comment also that since we have been in this place I have been impressed by the vicious and somewhat ridiculous cycle in which we pour water and fertiliser onto the lawns and, of course, make a lovely and attractive area for beetles and all sorts of other pests. Then we have other large areas of lawns that die because of the infestation of beetles and we have to spray these pesticides—or that is apparently what has been happening. Then, to repair the damage, we have to pour on more water and more fertiliser. I suspect that if we were a little more frugal with the water and the fertiliser we might have lawns that looked a little more like Australian lawns, with less infestation of pests and less need for the application of these toxic agents.

I certainly join with Senator Reid in calling for a more comprehensive reporting on just what is used. I certainly enjoin the gardeners and those who are responsible to look at far less toxic agents than agents such as malathion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I also wish to support the motion moved by Senator Reid to take note of your statement. I am disappointed that this matter needed to be raised here. It is a matter which has, of course, concerned many of us. On Tuesday the previous Chairman of the recently concluded Senate Standing Committee on Animal Welfare, Senator Brian Burns, was pleased to sign a letter which Senator Meg Lees and I had addressed to the Secretary of the Joint House Department asking for this matter to be investigated and explored further. I thank Senator Burns for his ready agreement to explore the matter.

PARA.TAB: On Wednesday morning Senator Lees and I were in receipt of a comprehensive briefing from Parliament House staff regarding this matter. I do not say that the answers we were given there are fully satisfactory, but they did follow the lines of the answers that were provided by your recently read statement, Mr President. They were also in general accord with the answers given on an ABC program earlier this morning when Parliament House staff were asked about the matter.

However, what did not satisfy me or Senator Lees at the time was that we were told of a code of practice which had been implemented in this area of the Parliament House gardens. It is manifest that the code of practice, which had been carefully thought out and obviously undertaken with all good intent and purpose, failed due to an inability, after getting rid of the immediate pest, to follow up on any unforeseen consequences. It is those consequences that were not foreseen that we are all worried about today.

I, like Senator Reid, believe that there are many other more natural possibilities which have not been sufficiently explored. I do not know so much about the mixture that Senator Reid was referring to, but I am absolutely certain that there are a number of other remedies which may or may not include the use of detergent, which is a traditional method of relieving Australian lawns of grub pests or other insects that live underground. After something like detergent, soapy water or vinegar and water is applied to the lawn, they are prevented from coming to the surface. Flood irrigation is obviously out of the question here. It may be possible to conduct these activities when bird activity is unlikely to occur, whether that be at night or in a different season. It seems to me that not enough attention has been paid to other possibilities.

I raised a similar matter not so long ago when I drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that last year at about this time the red-headed cockchafer was chased with malathion. The unforeseen consequence of that was that the worm population was found to be dead on the paths around Parliament House. Some short time after that, it was found necessary to aerate the lawns by plugging or coring them—a function which perhaps the worms would have performed at much less cost. That follows very much the sort of theme Senator Coulter was following—that our lawns are perhaps pampered to the point where it is very difficult to unpamper them. Perhaps if we followed some of Senator Reid's suggestions, we would find an easier and more economical path to look after our lawns. I support the motion moved by Senator Reid.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a brief statement about sitting arrangements for the next two weeks. A formal motion will be moved either later tonight or early next week to put down all the details. But I thought honourable senators would want to know as soon as possible what the agreement is so that they can make arrangements with their officers and otherwise.

PARA.TAB: The agreement, which has been discussed with all the parties and all the Independents, is that the days of sitting of the Senate from now on will be next week as scheduled—that is, 9, 10, 11 and 12 December—and then coming back for two days sittings concurrent with the House of Representatives on 18 and 19 December. That will give the spell between Thursday, 12 December and Wednesday, 18 December for senators away from here. It will be six sitting days: 9, 10, 11 and 12 and 18 and 19 December.

I shall move a motion about sitting and starting times and details later today or first thing next week. But that will enable people, I think, to make some proper arrangements for their officers and travel arrangements. I thank the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the Independents for their cooperation in the settlement of that sitting pattern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Government has reviewed the anti-dumping policy and administrative arrangements implemented with the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority in September 1988. At that time the Government scheduled a mid-term review of the initial five years operation of the Authority. In the March industry statement we undertook to complete this mid-term review by the end of 1991.

PARA.TAB: This statement is also a response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into Australia's anti-dumping legislation. It relates also to a recommendation in the report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's current account deficit and overseas debt. I table details of the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee report and seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [THE RESPONSE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4289]

TALK.START.PARA: —In the March statement this year we announced a number of changes to the anti-dumping system. They were intended to speed up the processing of complaints, to provide better access to the system for agricultural producers and to modify slightly the three-year sunset provision for dumping and countervailing duties. Legislative changes to implement those decisions were made in June.

PARA.TAB: Today we are announcing further changes which will make the Australian anti-dumping system one of the fastest in the world, one which recognises the need for applicants to substantiate a case, provides assistance to all parties and is fair in its judgments.

Dumping occurs when goods are exported at less than their normal value in the exporting country. Normal value is usually the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade in the exporting country. Subsidisation occurs when the government of the exporting country pays certain kinds of subsidy, bounty or other assistance on the production, freight or export of goods.

Dumping and subsidisation are condemned internationally if they cause, or threaten to cause, material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country. The internationally agreed remedy is the imposition of a dumping or countervailing duty sufficient to remove the injury to the local industry. I seek leave to have the remainder of the statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Effective anti-dumping and countervailing measures are necessary to protect Australian industry from injury caused by unfair trading practices. However in taking anti-dumping and countervailing actions there is a need to strike a balance. A balance between providing local producers with effective relief, and ensuring that relief does not unjustifiably impede trade or increase costs to Australian consumers. Anti-dumping decisions require judgements to be made involving a blend of economic and commercial considerations.

This Government has kept Australia's anti-dumping system under examination. In 1988, following a study by Professor F.H. Gruen of the Australian National University, we established an independent Anti-Dumping Authority. The Authority brings economic and commercial expertise to the assessment of material injury to an industry; and a rigorous examination of the link between the alleged dumping and the injury being felt.

Under the arrangements introduced in 1988 the Australian Customs Service has the important role of examining each complaint made and conducting preliminary investigations leading to decisions on whether provisional measures should be put in place. The results of the Customs' preliminary investigation form the basis of information from which the Anti-Dumping Authority commences its own inquiry.
For its part the Authority has the roles of:
advising the Minister as to whether or not dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed
recommending whether the Minister should revoke a dumping notice or release exporters from undertakings
reviewing, on request, negative preliminary decisions of the Comptroller General of Customs; and
providing the Minister with advice on anti-dumping issues in general.

Although the Authority is independent, its Act requires it to have regard to the Government's intention that anti-dumping duties should not be a substitute for assistance to import competing industry in Australia. Nor should they be used to shield industry from the need to adjust to changing economic conditions.

The latest review has been conducted by officers from my Department, in consultation with Customs and the Authority. The review team consulted widely with the manufacturing and agricultural sectors. It took account of the June 1991 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology Inquiry into Australia's Anti-Dumping and Countervailing Legislation, and a recommendation from the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt.

The review has found that there are many misconceptions and myths about what is dumping and subsidisation, and exactly what is caught by the Anti-Dumping legislation. Both Customs and the Authority have been asked to upgrade their public information activities to dispel some of the myths about dumping. The Government would like to take this opportunity to clear up some of the more common misconceptions.

Not all dumping is caught by the legislation. The law provides that anti-dumping action can only be taken when dumping or subsidisation causes, or threatens to cause, material injury to Australian industry producing like goods.

In September 1990, the Government gave a formal direction to the Authority on how material injury should be assessed. The Direction is consistent with the Government's policy that dumping duties should not be used as a substitute for assistance to local industry, or as protection against international competition. It provides that the Authority should only recommend duties be imposed where, because of dumping or subsidy, the injury which has occurred, or is threatened, is not immaterial, insubstantial or insignificant.

The Government did not impose a quantifiable threshold on the notion of `material' injury. Rather, it chose to provide the Authority with guidance on the circumstances in which injury may be found to be `material' and when it may not. Material injury should only rarely be taken as proven when the Australian industry producing like goods has not suffered, or is not threatened with, a material diminution of profits or when the dumped or subsidised imports do not hold (or threaten to hold) a sufficient share of the Australian market to cause or threaten material injury. During the review, some parties claimed that it is not clear how the material injury test is applied. I propose to write to the Authority and Customs suggesting that particular issues should be taken into consideration.

I believe the present state of the law does not prevent the Authority from judging the `materiality' of the injury caused by a given degree of dumping differently, depending on the current economic conditions of the Australian industry suffering the injury. The Authority should be able to find material injury when an industry has experienced a diminution in its rate of growth because of dumping. This can be just as serious to the Australian economy as the movement of an industry from growth to decline. I recognise that such a proposition should be demonstrated by facts rather than assertions that an industry would have been far more prosperous if dumping had not occurred.

Clearly circumstances can arise under which an industry is suffering material injury from any number of causes, making it necessary to make judgements about relative causation. However despite the assertion that is sometimes made, it is not the Government's policy, or the practice of either Customs or the Authority, that dumping must be the sole cause of material injury before action can be taken.

There are claims that the period for assessing anti-dumping claims can be considerably shortened. Let me examine the background. Currently, the statutory time limit is 35 days to establish a prima facie case, a further 100 days to reach a preliminary finding and a further 120 days to a final finding.

The process of determining whether the information provided by an applicant would, if substantiated, constitute a prima facie case is not something which can be done overnight. There is a considerable volume of information in an application and it all must be considered properly. In this period interested parties must be identified, a process which takes considerable time. In any event, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) requires that, where a country proposes to begin a subsidy inquiry, it should give reasonable opportunity for consultation with the exporting country. In practice, this is 20 days.

During a preliminary inquiry leading to a decision to take securities the evidence presented by an applicant about dumping, material injury and causal link must all be verified. Importers and exporters must be given an opportunity to respond to claims made by applicants. Currently, some 40 days is provided to importers and exporters to respond. Then, just as the claims of applicants are verified, the data provided by respondents is verified, usually in their place of business by Australian Customs Representatives overseas or, during time of high workload, by officers sent from Australia. Any statutory time limit short of 100 days for this process is likely to deny applicants and respondents some natural justice.
The Government does not see any basis for a less rigorous final inquiry by the Authority for which 120 days are currently allocated.

It is sometimes claimed that the system cannot deal with threats, either of dumping or of material injury due to dumping. The legislation provides that applications may be based on threats and that, where dumping has occurred, action may be taken to guard against a threat of material injury caused by dumping. Clearly it is more difficult to present facts to support the existence of a threat than to establish that something has already taken place. However the Authority has on several occasions recommended action on the basis of threats.

There is a lack of understanding of the ability of the anti-dumping system to handle cases in which dumping is confined to a specific region of Australia, and causes material injury to that part of the Australian industry located in that region, without directly affecting the rest of the Australian industry. The law allows the Authority to take account of regional injury of this kind and, in appropriate circumstances, to judge such injury to be material to the industry as a whole and recommend action.

There are conflicting views on the rigour with which Australia conducts dumping investigations and imposes anti-dumping measures. Some argue that measures are put in place too readily, others argue that the burden of proof lies too heavily upon local industry.

There are of course arguments from respectable sources that Australia would be better off if it acted only against predatory dumping. This issue is not new. It was canvassed extensively in the inquiry conducted by Professor Gruen in 1986. The Government's view has not altered. Effective anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements are necessary to protect Australian industry from injury caused by unfair trading practices; but without being an impediment to international trade. I am satisfied that the balance struck is right.
The recent review has not identified the need for a radical change to the present arrangements, but has drawn attention to the need to make some important refinements.

Mr President, the Government proposes to continue the present Customs/Anti-Dumping Authority structure for investigating claims. We will extend the operation of the Authority by a further 8 years to September 2001. In addition, the following improvements are proposed.

The maximum time for initial Customs consideration of applications will be reduced from 35 to 25 days with a consequent reduction, to 125 days (except in unusually difficult cases), in the total time allowed to reach a preliminary finding.

Customs will be given powers to take reasonable steps during the initial consideration of applications to verify claims and fill gaps in applications using confidential information which was not provided by applicants.
Customs will be given the power not to accept applications that are not properly documented.
The automatic termination provisions on anti-dumping and countervailing duties will be extended to five years and an opportunity will be provided for a review prior to automatic termination.

Provision will be made for suspension of an inquiry at the Minister's discretion upon acceptance of an undertaking, and for investigations to be re-opened if there has been a breach of a price undertaking.
The Minister will be given discretion in the apportionment of anti-dumping and countervailing duties in cases involving simultaneous dumping and subsidisation.
A new system for the imposition of anti-dumping and countervailing duties will be introduced.

Additional resources will be allocated to the Authority and to Customs to enable those organisations to cope with a greatly increased workload and expand the operations of the Customs Business Liaison Unit.
The Government proposes to introduce amendments to the legislation as soon as possible to give effect to these changes.

Some industry sectors are particularly concerned with so-called "tender dumping" which involves the loss to overseas suppliers of contracts for plant and equipment offered at allegedly dumped prices. The Minister for Small Business and Customs will exercise his powers under Section 9 of the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 and refer the question of "tender dumping" to the Authority for investigation.
I would like to outline briefly the reasons for these decisions, starting with our decision to retain the respective roles of Customs and the Authority.

The Government considers that the assessment of material injury and causal link must continue to be rigorous. An independent review process and appeal mechanism is essential to an efficient and fair anti-dumping system. Under the present system Customs undertakes preliminary investigations and the Authority reaches the final finding or, on appeal, reviews the negative Customs decision.

Alternative organisational structures, such as those in Canada and the USA which split the assessment of the dumping and material injury issues between two bodies with the Courts acting on appeals, have been considered. It was also suggested that there should be a specialist Tribunal replacing the Federal Court to hear appeals on questions of law as well as merit.

The Government is satisfied that the split of responsibilities between Customs and the Authority is appropriate for handling anti-dumping complaints. The mix of economic and commercial considerations associated with a dumping investigation, and the rigorous examination which must precede the imposition of dumping duties, have not been changed since 1988. They remain strong arguments for the maintenance of the Authority as the independent body to advise the relevant Minister on the imposition of duties.

Customs and the Authority have established close working arrangements concerning the way cases are investigated and considered. Close liaison at the beginning of an inquiry to determine the methodology of the inquiry will continue throughout the preliminary and final inquiries.

Contrary to some opinions expressed in the course of the review, the Authority's inquiry is not a duplication of the Customs preliminary inquiry. Rather, it is a rigorous assessment of the facts and issues in a case. It affords importers/exporters and local industry the confidence that advice to the Minister on the imposition of duties for a period of five years is based on a sound analysis of the facts put before both Customs and the Authority. It gives parties the opportunity to present evidence in rebuttal or confirmation of preliminary findings.

The Government considers that it is important that the Minister retains the current discretion to accept or reject the recommendations of the Authority. The creation of a specialist Tribunal body with similar expertise to Customs and the Authority to hear appeals on the merits would, we believe, increase the costs to participants. Overall the Government considers that the current organisational arrangements are cost efficient and fair to all parties.

One matter of concern raised by industry and by the Senate Committee is the time involved in initiation of complaints because of the information required by Customs and the subsequent time taken to commence an investigation. The Government believes that this concern has been addressed by the establishment by Customs of a Dumping Business Liaison Unit in March this year. This shopfront advisory service has been very effective in significantly reducing the time spent by applicants in compiling a case. The Government has decided to expand the operations of that unit.

Up to 30 per cent of applications were previously rejected by Customs, but there has been a marked improvement in the quality of applications. Nearly all now proceed to investigation. As a result the Government has decided that the maximum time allowed for Customs to reach a prima facie decision will be reduced by a further 10 days to 25 days. This means that the total statutory time limit for ACS investigations up to the point of preliminary findings (when provisional measures can be put in place) has in fact been reduced from 175 days in 1988 to 125 days (or 145 days in the case of complex applications).

Australia now has one of the fastest administrative processes for handling complaints. By comparison the time limits in the US are 160-210 days to reach a preliminary finding and in Canada, 141-186 days. The EC has no statutory time limits, but I understand it is typical for nine months to elapse between the application and a preliminary finding.

The Government considers that any further reduction in the time allowed for preliminary inquiries would jeopardise the quality of the Customs investigations and its preliminary decisions. It would impede the opportunities for importers and exporters to make submissions and respond to claims of other interested parties.

In considering an application for dumping or countervailing measures, Customs can presently only consider the information provided in the application. This is very limiting as Customs is precluded from verifying any claims made. Applications can, and have, proceeded where it was evident to Customs that a prima facie case did not exist or was doubtful. I propose that the Customs Act 1901 be amended to empower Customs to consider applications critically and to take reasonable steps to verify information, particularly where import data has been suppressed or aggregated on confidentiality grounds. The amendment will also allow Customs, during the initial consideration of an application, to use import data which is not normally available to industry. That data will remain confidential to Customs.

The Government does not believe that it should remove the onus on applicants to satisfy the Comptroller that there are reasonable grounds to conduct an inquiry. It does not consider that Customs should supplement an application with information which would normally be available to industry. To assist Customs consideration of applications it is proposed to amend the legislation to make it clear that the Comptroller of Customs may refuse to accept applications that are not properly documented.

In the last financial year, there was a 135% increase in the number of anti-dumping investigations initiated. The figure is likely to remain high this year. This has placed strains on the current resources of Customs and the Authority. As a result of these demands and changes in procedures outlined in this statement, additional financial and staffing resources will be allocated to these bodies to ensure that the quality of investigations and efficient handling of complaints is maintained.

The Government has recognised industry's dissatisfaction, expressed at the Senate hearings and during the review, about the relatively short period that anti-dumping and countervailing provisions are in place. Industry also complained that there is no provision for a review of the duties before they automatically lapse. Accordingly the Government has decided to amend the legislation to extend the sunset period from three years to five years. We will also provide for applications for continuation of the measures to be made before the expiry of the sunset period.

The current legislation with respect to undertakings is anomalous in that, where undertakings are accepted, consideration of an application is suspended indefinitely. In effect, there is no conclusion to the inquiry and no opportunity to revisit the case if undertakings are to be revoked or extended. The Government will amend the legislation to allow the suspension of a case upon the acceptance of an undertaking until such time as the Minister decides to continue consideration of it.

The Government is also aware that cases involving a combination of dumping and subsidisation have arisen which are difficult to deal with under existing legislation. It is proposed to amend the legislation to provide for the treatment of simultaneous dumping and subsidy cases and to give the Minister discretion in the apportionment of anti-dumping and countervailing duties in these cases.
A new system for the imposition and collection of anti-dumping and countervailing duties will be introduced. The duty payable will in future be calculated on the basis of :
the margin of dumping, or the amount of subsidy determined by the Minister subsequent to an inquiry or in a subsequent review; or,
a lesser margin or amount if that lesser margin or amount is determined by the Minister to be sufficient to remove the injury.

There will be an administrative review on request by interested parties twelve months after the duties are imposed. If, following the review, it is established that excess duties have been collected during the period of review, the excess will be refunded.

The Government recognises the important part which imports play in our economy and reiterates that it will not see the anti-dumping system used as de facto protection. However, we believe Australian industry will welcome the changes which this Government is now making to the anti-dumping system. The message is clear. We will not allow material injury to local industry from dumped or subsidised goods. We have backed up that statement with a system that is one of the fastest in the world, recognises the need for applicants to substantiate a case, provides appropriate assistance to all parties and is fair in its judgements.
I commend this statement to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's changes are the result of the Anti-Dumping Authority mid-term inquiry promised in the Government's 12 March statement. Before looking at the specific changes proposed, it is worth briefly considering the Government's recent record in this area and the reasons for its latest contribution.

PARA.TAB: The anti-dumping countervailing procedures were overhauled only a couple of years ago in 1988-89 following a review by Professor Fred Gruen in 1986. Among other things, he called on the Government to ensure that the then inquiry time limits of 55 days for the preliminary inquiry and another 120 days for the final inquiry be strictly enforced and adhered to. Instead, the Government proposed a three-tier inquiry process of 70 days for the prima facie hearing, 180 days for the preliminary inquiry, plus another 120 days for a final investigation by the newly created Anti-Dumping Authority.

During debate in the Senate the coalition was admonished for proposing that at least the first two hearings should be reduced to 55 days and 120 days respectively. Senator Button said that the amendment would lead to it being `much more difficult for the Australian Customs Service to reach the sorts of quality findings it has been reaching in the past'. Fortunately, the amendment was accepted in the Senate, against the Government's wishes, and soon after it became patently clear that even these time constraints were protracted.

So in March of this year the Government reduced the initial prima facie hearing from 55 days to 35 days and the preliminary inquiry period from 120 days to 100 days. The overall three-stage inquiry process now takes 255 days compared with 295 days under the 1988 legislation, with provisional anti-dumping and countervailing measures being available after 135 days—4 1/2 months.

The Government today is proposing a further marginal shortening of this timeframe to 245 days with a 10-day reduction in the prima facie hearing from 35 days to 25 days. In the coalition's view, this change, whilst in the right direction—and acknowledged as such—still does not go far enough. Our original scepticism of the Government's position a couple of years ago has been vindicated. Slowly the Government has inched towards our position and we believe it will be compelled to continue to do so.

Senator Button's comment today that `any further reduction in the time allowed for preliminary inquiries would jeopardise the quality of the Customs investigations and its preliminary decisions', which is on page 10 of the statement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), sounds familiar. He made the same response to coalition criticism about the promised 55-day, 180-day preliminary inquiry period in 1988. As we have announced in our Fightback program, the coalition now considers that the prima facie preliminary inquiry period could be shortened to 65 days in normal cases and up to 95 days in abnormal cases without affecting the quality of decisions or straining our commitments under GATT. These changes would allow provisional measures to be imposed after approximately two months.

We accept that in order to meet these stricter deadlines some changes in procedures and resourcing will have to be made. But in the coalition's view, it is essential that, if we are going to have an anti-dumping mechanism, and we believe there must be a mechanism to deal with genuine dumping, it must be effective. To be effective it must have the capacity to deliver determinations and remedies as quickly as possible. That has not been happening. That is as important for importers, who require some certainty, as it is for local producers. There is no point in imposing penalties once the local industry has closed its doors and jobs have been lost.

Today's statement proposes a number of other changes, including the extension of the existing three-year sunset on penalties to five years, which is consistent with the procedures now being adopted by GATT and by member countries to the GATT proposals, with the opportunity for applications for continuation of the measures to be made before expiry of the sunset period.

This change was recommended after the recent Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry into anti-dumping, and was announced as part of the coalition's policy in the Fightback package, released several weeks ago. The Government's decision to pick up this change is welcome because it picks up and endorses the Committee's report and also the coalition's policy direction. The five-year limit brings Australia into line with overseas practice and will give Australian producers some added certainty without making penalties open-ended.

Other major changes proposed include additional financial and staffing resources for both Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority. That is essential. However, it should not require additional Budget allocations, given reduced complexity of industry protection, et cetera, which will presumably reduce the workload of Customs in other areas and indeed the workload of DITAC.

There will be an expansion of the Customs shopfront advisory service. This was recommended by the Senate report. It makes sense to expand advisory and screening services. This will not only help local industry to know where it stands and what its obligations are; it will also facilitate faster inquiry procedures. There will be a granting of greater powers to Customs to access confidential information. This was recommended by the Senate Committee as a means of balancing rights and obligations of the parties in the screening phase of the inquiry.

Other changes to which the Minister has referred include a new system for imposition of anti-dumping and countervailing duties and provision for the suspension of an inquiry at the Minister's discretion, upon acceptance of an undertaking. Provision for Customs not to accept applications that are not properly documented will be fully considered by the coalition when the legislation becomes available, as will the Government's proposal to extend operation of the Anti-Dumping Authority for a further eight years. Overall, however, these changes suggest that at least the Government, belatedly, is moving in the right direction.

The fact that we need yet more changes to the anti-dumping countervailing arrangements, just three years after major legislative overhaul and some nine months after changes outlined in the 12 March industry statement, indicates that the Government initially got it wrong. It has now been forced to accept, at least to a degree, the direction proposed by the Senate inquiry and the coalition. Of course, it was the coalition which initiated that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to be modest about it; it was I.

—Senator Boswell wants me to ensure that his role in that Senate inquiry is acknowledged, which I gladly do. Dumping policy will always be a vexed issue because there are competing interests, but there is no need for so much indecision about the mechanism itself. Essentially, it must be fair and fast so that both importers and local producers know the rules and act accordingly. Continually changing the rules has merely added to their uncertainty.

PARA.TAB: If there is one thing industry needs in this country at the moment it is some predictability and certainty about actions for the future. In this context, the statement's clarification of some applications of the dumping laws, for example in relation to regional dumping, the threat of dumping and definition of material injury and causation of that injury, is welcome and should help to allay concerns and misunderstandings in the business community. But given the Government's track record, no doubt industry will reserve judgment until the new system is in place and the improvements are tangible and seen to be delivered.

In general summary, the coalition shares the Government's view that we must have an anti-dumping countervailing system in place and that that system must be balanced and fair. Importantly, it must not become a back-door opening for industry protection. That would patently work against the coalition's commitment for negligible assistance by the year 2000, which is a vital element of our blueprint for building a world competitive industry sector in Australia. However, where dumping or subsidisation is taking place, there must be an effective mechanism in place, and we believe our proposals will deliver this more effectively than those proposed by the Government.

There can be no doubt that the concern from industry about anti-dumping arrangements is a product of the Government's failed industry policy. It has done only the easy side of the reform ledger to date. It has reduced protection, but not much else, which has caused difficulties and major problems for industry in this country. It has failed to deliver on micro-economic reform, industrial relations reform, or taxation reform and reductions. Hence industries' costs are being squeezed and competition tightened. It is not surprising that in these circumstances more and more industries have sought assistance from dumping remedies.

The coalition's Fightback program will remove at least $20 billion of business taxes as well as implement comprehensive structural changes and reduce the size of government. That package will give industry an unprecedented opportunity to reduce costs and improve productivity and match and beat fierce international competition. We need to ensure that we put industry in this country on a more equitable footing than it has experienced in recent times.

I also make the point that I speak as a senator from South Australia, which has suffered greatly in the past few years from dumping. The Riverland, unfortunately one of the State's highest areas of unemployment, has just had the huge blow of the closure of a tomato cannery, with the loss of some 100 jobs.

Senator OLSEN—Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about the effects of dumping, particularly in the Riverland of South Australia, where a cannery recently closed with a loss of some 100 jobs. The reason for that was the dumping of tomatoes. These people have absolutely no hope of finding alternative employment anywhere in South Australia, and they know it.

Earlier I spoke about the region which has one of the highest unemployment levels anywhere in South Australia. That cannery, which successfully supplied the Australian hospitality industry with canned tomatoes, can no longer compete with canned tomatoes dumped from Italy, Portugal, Thailand and eastern Europe. Some 46 per cent of canned tomatoes now sold in Australia are dumped. South Australia bore much of the brunt of the dumped orange juice concentrate from South America, and particularly from Brazil. Now we have to contend with dumped peaches and pears.

While this report indicates that the Government is belatedly willing to move part-way in the right direction to deal with the problem—I certainly acknowledge that—there is a massive human element to the dumping problem which this report does not allude to. Dumping eradicates Australian jobs as surely as the Hawke Government's recession that we had to have has done. This has occurred in the factories, the farms and across Australia.

This statement, despite its points of worth, is a very clinical document. It makes no attempt to assess and deal with recent industry comment that eradicating dumping could well reduce Australia's unemployment rate by as much as one-third. Even taking into consideration that this may be an industry exaggeration brought about by deep concern, the Minister's statement is remiss in that it pays no attention to such claims, either to mollify the accusers or to give them credibility.

At last count, the industry in the Riverland believed that dumping had cost well over 1,500 jobs in that one tiny pocket of South Australia, not to mention the added human cost of failed businesses. When multiplied across Australia, this is no small problem.

As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology which investigated the anti-dumping crisis in Australia, I conclude by saying that I am overall most disappointed with the Minister's statement. I have given recognition to its good points but I have to ask why this Government has always had to be led almost screaming to deal with the issue and why it resists delivering all that is necessary when it is necessary and not months and years too late. I would like to know why it consistently turns its back on the worst element of anti-dumping, unemployment. For every product that is dumped in Australia there are Australian companies and individuals having to cut back or halt their production in the face of a marketplace which naturally will choose the cheaper products.

Today's statement does not indicate Government determination to eradicate this industry and social problem. I acknowledge that the Government is at least moving in the right direction, albeit belatedly. However, it needs to take greater account of the human cost of dumping in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement and I certainly welcome Senator Olsen's remarks. He served on the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology with me and made a very significant contribution. He certainly understands the problems of rural South Australia, as can be seen from the way he enunciated them a few minutes ago.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the Australian anti-dumping system. I note that the statement is a response to a mid-term review of the five-year operation of the Anti-Dumping Authority as well as a response to the report of the Committee which was published in June this year.

The Senate Committee inquiry was established after I had received many complaints from industry suffering from the massive subsidy programs of our overseas trading competitors. I brought the problem to the Senate and moved a motion to refer this matter to the Senate Committee.

We are faced with a situation of massive subsidies, leading to world overproduction, the flooding of world markets and world prices being pushed down below the cost of production both here and in the subsidising countries.For those countries supported by subsidies, unrealistic world prices do not matter as they are protected by their domestic price. But in Australia, where the industry has no assistance to back up its continued survival, the low world prices which have become the domestic price have devastated many of our rural industries and have cost thousands of jobs in the horticulture, wheat and sugar industries. They are all innocent victims of world subsidies gone mad.

Industry knows that anti-dumping is not the solution. This Government should know it too, particularly with no corresponding tax and micro-economic reforms. Many actions over many years costing hundreds of thousands of dollars have been launched. Meanwhile, imports have flooded into Australia. The tomato growing industry has lost 40 per cent of its market to subsidised imports, the canned peaches and pears industry has lost 40 per cent and the pineapple industry has lost 25 per cent of its domestic market. All processors are suffering. It does not matter whether it is peaches, pears, apricots or beans—they are all subsidised.

Growers are forced to meet the competing lower prices of the import below production costs. But no industry can survive for long on that basis. Some processors, reeling from massive debt levels, have stated that they will no longer source some products from Australia. Pacific Dunlop, the new owner of Edgell-Birds Eye, has stated that there are some products that it should not buy in Australia. It has nominated those products as tomatoes, potatoes, asparagus and corn.

While appreciating that commercial decisions have to be made, we have reached the ridiculous situation in Australia where our efficient farmers cannot even get their products canned here because the Government has allowed the situation to develop where subsidised imports replace our own. This is another loss inflicted on Australian farmers because of subsidised competition.

World subsidies gone mad have led to efficient Australian farmers and processors being run out of business because of totally unfair trading practices. Subsidies and guaranteed domestic prices protect and encourage our overseas competitors. The EC tomato industry is paid a subsidy of $425 a tonne. These same cheap subsidised EC products flood into Australia, reducing our growers' price—in the case of tomatoes, to $109 per tonne. The Italians and other members of the EC get $425 a tonne for their tomatoes.

The United States does not accept this. It instead imposes a 100 per cent tariff on EC tomatoes. America is not stupid—it knows that anti-dumping just does not work. But the US probably cares about its farmers more than this Government cares about ours. The situation is the same with most horticultural products.

The Minister in his ministerial statement proposes some changes to the present system. A prima facie case by Customs will now take place in only 25 days—a 10-day reduction from 35 days. This will reduce the time before duties can be imposed to 125 days—rather than 135 days—with a further 120 days for the final finding by the Anti-Dumping Authority. But this is still an all-up time of 245 days.

Senator Bell, the Australian Democrats senator from Tasmania, says that this will not stop imports from coming in. I must in fact agree with him. Industries told the Senate inquiry that this all must take place within 55 days to be meaningful. A lot of product can be dumped in 245 days.

Customs will now be able to supply confidential import information for the application form—a recommendation of the Senate inquiry and a very good one. The onus of proof for grounds for an inquiry still stays with the applicant. I am pleased that the Government has picked up the Senate recommendation to extend duties for five years with a review prior to termination—another very good recommendation—rather than the present ridiculous situation where the duties are removed after three years and injury has to occur all over again before another expensive, long action can be brought to prove duties should go on again, at a cost of sometimes hundreds of thousands of dollars.

The Minister also deals with the material injury test—the present test is based on a formal direction given by the Government to the Authority in 1990—that sets out guidance on circumstances when material injury may be found. The Minister has stated that he proposes to write to the Authority and Customs suggesting what particular issues should be taken into consideration. I tell the Minister that the formula has not worked in the past, with only three successful cases last year. Relying on anti-dumping will not work, not when we are up against the rest of the world subsidising by $385 billion a year. The Government has given away every bargaining chip that we have ever had in the pack.

Dr Blewett has volunteered everything on behalf of our farmers. We have bent over backwards to be the whitest knight in the free trade tournament. We have got nothing back in return. I accept that we are locked into the Uruguay Round. We put so much into it and we must stay the distance for the next three months. But we do not have to deceive ourselves that our anti-dumping laws will defend Australian industry against an avalanche of subsidised and dumped imports. To use anti-dumping to stop subsidised imports coming into Australia is like trying to stop a bulldozer with a flyswat. The world must split its sides laughing when it sees Dr Blewett giving away more and more and no-one does the same.

Countries such as the United States put conditions on abolishing their protection, as with their beef quotas. The United States says that only if the Uruguay Round is successful will it reduce quotas. At the same time, we have given everything away. We have nothing left to give away and we have received nothing back.

Australia becomes a further victim in its best export market when the United States cuts the beef quota this year using its protection measures. At times of rock bottom returns, anti-dumping actions have cost Australian industry massive amounts to fight against unfair trading competition.

Let us take the case against imported peaches and pears from Spain and Greece. The case has so far taken 19 months. A final decision will not be made until January. The case has already cost the fruit growing industry in Australia $190,000, at a time of very depressed markets. In the first hearing Customs found dumping and subsidies existed, profit losses of 59 per cent for peaches and 38 per cent for pears, and job losses in the industry—yet no causal link was found. The case then had to be appealed to the Anti-Dumping Authority. The Minister's statement does not deal at all with the stumbling block of causal link between the dumping or subsidy and the injury. How can we bring an anti-dumping action when our industries are forced to sell at a low world price which is, in fact, a dumped price?

Let me refer to the sugar industry. I would like the Australian Democrats to listen to this. The sugar industry presently has to accept the corrupt world price of $230 per tonne, below the cost of production in Australia. This is all in a world scene where sugar exporters subsidise their producers. The United States subsidises its producers to 23c per pound, when the corrupt world price is 7.5c per pound. Thailand has a domestic price of $447 a tonne and the EC a domestic price of $551 per tonne. The Australian producer is forced to take a world corrupt price of $230 a tonne—8c a pound—which is lower than the cost of production.

If world price sugar is imported to Australia, how can we challenge it when we are forced to sell our product at a dumped world price—under the cost of production—to meet world corrupt markets? That is a question that Senator Button has to answer. But it is not only the producer who is a loser; all Australians lose.
The Minister's statement points out that we will have one of the fairest anti-dumping

SPEECH.PARA: systems in the world. It makes one wonder whether Australia is the only country that has a GATT rule book. Maybe Dr Blewett could take a few photostat copies and send the rules to other countries, because it seems that Australia is the only country that is playing by the GATT rules. We do not want to be the only country playing by those rules. If it is fair for us to do it, it should be fair for every other country. No other country keeps to the strict letter of the law of the GATT rules as we do—and it has cost us plenty.

PARA.TAB: I, with farmers and industry, am pleased that the Government picked up the terms of reference of the Senate committee and introduced the three changes in the March industry statement; that is, shortening the time period from 295 days to 255 days, extending actions to farmers, and applying duties for a full three years. These further changes announced today should help, but the Government cannot kid itself about our anti-dumping laws. It must be realistic; blind faith is not enough.

Australian industries are being wounded by subsidised imports. Australian farmers have reached a crisis point through having to accept world prices corrupted by subsidies way below the real cost of production. The Government's changes will improve the anti-dumping system; but, no matter how many patches and bandages the system is given, it will never hold back the flood of unfairly traded imports. No-one likes tariffs, but the Government's system of relying totally on anti-dumping will not work. The option is a variable levy that catches subsidies on imports.

The world protection level has risen by 48 per cent over the last 10 years, creating annual subsidies of $385 billion and distorting world trade and world prices. The Government must realise that this is what our farmers and processors are competing against. It cannot afford to keep its head in the sand any longer. It cannot keep reducing tariffs on our agricultural products—to zero by 1996—when the rest of the world is increasing subsidies by 48 per cent and Australia has reduced tariff levels by 60 per cent. That is just burying our head in the sand up to our shoulders. A crisis point has been reached that anti-dumping laws can only dint but not attack. We must stand up for our farmers and processors. We cannot stand by and let everything they have built up in the agricultural sector over the history of Australia go down the drain.

I welcome this ministerial statement. It goes some way to helping the farmers, but it puts a total reliance on anti-dumping. That is just not realistic, and I have explained why in my speech. I will go along with it for three months but, if the Uruguay Round fails, Australia definitely has to come up with some fall back position. If Australia does not, we will not have a rural industry left, we will not have a horticultural industry left, and we will not have a dairying industry left—but we will have a lot more people unemployed. So let us see what the Uruguay Round brings. But if it does not bring some meaningful cuts in protection and subsidies, let us be realistic and not bury our heads in the sand. Let us find some sort of fall back position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the statement made by Senator Button, pitiful though it is. It is a case of `a little bit is better than nothing at all'. His statement shows that the Government, ever so belatedly but, nevertheless, importantly, is doing something about anti-dumping measures. I wish Senator Button had stolen a little more of the Fightback package and taken our proposals for anti-dumping, the proposals enunciated by Dr Hewson, which will substantially ease Australian manufacturers' ability to bring anti-dumping actions, should it become necessary.

PARA.TAB: The Government has pinched the abolition of the coal export levy from our Fightback package, as it will no doubt take more of our package. I congratulate it for that; I just wish it would take the lot. Senator Ray understands what a great package it is. I know he would like to implement the lot of it. I think he was one of those who supported the consumption tax back in 1985. It is just a pity that he, Senator Button and Mr Keating, the now discredited former Treasurer, did not have the courage of their convictions back in 1985 and did not introduce the package that we are proposing. I invite the Government not just to steal some of the package but to steal the lot. However, I wish it had looked a little more at our proposals on the anti-dumping reform.

Dumping is a very complex matter which I do not even pretend to understand fully. In travelling in my electorate of Queensland in recent months, I was favoured by being able to look through the sodium cyanide plant constructed by ICI at Yarwun, near Gladstone —a very exciting project, a plant that was built using the latest technology and all Australian materials, sources and resources to produce high grade sodium cyanide. ICI entered into this field because, in the past, overseas companies brought in most of the commodity. I do not want to be held to these figures, because I am not sure of their accuracy, but something like $2,200 a tonne was being charged for sodium cyanide which was being imported to Australia by Dupont from America, by I.G. Farben, I think, from Germany, and by companies from several other overseas countries.

ICI built this plant, which is an exceptionally good plant. Its work force is working very happily under a section 115 agreement. That agreement is not as good as the enterprise bargaining agreements we propose for the work force, but it is as good as this Government will ever do, it is working well and it is a very efficient plant. ICI started producing the commodity at about $1,600 a tonne, I think—quite substantially undercutting the imported product and still making a good profit. Lo and behold, not long after that, the overseas competitors suddenly found it within their power to sell the product at less than $1,600 a tonne—from memory, something like $1,400 a tonne. They were charging the lesser rate to put the Australian industry out of business.

A very expensive anti-dumping action was mounted which required a lot of overseas investigation to get particulars of the costs and the prices at which the product was being sold overseas as compared with what it was being sold for here. The action was taken to Customs, which agreed, over a lengthy period of time—as it is able to do these days—that there was a prima facie case.

The action then went before the Anti-Dumping Authority and, again—I understand from the people involved—a very expensive proceeding ensued. The Anti-Dumping Authority then determined that the product was being dumped in Australia, from all sources. It decided to impose anti-dumping duties on the European and Asian importers, as I understand, but not on the biggest importer, Dupont. I believe that the reason for this was that Dupont said that if it had done it before it was sorry and it was not going to do it again.

All of that action was taken and no anti-dumping duties were imposed. That means that we rely on the word of an international giant not to compete unfairly with the Australian industry. There is no worry about fair competition, but the dumping of Dupont's product was found to be unfair. It guaranteed it would not do it in the future, but there is no bond taken, no penalties taken, in the event it breaks its word. There is just no back-up for this type of thing. We rely on the company's good word after it has already tried to put the Australian industry out of action.

It seems to me to be absolutely ridiculous that that sort of thing should be allowed to happen. If it does happen again the Australian-managed company which runs the plant at Gladstone will have to go through all that all over again. It will have to start its investigations, take its action and prove its case before it can get any relief. That seems to be quite a ridiculous situation and I had hoped that Senator Button's statement would have addressed that type of thing a little more.

I agree with the comments of the previous speaker, Senator Boswell, regarding the sugar industry. Head to head, the Australian sugar industry will compete with any sugar industry around the world. I do not care whether it is a country which has cheap labour or even slave labour; it will not produce a tonne of sugar cheaper than the Australian industry will. So there is no fear within Australia of any imported sugar competing against the home-grown product, because the Australian industry is the most efficient. It will produce the cheapest and best sugar going.

But imported sugar is coming into Australia. It is only in small quantities at the moment, but it is coming from countries which have a heavily subsidised sugar industry and a heavily subsidised means of production. I also suspect that it is being sold here cheaper than the cost of that heavily subsidised production in the country of origin. That is fairly well understood; I do not think there is any argument about it. But getting around to proving it—actually getting the evidence and following the trail of sugar and sugar commodities as they move around the world to the markets, brokers and international selling rooms—is a very difficult and expensive process. It is very time consuming, and the Australian sugar industry really does not have the money or the expertise to follow it.

That throws up a very big problem for the Australian sugar industry. It has to decide whether to just let this sugar come into Australia unchallenged or whether to set aside the hundreds of thousands of dollars that would be necessary in order to mount an anti-dumping action. It then has to wait for this enormous amount of time before it can do something about it and even then it cannot be guaranteed—particularly under this Government—that the results will be enforced when it gets there. They are some problems which should be looked at very closely.

As I understand it, Australian exporters are also having a lot of trouble with their operations. Under this Government, the wholesale sales tax adds, according to Senator Button's departmental advisers, some 5 per cent to their cost of export. As I commenced by saying, if the Government or Senator Ray were prepared to adopt some of the proposals we have suggested in the Fightback package—he can have them; it will not be stealing; we will give them to him—then we would not have that sort of impost on exporters. If the Government were to adopt our form of GST, then the wholesale sales tax would be wiped completely and no GST would be imposed; it would be zero-rated for GST. Our exporters would then be able to compete on a par with their overseas competitors.

That is very important to a town like Mount Isa, which is located in the area where I come from. It exports a lot of goods. The cutting of the wholesale sales tax on the things that the townspeople import, and in fact on all of the things that they use in their production process, would mean an enormous boost to the mining operation and to the community. Talking about Mount Isa and the Fightback package leads me to another matter which I want to raise briefly. It is a very sad day for Australian democracy when a Federal parliamentarian attempts to intimidate, or goes ahead and intimidates, the people of Queensland because they are attempting to have a say about a political matter. It has recently been brought to my notice that the ALP member for Kennedy, Mr Rob Hulls, attempted to intimidate someone in Mount Isa who wanted to take part in the GST debate, who wanted to raise this issue—

PARA.TAB: This mailbox happens to be in this gentleman's office. Someone in authority then wrote to the head office of this businessman and said, `Do you know your premises are being used for political purposes?'. What does that suggest to you, Madam Acting Deputy President? Does that suggest that this businessman, who runs his own business on franchise, is being intimidated by someone threatening to report his actions to the head office of the franchisor in Sydney or Melbourne so that he will not use his office as a collection place? Does that seem to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to be the sort of thing one would allow if there were to be free, open and democratic discussion about anti-dumping, about the GST and about the Fightback package? It suggests to me that there are people in Mount Isa, there are parliamentarians in Mount Isa, who are doing their damnedest to intimidate people from letting this package be known, from letting our proposals on anti-dumping—

—I will certainly not mention any parliamentarian from that area. However, I will say that the type of action that is taken to prevent our Party promoting our anti-dumping proposals is the sort of thing that was happening in Germany in the 1930s: people who had political points to make—in the same way as people who have a proposal to make on anti-dumping or a proposal to make on the GST—were prevented from raising them or were intimidated against raising, distributing or publicising those points. People wanting to promote their own party, to take part in the political process, led to the holocaust in Nazi Germany. PARA.TAB: I would fight to the death to support members of the Labor Party being members of that Party, and raising every issue they ever wanted to raise to promote that Party. I would fight to the death to make sure they can do that, but I ask people in the Labor Party to do the same for our people. If our people have a political point to make, then they should be free to make it without fear, without favour, without threat and without intimidation.

That is all I say. I am not going to mention any politicians in Mount Isa. I can only say to Senator Ray that if he is sensitive about it and the cap fits he might just have to wear it. I do not think it is you. I do not think you come from Mount Isa—I do not think you come from Queensland—but, if the caps fits you, you wear it. I am not going to say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will. I have mentioned a couple of aspects of anti-dumping which concern me, including the Yarwun plant at Gladstone, sugar and exports. This is all mentioned in the Fightback package, one of the greatest economic proposals put before this country for a long time.
