I repeat that I am grateful that Senator Button and his tired, worn out Government have at last done something towards fixing up the anti-dumping rules—little though it is—but a little bit is better than nothing.
—Which you never did in government. You did nothing about it. Eight years of Fraser—nothing done.

—Except for Senator Ray. I wish I could say to him that a little bit is better than nothing. Maybe if I said that a big bit is better than nothing it would be right. It is a pity that we cannot get a big bit of our proposal in as the anti-dumping statement, but it is still better than nothing. I urge Senator Button to look very closely at Dr Hewson's proposals for the anti-dumping measures. I invite the Government to take further steps along the path that it has started on to get the anti-dumping proposals in Australia in a much better way than they have been in many years past.

—I am glad to see Senator Ray, the only Minister at the table and one of three Government senators in the chamber, taking an interest in anti-dumping. I did not think that down around Melbourne people would have taken much notice of it, but presumably this ministerial statement, which the Minister has taken an interest in, is the only thing that will help stop the Government getting dumped in the next election.

PARA.TAB: The period is being reduced from 35 days to 25 days. At present we have a limit of 35 days to establish a prima facie case; a further 100 days to reach a preliminary finding; and then 120 days to reach a final finding. That is a total of 255 days. Under the new situation the first prima facie case will be down from 35 days to 25 days; there will be a further 100 days for the preliminary finding; and the final one does not say so, but I presume it is still 120 days. The Minister at the table might be able to tell me whether I am right or wrong on that. That still gives a total of 245 days, which, of course, is far longer than the Hewson package.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the Hewson package comparable with what is allowable in GATT?

—I am coming to that. The Hewson idea is to get down to a total of 125 days. I know that we have GATT and GATT is working on it. If Senator Ray listens, he might find out some of the problems of the rural industries in Australia, which he takes very little interest in. Senator Macdonald certainly told the Minister plenty about that but he was too busy arguing with him.
—Sleazy tactics need some confrontation.

—Okay. If we can get down to that it will be a vast improvement on what we have had to date. I welcome the present cut but it is nowhere near enough. The present situation with a maximum of 245 days is okay for the bigger, stronger, widespread year-round sort of industry, but it is the small seasonal industries that are very much reliant on the weather which the anti-dumping measures need to protect. Those industries mainly lie in the horticultural section where there is one small crop all over Australia which may be harvested in a matter of three to four weeks or even less. Where a dumper comes in from Argentina, Brazil, Chile or any of those South American countries—Spain has also been mentioned—that industry can be wrecked in a matter of a few weeks.

PARA.TAB: The anti-dumping measures should have a bond on them. A company should sign a bond to say that it will not kill off the industry. If the industry is killed off, and there is a penalty, that bond could then be distributed down the line to the industry. There is no such measure. A small industry can be wrecked in three or four weeks.

What happens then? The next year the growers in that small industry have been driven out of business and they are not there to provide the crop; they have gone. One of two things can happen. The following year the dumping company—from Argentina or anywhere like that—may not have the production to dump in Australia; it will go somewhere else. It might have to satisfy its home market or the market next door. The company will not be able to provide the goods. The prices in that small industry in Australia will go through the roof. For example, the price of strawberries could multiply three times because our anti-dumping regulations do not allow a quick action to be brought on to keep that industry going. I believe in competition. I am in the agricultural industry. We have a lot of competition. I do not mind competition, but I believe in fair competition. Even though the Government has gone a small way towards cutting down dumping, it has not gone far enough.

For only the second time in living memory Australia will be importing wheat. As I said earlier, I do not mind competition, but we should compete on a level playing field. I am sick and tired of hearing about a `level playing field', but I suppose I will use the phrase until we coin another one. When subsidised wheat comes into Australia to make up for what we have not grown, the injury is greater still. I do not mind competition, but that is what happens.

The killing off of these industries will reflect on the balance of payments. We have to watch for that in Australia. If we cannot do anything further to put this situation right, we have to make sure that the agricultural producers, manufacturers and so on are able to compete internationally. This is covered in the Hewson package. We can do that by cutting the cost at the base: the manufacturing cost, the growing cost and so on. The Hewson package will remove all taxes on exports to the tune of $1.7 billion, which will give us a chance to compete internationally and get this country moving again. In short, I welcome the small measure which is to be introduced on anti-dumping, but it does not go far enough. For many industries, it will be too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the statement of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the review of Australia's anti-dumping system. I have had a chance to look at the statement only very superficially. Dumping legislation has been an interest of mine for some years. It is an extraordinarily complex subject; there is no simple approach to it. Dumping is an essential subject. There is almost nothing that is made in this world of which a few more thousand units cannot be made at very little extra cost of production. They can then literally be dumped on a market in another country just to clear them. Of course, that could be done either for simple gain or to completely destroy an industry which is dependent on limited runs, particularly if enough product is put into a country with a small population, such as Australia.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the point that it is an extraordinarily complex field to get into. It is very easy to claim outrageously that a product is coming in here and being dumped. The definition of dumping, quite simply, is a product sold in another country for a price that is less than its normal sale price in the country of origin. It is often very difficult to prove that. If I have a criticism that I can encapsulate in a few words about Australian anti-dumping legislation, it is that it is eminently far too fair. It really does give the benefit to the importers, as opposed to Australian industry. If there is doubt about dumping, I would certainly give the benefit of the doubt to the local company rather than the importers.

I would like to move briefly through the Minister's statement. The first point that the Minister makes on the top of page 4 is that not all dumping is caught by legislation. That is perfectly true. Countervailing duties and their legislative base is only one of the devices that can be used to protect home production in a country. In Australia we tend to operate closely with that as our means of controlling imports, whereas other countries use a lot of quite absurd and covert means of stopping importation.

I was in Malaysia once when it was the Chinese New Year. The Chinese like oranges for the New Year. There is no embargo on oranges coming into Malaysia. Some Chinese merchant bought a whole heap of oranges in Singapore, loaded them on semi-trailers and drove across the causeway. Then he found that it took him six days or 12 days, in a tropical climate, to clear his paperwork. There was nothing wrong; it just took a little while to understand the paperwork. Of course, the oranges had to be dumped and the New Year passed. That might be a humorous example—if one is not the Chinese merchant involved—but it is the way a lot of the trade around the world is done. What is on paper, what is open and in full public view, is not necessarily the only impediment to trade. We can pretty fairly make the case in Australia that we do try to put our legislation, our tariffs and our dumping procedures in full view and rely on those and nothing else.

In the next paragraph of the statement the Minister makes the claim that damage to industry is not immaterial, insubstantial or insignificant. That is putting it in lawyers' definitions. The real world is a little different. In the next paragraph he talks about proposing to write to the Authority and Customs, suggesting that particular issues should be taken into consideration. That is a bit of a weak response.

The Minister then goes on to make the claim that it is only necessary to show that there has been a decline in growth of an industry; we do not have to show, within the classical definition, that there has been a loss of market share within the country. If production which was increasing has decreased a bit, that may prove the case. That is an interesting interpretation. It may be possible to put that interpretation on the current legislation, but I would not advise anyone to spend much time trying to prove it, because the counterclaim would be made quite readily that we have an industry downturn. It is the industry downturn that is causing the problem, not competition from overseas.

One of the most vexed points is the period of inquiry. We have a current statutory limit of 35 days for a prima facie case, 100 days to reach a preliminary finding and a further 120 days, which comes to about 255 days. That has been reduced by about 10 days so that 35 comes down to 25. It is a very long time. Most of a year has gone before we can prove a case. An awful lot of product can come into a country in that time and destroy a market, particularly where margins are tight, as at present, and companies cannot operate on low margins for very long. The Minister defends this when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Any statutory time limit short of 100 days for this process—
talking about the preliminary finding case—
is likely to deny applicants and respondents some natural justice.
I just wish the Minister would extend the same sort of natural justice to the Opposition that he seems to extend to importers.

PARA.TAB: The rest of the report goes on with very fine sentiments, but a lot of it turns on this underlying belief in fairness. I make no apology for the fact that I think, if there is fairness involved, the benefit of that fairness has to go to our local producers, not to people overseas. We bend over backwards to be able to defend impeccably in any court any action we take. In the process we let a lot of product come into this country that would not get past similar barriers in another country.

Senator Panizza was talking about primary production and the importation of wheat. There is a great deal of concern in the community about the fact that we now import somewhere near $2.2 billion worth of foodstuffs a year. I would certainly like to see that stopped because there is nothing that we import that we cannot produce here. We can certainly live without the few lines like caviar and the rest of it for a few years until we get our balance of payments position right. If we could cut back $2.2 billion a year we would go pretty close to saving two months of balance of payments deficit. It really is quite a considerable and a very attractive goal to pursue.

But as I said in this chamber last Thursday, while I think the Australian producers are very good, the marketing of Australian foodstuffs and the packaging and the promotion of them are often not up to world standard. That is certainly not true in all cases, but the test that I apply is to go round the supermarkets of the world and look at the shelves and see how much Australian product is on them. I can tell honourable senators that, if they go around the Asian and European capitals, they will find very little Australian produced foodstuffs on the shelves, whereas pretty well most of the other countries will be represented. The simple conclusion that we must draw from that is that the Australian product, while it might be of high quality, is simply not packed in a modern and attractive way, and it certainly is not promoted.

With those few words, I accept the report. I do not think it really goes far enough. I would like to see it taken a bit further. I would like to see a bit more steel put into it, but it is an improvement on what we had before.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everyone has about had their say, so as duty Minister I would like to thank everyone for their contributions tonight. Senator MacGibbon quite fairly says that it is a very complex area. It is one where we are always competing between the question of fairness and the question of protecting local industry. There is nothing that will rile people, the consumers, more than seeing Australian products and Australian goods undercut, totally unfairly, and destroyed, because, whilst in the short term they benefit by dumping, in the long term they pay the price. That has happened quite often.

PARA.TAB: I have to respond to a couple of points. Senator Panizza says that I personally have no interest in rural affairs. That is very hurtful. I hope he is watching on television right now. That is a very hurtful statement. I take a great interest in rural affairs, and the absolutely infamous senatorial tours around rural Victoria of a few years ago are testimony to that.

We also have some problems in this area with GATT—as I think most fair people in the chamber would acknowledge—of trying continually to free up trade and to allow for some rational reform. Senator MacGibbon and many other people have seen other methods that can be used to stop the import of goods. One can insist that certain goods land in the middle of the country and then put one official on the gate who lets one car through a day or something. These are the sorts of practices that we are trying to expunge from the international scene long term. But if we get up to it ourselves we will lose all credibility. There is a line, however, that has to be drawn to make sure that we do protect people.

I note for the record that in about 1982 I remember looking at anti-dumping and the record of the Fraser Government. It was nowhere near as good as this Government's record, nor was it on tariff reform or anything else.

Senator Macdonald got a bit excited about the Fightback package, so I will not go into that much. He said there was a great anti-dumping section in it. I just ask how many extra public servants will be employed under that, seeing the Opposition is going to sack about 20 per cent of the Public Service in the three years of its first government. You cannot have your cake and eat it too. But that is not surprising. I do not expect trained lawyers to understand economics. I find that lawyers usually make the worst possible treasurers or economists, because they enjoy more the use of words than reality out there.

I am sad that the standard of Queensland representation from the Liberal Party has dropped off in recent years. The average has certainly collapsed with the election of Senator Macdonald to this chamber. If Senator Macdonald wants to come into this chamber with his junior woodchuck sleaze, he will impress me more if he will then walk straight out the door, down the steps and out into the open and say the same thing. Then I will know that he has great strength of character, that he has moral convictions and that he believes in what he says. The difference between saying it in here in his sleazy attack today and walking out of the chamber and saying it is that he might get sued. That is the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think the word `sleazy' is quite appropriate. I think Senator Macdonald spoke his words very forcefully, but I ask the Minister to withdraw the word `sleazy'.

—I withdraw that word unreservedly. Any time I am asked to withdraw anything in this chamber I do, because I would hate to give offence. But I say this: Senator Macdonald came in to speak on a ministerial statement that is directed towards anti-dumping, with the intention of the character assassination of another member of parliament. He drew the tenuous link between a couple of words in the Fightback package and an attack on another member who could not defend himself. I do not know how to describe that tactic.

PARA.TAB: Is it unprincipled, I ask myself? Is it sleazy? Well, I cannot say that. Is it a gutless sort of act to do it in here but not outside the chamber? I am pondering these things philosophically, wondering whether I would be in breach of the Standing Orders if I were actually going to essay them in this particular debate. No doubt I will have to have a sleepless night, weighing up in my own mind whether Senator Macdonald, through his inexperience and his legal training, has come in here on a character assassination attempt, or is merely naively being seduced by some dark side of the Queensland Liberal Party force into this sort of character assassination.

We do believe in the jury system—almost, in Queensland—and I will let the jury sleep on that. Everyone can make their own determination about the value of Senator Macdonald's speech here tonight. I do not rate it too highly. If individuals want to smash into a political opponent, I would much prefer that they do so during the adjournment debate—do it directly, and not indirectly try to sneak it in to a ministerial statement on anti-dumping. What Senator Macdonald was doing tonight was dumping. It is a pity the provisions of this particular statement, of anti-dumping, did not rule him out.

We all get excited about dumping because it is a terribly irritating thing. The processes that currently exist irritate everyone. I am not sure there is a much better alternative around. I am pleased to see that Senator Button's statement today again foreshortens the time that has frustrated many people. I am sure this is just one of the many reforms we will see in anti-dumping legislation and procedures in this country.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will bring a few matters in this report to the attention of the Senate. The 1990-91 financial year saw a significant increase in R & D expenditure by the Corporation from just over $2m in 1989-90 to $5.2m. I commend the Corporation on that because R & D is a very important part of any of our industries. Some 239 projects in a broad spectrum of horticultural crops and production regions received financial support.

PARA.TAB: Voluntary levies still comprise the main source of industry funding. However, the proportion is declining from 86 per cent in 1989-90 to 74 per cent in 1990-91 in favour of statutory levies which are more equitable and provide a sounder basis for planning and implementation of agreed ongoing programs.

The decision to impose statutory levies is most commendable and shows a responsible attitude by the industry. I think the HRDC is to be commended for deliberately adopting a `lean ship' policy during its establishment phase because of the uncertainties as to the level of funding that would be received.

Some of the research that the Corporation has undertaken is a step in the right direction. Among the highlights of the R&D program is work in the apple and pear area with a complementary disease resistant program at the Granite Belt Horticultural Research Station, which is now concentrating on producing apple scab and powdery mildew resistant seedlings. This is a step in the right direction. A unique project at Batlow dealing with apple pest management on a whole district basis is aimed at minimising pesticide use.

An instance of pesticide use was talked about in the Senate this afternoon. I notice that a lot of magpies were back around Parliament House tonight. I think this is a great thing. We do not want to jump to too many conclusions too quickly. Chemicals are good if they are used correctly. Sometimes they do not always work as well as they should. But I want to make the point that the horticultural industry is looking for alternatives to the use of chemicals. I know that you, Mr Deputy President, did a good job on the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, on which we both served.
Supervised pest control is being used with populations of all major pests and the incidence of major disease is monitored by pest management scouts. I think that is a great thing for the industry.

The use of predators to control pests was mentioned today when we were talking about the spraying of the grass around Parliament House. The point should be made that birds can eat only a certain amount of pests—they cannot eat every pest. The horticultural industry is doing something about this problem. A wide range of beneficial agents has been found since monitoring began. Spiders and ants have emerged as two major groups of predators in banana plantations. Predators can do a great deal of good at the same time as allowing industry to reduce its use of chemicals.

A CSIRO study in the Shepparton/Cobram area of Victoria is examining soil structure decline under irrigated fruit trees and its influence on fruit yield. This is most important. Based on observations of the wetting-up pattern of the surface soil, good structure seems to be associated with the solid fraction being just wetted by capillarity, but not saturated.

I mentioned in this place the other day that it is very important that we in Australia make sure that we produce pure foods. If we can keep our foods in Australia pure, we will be the supplier for the rest of the world. We are an island nation and if we keep things right we will be at the forefront of horticulture and agriculture in future years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Act 1991, on behalf of the President I present the following report: Joint review by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance—Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme—Review of estimated savings from proposed system for eligibility checking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise today with very mixed feelings. I am disappointed, disgusted and disillusioned by the comments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in this chamber today when he said that the Senate was a useless institution. I find that very difficult to accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Relatively.

—The Minister should look at the Hansard tomorrow. I wonder why the Foreign Minister stays here when he thinks that the Senate is a useless institution. My emotions are mixed because today there has been a victory for the Senate. Today the black box is dead.

PARA.TAB: In the last session the Government brought legislation into this chamber which had been brewing away for some time. In fact, Dr Blewett proposed a system whereby pharmacists would be required to use a compulsory transmission system, a computer system, to check the eligibility of Australian citizens for pharmaceutical benefits. Because of the concerns that were expressed by the Privacy Commissioner during the election campaign, or about that time, Minister Blewett withdrew the suggestion. But, as many of these things are inclined to do, after the election when the public has been hoodwinked by the Labor Government, back comes the insidious black box proposal.

The legislation came before this chamber and was sent off to be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration because the coalition had very grave doubts about the estimates of the savings that would be made, the figures that were being used in those estimates, and the justification that was being given for those estimates. The legislation went off to the Committee and, after that, we were even more concerned about the fact that people were going to give up an enormous amount of liberty and privacy for what were likely to be very small savings.

The Government told us that if we did not do what it said there would be enormous problems. I remember that night well. It was very late. The Government used standover tactics to the effect that if the legislation was not brought in there would be a disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson has just said that some staff were told what would happen and how my name would be smeared across the nation amongst all pharmacists if we stopped this legislation going through. Despite that, we moved an amendment to the Bill that required an investigation of those estimates. Section (2)(6)(c) of the Act states:

PARA.TAB: (c) the day after a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General has reported to both Houses of Parliament that the estimated savings contained in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 are realistic estimates and that equivalent savings could not be obtained through the use of alternative eligibility checking systems which are no more intrusive than the eligibility checking proposals contained in the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Act 1991;

SPEECH.PARA: There is the protection that the Senate placed on that legislation. We needed to be shown and we needed the Government to justify that those estimates on which that proposal was based were appropriate, adequate and right.

PARA.TAB: Today we have before us that report, for which we have all been waiting. It makes very interesting reading. The original estimates for gross savings were: 1991-92, $12m; 1992-93, $34m; 1993-94, $40m; and 1994-95, $40m. The original estimates for net savings were: 1991-92, minus $0.7m; 1992-93, $19.2m; 1993-94, $26.3m; and 1994-95, $25.8m. The Auditor-General's department shows a range of figures for the revised estimates of gross savings. It includes minimum and maximum figures and it gives the assumptions on which these figures are based. Its figures for the gross savings are: 1991-92, minimum $9.1m, maximum $13.6m; 1992-93, $9.7m, maximum $14.5m; 1993-94, minimum $10.7m, maximum $16.1m; 1994-95, minimum $12m, maximum $18m. The net savings figures from the department are: 1991-92, a minimum of minus $3.6m and a maximum of $0.9m; 1992-93, a minimum of minus $5.1m and a maximum of minus $0.3m; 1993-94, a minimum of minus $3m and a maximum of $2.4m; and 1994-95, a minimum of minus $2.2m and a maximum of $3.8m.

If this were introduced, the maximum loss of net savings would be $13.9m and the maximum gain would be $6.8m—a far cry from the figures we were given before. Why were these estimates so wrong? Anyone reading Mr Staples's scurrilous and appallingly inaccurate press release would think it was all the Auditor-General's fault; that it was the Auditor-General who gave him the wrong figures and that is why it was wrong. This has to be one of the worst press releases I have ever seen—it is so wrong.

So the Auditor-General's department is blamed. When the department first estimated the ongoing savings, it used three figures: the incidence of ineligible claims against the PBS—people who get a PBS benefit when they are not entitled to it; the number of items processed; and the average value of the claims. The department told us that the incidence of ineligible claims was 4.5 per cent. That was sort of a rough guesstimate. It had a figure of 5.22 per cent that the Audit Office had given after it had investigated people getting benefits when they should not have been. The department admits that it made a sampling error in that. In addition, the Health Insurance Commission had given us an estimate of 3.5 per cent. To estimate the savings it did a rough in-between figure of 4.5 per cent, arrived at by applying a 10 per cent tolerance level to an error rate of 5 per cent and taking the lower of the two figures. It was like thinking of a number between 5.22 and 3.5, dividing it in half, adding on a few, taking some away and ending up with a number. So we started with 4.5 per cent. Both figures were based on inaccurate information.

The next basis for the estimate was the number of items processed. This has changed because of some government initiatives. Although it may not have been possible to predict exactly, that was not costed in; changes as a result of that budgetary initiative were not taken into account. I suppose that can be excused.

The next one is totally inexcusable. Mr Staples has the audacity to say, `If any of our figures are wrong, let them address their own problems first'. But this was a very simple problem—an error that I cannot believe the Department made. It was trying to estimate the average benefit per item that was given to a person who was a social security benefit recipient who received a pharmaceutical benefit. It estimated that it would be $12.50 for each person. But it made an extraordinary error. It forgot that all of us get a benefit for drugs which cost more than $15. In the averaging calculations, it had included the average drugs that a beneficiary received and their price—not the $15. So, when that was fixed up, the estimate of average benefit was $7.93—a basic error in estimating the average cost of the drugs that a beneficiary gets. It just forgot.

Does Minister Staples say that in his press release? No. He blames the Auditor-General's department. Where does the buck stop? It stops with the Minister. And why did the Minister not ask the questions about these estimates? If I had been the Minister, I would have said to the Department or the Health Insurance Commission, `Have you doubled checked these? Have you triple checked these? Who else could give us advice?'. A junior in the department should have picked up that error; it is appalling.

Our privacy and freedom are going to be restricted—as they have been restricted today already in the Bill that has just been through the Senate earlier—on the basis of that sort of calculation, that sort of estimate. It is absolutely atrocious. With all due respect, and to give Senator Tate his due, he said in the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: As to the exact order of these,—
this is as to the level of savings—
you would need to have a look at them in a more sophisticated way than simply saying `$40m'.

He was dead right. We need to look at them in a more sophisticated way—sophisticated to the extent that we get the figures right in the beginning; that the averages of how much beneficiaries are receiving that they should not be receiving are calculated on an accurate basis. I suggest to Senate Tate that it is not so much a question of being more sophisticated, but of being accurate. He went on to say:
I think that is what this Committee has done.
Well, we did not do it. I said in my speech on this Bill that I was concerned that we would not have the opportunity. I said:
Unfortunately for us, but maybe fortunately for the Government, it will probably be impossible to check the accuracy of the Government's savings estimates.

That is because we do not have the resources to do that. But, thank heavens, we have a process and, thank heavens, on that occasion—although not today—the Democrats supported us to put this clause in the Bill to stop this going ahead, if it was demonstrated that the Government could not produce the estimates.

PARA.TAB: I remind all honourable senators that what was involved was that when every single one of us went into the pharmacy to get a scrip we would have to get checked to make sure that we were eligible. This was to be done because we wanted to discover whether there were immigrants and visitors who were getting benefits that they should not have been getting. That is why everyone was being checked. I asked the Department, `How have you assessed the number of immigrants and visitors who are not eligible for pharmaceutical benefits and who are receiving them?', and I asked, `How did you guesstimate that figure?'. Mr Hazell said:

SPEECH.PARA: We assessed that figure at about 200,000 . . . We then assumed that these people would have half the utilisation of drugs as other persons.

So the Department estimated that the 200,000 people a year who are visitors and immigrants would utilise half the quantity of drugs as other persons.What rubbish! My mother is an American citizen. She comes from overseas. She does not come and get drugs here. She brings them with her, as many others would. We know that there are some people who cheat the system. But most visitors would bring their own drugs, unless they get sick here.

PARA.TAB: During the hearings of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Mr Hazell from the Department was asked, `How did you guesstimate half?'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There was really no base upon which it was done, Senator. We had to assume some level of utilisation rate. We felt that the full rate was certainly not appropriate, and that half was probably a more appropriate figure to work on. But, as there is no data concerning the use by foreign nationals, it required some assumption.

We have assumptions directly out of the heads of those in the Department. We have figures where they chose to go halfway between the Auditor-General's figure and the Department's figure. We have figures on how much it costs on average for each person who is on benefits to get a scrip, the basis for which was wrong. That is how this Government came to a decision that all citizens in Australia would have to have their card checked when they went into a pharmacy before they would be issued with a scrip. That was the basis of the Government's decision.

PARA.TAB: Yet the Government has the hide to go looking into our estimates and our budget for our Fightback package. It ought to be looking in its own backyard to make sure that its estimates are right and are based upon the correct figures.

In his press release, the Minister blames the Auditor; he says it was the Auditor-General's fault. I think I have demonstrated fairly well that the Auditor-General did give a figure for the number of people who were receiving benefits when they were not eligible, but that was done in the context of an examination of the ways in which the Department could make savings. It was beholden upon the Department to examine the basis of that figure and to look at its own. When that was done, and the Auditor-General did that with a sample of 3,700, or whatever the figure is in the report—a very adequate sample was used—and looked at the number of people who were likely to be receiving benefits when they were not eligible for them, he came up with a range of 2 to 3 per cent. The Auditor-General said there was a 95 per cent confidence level that the actual error rate was in that range of 2 to 3 per cent—nothing like the 4.5 per cent guesstimate that the Health Insurance Commission had been using in its estimates.

Minister Staples makes some comment in his press release about how the withdrawal of the black box proposal would affect the coalition's policy in relation to retail pharmacists acting as agents for Medicare. He said that one of the things we have not done is consult the Privacy Commissioner. That caused me to laugh because we find—as I think I mentioned earlier—that, when Dr Blewett was proposing this, he was forced to abort the scheme when the Privacy Commissioner registered his significant concerns about the possible ramifications of such a system. The Privacy Commissioner also expressed his concern when it came into the chamber when we were investigating it on the last occasion, because he had not been adequately consulted. So we will not let Mr Staples tell us that we will not consult the Privacy Commissioner when, in fact, the Privacy Commissioner was not consulted properly when this proposal was put forward.

The Auditor-General's report is an indictment of the Minister, the Health Insurance Commission and the Department of Finance in that they accepted these estimates unquestioningly. To an extent, it is also a criticism of the Audit Office itself in its original estimate of the number of people who were receiving benefits when they were not eligible to receive them; the ANAO admits that. But that is a minor problem when compared with the errors and the sloppiness of the others I have named. But those people are not listed in this appalling and scurrilous press release that the Minister has put out.
It is, I suppose, very sad that people in the Auditor-General's Office have to put up with that sort of blame when the blame really lies in the lap of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis).

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that this process has demonstrated the important role that the Senate can play in reviewing and scrutinising legislation and also in calling the Government to account. This is about the interests of every single Australian resident, every single person, who goes into a pharmacist to obtain a pharmaceutical benefit. That includes people who get benefits at a lower rate, politicians and business people. I doubt whether there is anybody who chooses to pay the full rate because they do not want anybody to know. So every single Australian resident will be affected by this legislation.

This chamber and the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration have worked together to ensure that the interests of the Australian people have been met and that their privacy has been protected. This Government has been shown as the fraud that it is, in that it cannot get the figures right even when simply estimating the average cost of a benefit to a person on social security. The Government got it so wrong. It is a great lesson for us all that we should not take financial estimates at their base value. We should always question policy issues, and especially policy issues which affect the rights and freedoms of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Patterson has made a very thorough speech on this report of the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. As Senator Patterson has stated, this joint review was carried out following concerns expressed in the Parliament regarding the estimates of savings contained in the financial impact statement on the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991. Concerns were expressed about the privacy aspects of the proposed new methods of checking.

PARA.TAB: I was a member of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs that looked into the Bill. We were very concerned about the figures that the Government put forward in its financial impact statement on that legislation. We said time and again that the figures were totally inaccurate. We even put forward options that the Government should follow to correct its estimates. The Committee went into it very thoroughly, and it was as a result of the persistence of the Opposition, and our Committee, that it was finally decided that a review must be undertaken.

I will not go into the detail since Senator Patterson has already done that. To do so will just waste the time of the Senate. But let me make it very clear that the Government's estimates of the net savings in the year 1991-92 were minus $0.7m; in 1992-93, the savings were meant to be $19.2m; in 1993-94, $26.3m; and in 1994-95, $25.8m. That is what the Government said it would save, and that was the excuse used for the black box being introduced into all pharmacies around Australia for pharmaceutical benefits. The Government said there would be no capital cost because all the boxes would be leased; it would be all right.

After the Auditor-General reviewed the figures, as requested by us, a range—a minimum and maximum—was given for each of those years. The minimum for 1991-92 was not minus $0.7m but minus $3.6m; as a maximum it was $0.9m. For 1992-93 the minimum was not $19.2m but minus $5.1m with a maximum of minus $0.3m—a loss, not a saving of $19.2m. For the year 1993-94 the Government claimed $26.3m. The Auditor-General's minimum was minus $3m and the maximum was $2.4m, not $26.3m. For 1994-95 the Government estimated a $25.8m saving. The Auditor-General's minimum was minus $2.2m with a maximum of $3.8m. And the Government says it can find holes in the Fightback! document!

If this is the standard of work done by the office of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and his Department, is it any wonder that Mr Howe said on television the other night that, yes, he had made a dreadful mistake when he was criticising the Fightback package; the Department had given him the wrong figures? The Department has given the Senate and the lower House of the Parliament the wrong figures once again. The figures were so wrong that the Government has been forced to withdraw the legislation altogether. It will not put forward the black box any more. It has withdrawn the whole idea because, if it did not, it would be running at a loss.

We had the wonderful media release put out by Mr Peter Staples. Just like Mr Howe, he did not take the blame. The buck never stops with the Ministers in this Government. Whom did he blame? The Auditor-General. Mr Howe did not blame his office; he blamed the Department. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) does not blame himself or his Department; he blames the Auditor-General.

What is wrong with this Government that it will never accept responsibility? It is never a Minister's fault; responsibility is always shoved off to the departments. I do not think that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator McMullan, can possibly expect the Government to get loyalty from the departments while Ministers continually blame them and try a whitewash of their own responsibility. In his press release Mr Staples said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the decision not to proceed with the computer system was based on revised estimates indicating potential savings were not as great as first forecast.

Not as great! There will be a loss. The legislation has not been withdrawn because of perhaps a $1m or $2m estimate being incorrectly perceived; it has been withdrawn because the estimates would result in a possible loss, if just a few hundred thousand dollars. The press statement also said:
During the Senate hearings, representatives of the Auditor-General stated that the 5.22 per cent figure was, in fact, conservative.

PARA.TAB: That was the figure for prescriptions that were wrongly claimed. The Minister is blaming the Auditor-General. But it was not just the number of prescriptions that was incorrectly claimed. The Auditor-General was asked by the Opposition to look at other matters, including the incidence of ineligible claims against the PBS, the number of items processed and the average value of items claimed. After each one of those matters were looked at, this report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This resulted in a significant overstatement of the value of ineligible claims. . . .the total error rate reduced from 9.27 per cent to 5.6 per cent and from 5.22 per cent to 2.06 per cent for lapsed entitlements.

It goes on and tells us that the estimated 72 million pensioners really was not 72 million pensioners, it was more like 67.7 million—a vast difference.As Senator Patterson has also made very clear, the difference with the $12.5 as an average was really only $7.93.

PARA.TAB: The whole thing is a shambles. The Government goes ahead with legislation such as this without doing proper financial statements. They are so inaccurate that we can pick it up at a glance. We have not had the opportunity or the facilities to do the numbers, but in our Committee, as Senator Patterson said, they were so wrong that we knew at a glance. The pharmacists knew at a glance that the figures were totally wrong. That was why we asked the Auditor-General to go over them and to come up with what the figures were more likely to be.

It is a dreadful indictment of the Minister. It is a dreadful indictment that the Minister cares to blame the Auditor-General's Office; that he is not prepared to accept the responsibility; and that he will not abide by the Westminster system of government which says very clearly on every occasion that the buck stops with the Minister.

This is so common in this Government. Senator Patterson will remember last Friday's meeting with the PRA—the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. We asked then, `What happened?'. I asked the senior departmental officer before me at that meeting, `Why did you allow legislation to go through that did not supply a form of appeal for the pharmacists when they felt that an injustice had occurred? Why is it that you allowed the Department to put through that legislation?'. He said, `It wasn't our intention'. I said, `Where does the buck stop?'. He said,`The buck stops with the draftsmen'. Does Senator Patterson remember that?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—I said, `The draftsmen? Doesn't the Department look at the legislation?'.
—What does the Minister do?

—I also asked, `Doesn't the Minister look at the legislation?'. The officer said, `You can blame us, Senator, if that is what you want, but the draftsmen were given instructions and they didn't carry them out properly'.
—It is a wonder they don't blame the truck driver who brings the papers here.

—Is it any wonder? I am pointing out that passing the buck is rife in the Government—the Minister does not take the blame, he blames the Department; the Department does not take the blame, it blames the draftsman; who on earth can the draftsman blame? Honourable senators would know the old saying—you go home angry, you bawl out the kids, and the kids kick the dog. That is what this Labor Government abides by. The buck is passed further and further.
—It is like the butter for the royal slice of bread.

—That is a very good analogy, Senator Patterson. The draftsmen have no loyalty to the Department; the Department has no loyalty to the Minister. The Minister must realise that he cannot blame his underlings and that the buck stops with him.

PARA.TAB: This media release from the Minister is a cowardly way to withdraw his legislation. I have never read a more cowardly news release in my life. The Minister says that he will now be withdrawing the black box and that that will make a heck of a difference—he does not know how the Opposition will cope with that in the Fightback program. Minister Staples put through legislation which was going to be a drain on the Government's purse. He had to withdraw it. He says, `Ha, ha! Now that I have withdrawn that, how are you going to cope with the Fightback program?'. I cannot believe the idiocy of that statement. The Minister claimed that the Opposition cannot now fulfil its promise to allow pharmacists to be able to act as agents for Medicare. It was the most cowardly news release that I have ever read from any Minister.

I am very concerned about the Government's lack of responsibility, blaming of departments and blaming of underlings. It is so rife that the Westminster system, under which every department and Minister is meant to abide, is non-existent so far as this Government is concerned. Senator Patterson has put out a news release. I love the heading—`The Black Box is Dead'. It never really had a chance of being alive because, at a glance, we knew that the figures were wrong. I believe that this is a lesson for the Opposition—we should never take for granted a financial statement that this Government puts down.

In, I think, the Sun-Herald the other day there was a picture of Mr Kerin and Mr Howe. The headline said, `The Laurel and Hardy act that let their team down'. I think we need Mr Staples to enter the act. It is not a hole in the Opposition, but it is a mighty hole in the Government's figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing my remarks on the report of the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, I believe it is important that I declare an interest in this topic, an interest generated by my wife's professional vocation as a locum salaried pharmacist. In doing so, I wish to take this opportunity to thank her for her encouragement in ensuring that this Parliament received a more satisfactory outcome than the Government was initially seeking when this matter was first put before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: From my wife's practical work involvement, she was very aware that the claims that were made appeared to be extravagant. She was also concerned about the public relations problems—particularly those affecting the patients—and problems that arose as a result of the Government not keeping up its information base as it should, and the consequence and detrimental effect that this would have upon the patients.

It is important that the Government—indeed, it is a lesson for all Ministers and all government departments—be much more cautious in the future before presenting shonky figures to this Parliament. I feel confident that under similar circumstances the Senate would again refer such issues for further examination by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that, following a Senate initiated inquiry by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance, the Government's proposal to establish a highly intrusive computer transmission link between pharmacies, the Department of Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission has been scrapped. The figures were shonky. The report revealed that the potential savings were substantially less than the original figures.

We must indicate that the Senate amendment which initiated this inquiry forced a delay in the introduction of this computer system until such time as the real savings in such a process had been established. The report tabled today has vindicated that amendment. Fortunately, the Minister has taken note and scrapped this transmission system with the result that what has become known as the black box is now dead.

It is important that we realise that the Senate debated the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill. This is where the problems were first detected. At the time I recall accusing the Government of not having adequately considered the alternative methods of preventing unauthorised claims on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I am pleased that the joint report has addressed some of these other alternatives.

We also drew attention to some of the inadequate internal auditing procedures that are used by the Department and the Health Insurance Commission. Following those concerns raised during the Committee hearings and within this Parliament, an amendment to the (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill called upon the Government to see that the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance produced a report. This report is the one we have today. Again, it is a vindication of the request that was initiated by the Senate. It highlights the important role of having a House of review, a second opinion and a second opportunity to get out into the community to assess the real problems and to inquire of the pharmacists and of the patients what is really in their best interests and the best way that money can be saved.

I would also like to take this opportunity of acknowledging the role at the time of Senator Tate. Following that debate, he acknowledged that there were some problems with some of the estimates that were put before him at the time. I thank him because he was honest enough to admit that some of the savings, to use his words, were not exactly or precisely known. I believe that even Senator Tate would be rather pleased with the results of that inquiry. The inquiry results in a significant reduction in the original estimates of the savings.

I must emphasise that the error was essentially a departmental one. The mistakes that the Auditor-General's report have revealed reflect very poorly on the Department. Some of them were very elementary errors. They did not recognise certain features. For example, age pensioners tended to have a higher degree of responsibility and honesty than other sections of the population.

The gross savings from introducing that highly intrusive checking system were estimated at $40m, less an amount of $15m for the ongoing lease of computer equipment. There were even suggestions that we should delay the matter for a year or two, but that delay would have resulted in an up-front cost for leasing this computer equipment. I believe it has been a successful result for the Parliament, for the taxpayers and for pharmacists, but above all for the clients of pharmacies.

So I must emphasise that the inquiry which was conducted jointly by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance to validate the estimated savings significantly reduced those estimates downwards. This would mean gross savings of only between $12m to $18m annually and the cost of supporting the system naturally made it not a viable proposition. So it is not surprising that Minister Staples scrapped the proposal.

This is a relatively short report. I think it is a very good exercise and perhaps the Senate should be using the offices of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General more frequently to substantiate certain Government estimates and claims.

We also notice that the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has been very quick to gloss over this large gap in the estimated savings versus the actual. Instead he has chosen to concentrate on what this finding might mean for the Opposition's Fightback program. I think his press release was in poor taste. It does not address the original concerns. We are indeed pleased that he has scrapped the system, but the manner in which he addressed the question, the manner in which he threw allegations and the manner in which he blamed other people did not reflect all that highly on a Minister whom the community should respect. The Australian public would have been better served if instead the Minister had concentrated on how the Government was going to realise $10m to $18m worth of savings which this report has identified.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance into the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is a victory not just for the structure of the Senate; it is a particular victory for my colleagues Senator Patterson and Senator Walters because they pursued this matter at a time when it was not fashionable. Today we see in the Auditor-General's report the magnitude of the error. The magnitude of the error was not in hundreds of thousands of dollars or even in millions. It was as far as $26m out in the estimates for the year 1993-94, when the Auditor-General reported, in contradistinction to the Department's estimate, that in that period there would be, at the minimum estimate, a loss of $3m and, at the most, a gain of $2.4m. So this was a major error. It cannot be glossed over.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon we saw Minister Tate caught quite flat-footed. He had not even seen his own Minister's press release. He had not read the Auditor-General's report. Then, when asked a question by Senator Patterson about this matter, he went on a diatribe about the coalition's health policy, talking about fee structures, which had nothing to do with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It brought home to me the stark contrast between the Government's approach to things and our approach: the contrast between a Government that believed in black boxes and more controls, more government intervention and intrusion into privacy considerations, and the coalition's approach of freedom of choice and assistance to individuals through self-reliance.

It was a victory for the coalition. If I may draw the analogy with the black box, it was just another nail in the coffin of the Government. Not only is the Government nailing itself into the coffin, but the wheels are falling off the hearse as well. It has been demonstrated today with the attempt to control freedom of speech, and then this evening we have had the debate on the way in which this whole structure has been mismanaged, which was brought to light by the Auditor-General's report. I commend my colleagues for their approach. I also commend the Auditor-General for bringing to light the incredible errors made by the Government in handling this matter.

Of course, the coalition health policy is not affected by this minor change in relation to the black boxes. It is far more detailed than that. In addition to the provision of pharmaceutical benefits concession cards to people aged 65 and over who are not currently in receipt of any government concessions, we will retain Medicare and significantly improve it. It will remain a system of universal health cover.

We will restore the balance between the public and private sectors by encouraging individuals to provide for their own health care by taking out private health insurance. Higher income earners who do not take out private health insurance and who occupy public beds will be encouraged to take out private health insurance by being penalised with a higher levy if their income is over $50,000 per annum for married couples or $40,000 per annum for singles. It will not stop the funds acting as agents for Medicare and it will not stop the additional medical cover that can be provided by gap insurance. So the Minister's statement about the deletion of the black box is but a very minor matter in the overall approach of the coalition to its health policy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 16 of 1991-92—Accountability off the Rails; National Rail Corporation Limited—Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be brief because I know that a number of my colleagues want to speak to this report. There is no doubt that this tired Labor Government not only has brought this country to its knees but also is accident prone. Is there no end to the mismanagement of the Australian economy by the Labor Government?

PARA.TAB: One of its recent planks of reform which was supported by the coalition, particularly the honourable member for Wannon, Mr Hawker, and the honourable member for Farrer, Mr Tim Fischer, was to improve the rail system in this country. Before it has even got off the ground, before the Bill has even come into the Senate, it is fatally flawed. This is probably the most extraordinary report I have seen in the six or seven years that I have been in this place. The Auditor-General points out that his report is unprecedented in that it has the agreement and support of the six Auditors-General of the parties involved.

Let me explain briefly what this matter is about. This might save my colleagues having to go through it again and allow them to speak on the broader issues. The National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill seeks to merge Australian National with the other State rail systems so that they can be integrated between the capital cities. The Commonwealth will contribute equity of $296m of taxpayers' money out of a total of $415m over five years and the States will make up the balance.

The agreement, according to the Auditor-General, raises the fundamental issue of public accountability. There are two flaws to the way in which the Bill has been presented. Under the corporations law the Corporation will be a strictly commercial operation at arm's length from the Government. There are no problems with that. But what has happened is that, even before legislation has come before the Parliament of Australia, a private auditor has been chosen and the Australian National Audit Office was not even consulted.

When a similar issue came up some months ago in respect of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Wool Corporation, Senator Collins berated senators on this side of the chamber for suggesting that we would oppose a private audit. He argued, `After all, were you not the party that believed in contracting out and privatisation?'. He is quite correct. But as the Auditor-General points out, there is a massive gap between corporatisation and privatisation. When we have corporatisation, the money is being put in by the taxpayers of this country. For that reason, this matter deserves to come under the scrutiny of the Auditor-General.

In particular, the Auditor-General points out that, under the legislation as proposed, there is no legislative requirement whatsoever for the Corporation to report to the parliaments of the Commonwealth or the States, notwithstanding the massive $415m of taxpayers' money being put into the Corporation by both the Commonwealth and the States. In one of his conclusions, the Auditor-General says:

It seems extraordinary, given the results of similar attempts in some other administrations, that a company, wholly owned and funded by the Commonwealth and State taxpayers, can be established and avoid accountability mechanisms (including the appointment of an Auditor-General) which are properly designed to protect the interests of Ministers, the Parliament and taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned previously, there was no consultation at all with the Australian National Audit Office in respect of the auditing arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General goes as far as to request of the Parliament, of honourable senators and of members of the House of Representatives, that we amend the Bill to require the Corporation to report annually to the Commonwealth Parliament and to provide for the Auditor-General to be the sole auditor. I would have thought that this did not even have to be said. There is no doubt that the setting up of this organisation is a move in the right direction in respect of micro-economic reform. But the legislation is found to be wanting in that the Corporation does not even have to report to the Parliament which represents the taxpayers of this country.

I mentioned that I would be brief because a number of my colleagues want to speak and because we will be rising in 20 minutes. I think the position was properly spelt out in an editorial in today's Herald-Sun, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The once great Australian Labor Party is now politically, financially and morally bankrupt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I note that other senators also wish to speak on this matter. We are discussing the Auditor-General's report on the accountability of the National Rail Corporation which, incidentally, is at least nine months behind because of the bumbling attempts of this Government to bring the States together.

PARA.TAB: We know roughly what this proposal entails. We know that the Corporation was to start operating last July.The Auditor-General and the State Auditors-General have all voiced their concern that audits will not be carried out by the Australian National Audit Office but will be handled by a standard auditor appointed under the Companies Act.

As the NRC is wholly owned and funded by the Federal Government, I believe that the Auditor-General should do the auditing on behalf of not only the States but all the taxpayers involved. First up, over the next five years a total of $415m will be put into this project. It is a worthwhile project because central rail has been run down through inefficiencies and will need to be put back on track again. The Commonwealth's share alone is $296m, which is not small bikkies. The Auditor-General stated:

The Agreement provides for the Commonwealth and the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia to contribute equity totalling $415 million over five years. The Commonwealth share is $296 million. The balance of the $1.5 billion in paid-up capital comes from the transfer of assets into the Corporation from the Commonwealth and State Railways.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not only looking at $415m, we are looking at what has been put into it in rolling stock, track and whatever. The Auditor-General continued:

It is extraordinary, given the results of similar attempts in some other administrations, that this company should be able to avoid accountability mechanisms (including appointment of an Auditor-General) which are properly designed to protect the interests of Ministers, the Parliament and the taxpayers.

The taxpayers are the most important. With that in mind, I believe that the Auditor-General's concerns should be relayed to the Government so that it can fix up something that has weathered by design or by negligence. We are not in a position to say. This is a commercial situation. We have to have an Auditor-General. The final underwriters of this undertaking are the Australian taxpayers. We have seen in other places—especially in Western Australia and WA Inc. deals—what has happened to the taxpayer when proper auditing is not in place. I commend what the Auditor-General has said to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I know that Senators Watson and Chapman want to raise some issues. I will deal with one specific point. It relates to what the Auditor-General regards as some issues which are fundamental to public accountability; that is, the question that has been touched on about there being no legislative requirement for the National Rail Corporation to report to the Parliament of the Commonwealth or the States—that is, the taxpayers' representatives—despite the fact that it is entirely publicly funded.

PARA.TAB: The specific matters of the National Rail Corporation Ltd will be raised next week because the Government has this legislation listed, as I understand it, for next Tuesday. I hope the matter will be dealt with at length in that legislation. The problem is that we have here an uneasy halfway house between governmental operation of activities and privatisation. This corporatisation, which Senator Parer said will lead us in the right direction, quite frankly is a disaster position. It is the worst of all worlds. I have mentioned this quite often in this place. I have spoken about government operations that have been corporatised without being privatised. What happens when they are corporatised is exactly what the Auditor-General has pointed out here—they are removed from the scrutiny that this chamber has, particularly in Senate Estimates committees, which quite frankly they must be subjected to. We have seen this in other areas and in other administrations. State governments, particularly Labor State governments, around Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —WA Inc.
—WA Inc. But we can also look at banking in South Australia and at Victoria's banking disasters and other disasters in its government-owned operations. As the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems extraordinary, given the results of similar attempts in some other administrations, that a company, wholly owned and funded by the Commonwealth and State taxpayers, can be established and avoid accountability mechanisms (including the appointment of an Auditor-General) which are properly designed to protect the interests of Ministers, the Parliament and taxpayers. There was no consultation with the ANAO in respect of the auditing arrangements.

I do not want to go into that. Senator Watson will deal with that matter. My concern is with the disastrous consequences of exactly what the Government is going to proceed to do now. The Auditors-General of other States—New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia—agree with and support what the Auditor-General is saying in this report. The Auditor-General makes this conclusion:
Those implementing commercialisation (short of complete privatisation) must recognise the fact—
and I underline the word `must', because this Government has not recognised it yet, having seen the disasters that its Labor colleagues in other States have brought upon themselves—

that commercially operating units are still part of government. They are underwritten by the taxpayer or given power by citizens. Ultimate responsibility has to be accepted by the Government whatever attempts it might make to create arms-length operations. Corporatisation should not be used to weaken public accountability, nor to cloud the responsibility Ministers have for public sector activities.

I stress that, because this chamber received a letter from various Ministers of the Government—and I think Mr Beazley was the most gross offender—telling us that in Senate Estimates hearings we were not entitled to ask questions about or make any examination of those government corporations which did not depend on an appropriation of the Parliament; in other words, telling us to butt out of inquiries of these corporatised animals.

PARA.TAB: This is simply intolerable. This Government is moving further in that direction, taking away the scrutiny that is absolutely essential, as has been evidenced in other States, and preventing this Parliament, particularly this Senate, exercising the scrutiny that is absolutely vital.
The Auditor-General, recognising that the Parliament has taken note of the same sorts of concerns he expressed about wool, concludes by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament did correct the matter and I again ask the Parliament to consider the implications of the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill for its future ability to scrutinise that proper care is taken of taxpayers' funds.

We say amen to that. My view is that we should not countenance more corporatising by this Government unless there will be privatising. In the past we have taken the view, `Oh well, it is setting up the system and making it easier for us to come in and privatise, as is our policy'. The more I see of this halfway house resting in this no-man's land of no accountability, of preventing our proper questioning, the more I am concerned about where it is leading us. I believe, from the experience of disastrous Labor State governments, that it is not good enough to say, `At least we are moving in the right direction'. If the Government is not going to do it properly, it should not do it at all. I think the Auditor-General's warnings are very sound. I totally support him and I ask the Government to take note of the report and amend the legislation accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament and the Australian people should question why this Hawke-led ALP Government does so much, so insidiously, to attack the role of the Auditor-General and his accountability to this Parliament. I mention three principal areas: the restraint of resources; the withdrawal of mandate; and subjecting the Australian National Audit Office to an extensive number of inquiries, all of which have vindicated the Auditor-General's operations and praised him for the professional manner in which he has discharged his responsibilities from an inadequate resource base.

PARA.TAB: I call on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is now in the chamber, to table in this Parliament the articles and memorandum of association in order that an appropriate debate can take place in relation to the Bill coming before the Senate next week, No. 18 on the Notice Paper, the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991. Without that, I believe that we will not be able fully to appreciate the difficulties that this Parliament perceives in relation to what this Government has done.

What this Government has really done is anticipate this Senate's action. The Government was aware of the action of this Senate in relation to a number of earlier Bills—for example, the Wool Realisation Corporation Bill where we restored the mandate of the Australian National Audit Office. But on this occasion, before the Bill has passed through the Parliament, I understand—and I hope I will be corrected—that the Government has already appointed an auditor. This would put the private sector auditor in a most embarrassing position because the Government has jumped the gun, despite the fact that this legislation has not yet passed through parliament.

What responsibility does the Government have? This body has not yet been incorporated—it has not been established because the approval has not gone through the Parliament. Yet the Government has taken action to appoint an auditor, contrary to what I believe will be the intentions of this Senate.

On 17 June 1991 we spoke in response to the Auditor-General's report No. 35. In that earlier report, the Auditor-General also expressed concern about the removal of accountability and the weakening of parliament's role in the scrutiny of and reporting on activities of a public sector enterprise. It is a concern with which I concur today, as I did then.

I remind the Senate of the recommendation of the famous Public Accounts Committee report 296 in the production of which I took a significant part. It was a report that the Government basically accepted. It was not only endorsed by the Committee, but also by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration; by a subsequent review of the Auditor-General's Office by a Mr T.A. Sheridan, a prominent South Australian State Government auditor; and by the independent auditor appointed by the Government itself. I remind the Senate that, in report No. 296, the Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Act 1901 be amended to require the Auditor-General to be appointed the external auditor of all government companies.
This is a government company. It continued:

Private sector audit firms and partnerships which are the external auditors of government companies would continue until their appointments expire, whereupon the Auditor-General would become the company's external Auditor.

The Government on this occasion has jumped the gun; it has anticipated a decision of this Parliament. We find a government agreeing with this recommendation yet, in this instance of the National Rail Corporation, it has chosen to ignore its own recommendations. Apparently, even before the Bill has been passed through this chamber, the Government has appointed a private sector auditor. I commiserate with that private sector auditor for the position in which he now finds himself.

PARA.TAB: This action by the Government has resulted in an unprecedented move by the Auditors-General of five States joining together with the Auditor-General for Australia, Mr John Taylor, in support of this report warning of an erosion in the ability to scrutinise the activities of a public sector company. In fact, the public sector in the last few years has fared remarkably well, because we have not had the sorts of scenes that have been witnessed in the private sector with so many people losing so much money. I think that is testimony to the work of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General said in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: It is extraordinary, given the results of similar attempts in some other administrations, that this company should be able to avoid accountability mechanisms (including appointment of an Auditor-General) which are properly designed to protect the interests of Ministers, the Parliament and the taxpayers.

I believe this statement has the full endorsement of the Senate. Based on a profile of entities audited by the Australian National Audit Office, commercialisation in the Commonwealth sphere generally has taken, is taking or potentially could take place in departmental commercial undertakings where we have nearly $957m in assets and 11,000 employees. So we are talking about a very significant enterprise; an enterprise which the Auditor-General has the capability, in terms of professional standards and staff, to handle. At this point, given the late hour, I seek leave to speak again so that Senator Chapman may make a contribution.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that this Government never learns. It was only five months ago, in June, that the Auditor-General urgently produced Audit Report No. 35 of 1991, entitled Potential Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament—Australian Wool Realisation Commission and Australian Wool Corporation, which referred to the provisions in those two pieces of enabling legislation whereby an external auditor was going to be appointed to those two bodies to do the work which correctly should have been undertaken by the Auditor-General. In that report of last June the Auditor-General, in expressing his concern, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hope this is an oversight which will be corrected, rather than a reflection of a change in Government attitude to the role of the Parliament and the ANAO.

Of course it was corrected by the Senate because the coalition and the Australian Democrats combined to amend those two pieces of legislation relating to the wool industry to ensure that the responsibility was returned to the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Yet today, just as urgently, the Auditor-General has provided Audit Report No. 16 of 1991-92 entitled Accountability off the Rails—the National Rail Corporation Limited—Erosion of the Accountability to the Parliament. The purpose of this report is to draw attention to the fact that yet again, as with that earlier legislation, the Government is providing for a private sector auditor—and in fact it seems as though it has already appointed, prior to the legislation passing this Parliament, a private sector auditor—to undertake the work that correctly should be done by the Auditor-General.

So it would seem that this is not a mistake on the part of the Government, as the Auditor-General expressed the hope that it was when it was first done five months ago. In fact, it is a deliberate policy of this Government; it is a direct attack on this Parliament's role in the scrutiny and reporting of the activities of public sector enterprises. In his letter accompanying this report, which is incorporated into the report, the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that I should have to report in this way within six months of a similar report on the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation.

So there we see the lines drawn as far as accountability and responsibility are concerned.
