Whatever its commercial charter may be, the National Rail Corporation remains a public sector enterprise—an enterprise which is funded by the taxpayer. Replacing the Auditor-General with a private sector auditor involves removing appropriate accountability for that organisation.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate of the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament in its report No. 296, where it recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Act 1901 be amended to require the Auditor-General to be appointed the external auditor of all Government companies. Private sector firms and partnerships which are the external auditors of Government companies would continue until their appointments expired, whereupon the Auditor-General would become the company's external auditor.

The latter part of that recommendation was obviously dealing with pre-existing government business enterprises, but the essence of this recommendation is that new enterprises being established, such as this Rail Corporation, should in fact have the Auditor-General appointed at the outset. Of course, that recommendation was endorsed by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It was also endorsed by a subsequent review of the Auditor-General's Office by Mr T.A. Sheridan and by the independent auditor appointed by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Senator Chapman—I seek the leave of the Senate to continue my remarks with regard to the Auditor-General's report.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate, and I thank my colleagues. As I was saying, the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts were endorsed by other very important individuals and organisations.

PARA.TAB: But, most importantly, the recommendation of this Committee was accepted by this very Government. In its tabled response to the Joint Committee report, the Government indicated that the Auditor-General was to be the sole auditor of all government owned or controlled entities subject to exemptions by the Minister for Finance in special circumstances. In fact, I understand that the legislative provisions in the proposed new legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901 include a provision which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General is to be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth agencies and entities, except where the Minister for Finance has determined that an entity may make other audit arrangements. The Minister for Finance may not make a determination to grant an exemption unless he has first consulted the Auditor-General.

This new audit legislation is still to see the light of day. It has not yet been presented to this Parliament. Perhaps this is yet a further example of the mismanagement of this Government which we see with regard to finances generally and with regard to government business enterprises in particular. Either it is mismanagement in that situation or else it is a very Machiavellian delay to allow this National Rail Corporation to avoid proper scrutiny by the responsibility for auditing being given to the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General is the linchpin of public administration. If the system of auditing by the Auditor-General breaks down, then the system of public accountability breaks down. The Auditor-General is the essential link between this Parliament and government business enterprises. Commercialisation of government activities does not remove this necessity.

It is worth referring to another report on this issue, the November 1989 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into government companies. With regard to the nature and function of audit, the report of that Committee makes the following statement under the heading `Audit is not a service to management':

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the fashion for a move away from audit by the Auditor-General appears to be based on a misunderstanding of the role of an auditor. The purpose of audit is to provide an independent report on management, not a service to it. Management freedom should apply to management functions but the appointment of the auditor is the prerogative of the owners, not managers.

In other words, as far as government business enterprises are concerned in general, and this National Rail Corporation in particular, the responsibility for audit reporting is to the owners—that is, to the Government in the first instance, but, more importantly, to the taxpayers, because the taxpayers are the owners of government business enterprises. It is this Parliament which is the representative of those owners, the taxpayers, and it is to this Parliament that that reporting should be done, and it should be within the responsibility of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: The only ground for removing from the Auditor-General the responsibility for ensuring accountability is where there is complete privatisation of a former government body. Obviously, in that situation taxpayers' funds are no longer involved; it has become a fully private sector organisation with private shareholders. In that case it is up to those private shareholders to determine whom the auditor will be. So long as taxpayers' funds are involved, the Auditor-General should have that auditing and reporting responsibility.

One can only question the motives of a Government in removing the responsibility of the Auditor-General in circumstances other than full privatisation. In other words, in the circumstances relating to this National Rail Corporation it can only be regarded as a deliberate weakening of parliamentary scrutiny. Therefore, I trust that this Parliament and in particular this Senate will take notice of all of the issues raised in Audit Report No. 16 of 1991-92 with regard to the National Rail Corporation when the legislation comes before this chamber next week.

I will just refer in summary to two of the issues, the two which the Auditor-General raises in particular. In referring to the agreement between the various States and the Commonwealth for the establishment of the National Rail Corporation, the Auditor-General says that there are issues which are fundamental to public accountability. Firstly, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Corporation will be entirely publicly funded, it is intended that the Corporation will operate under the provisions of the Corporations Law as a strictly commercial corporation at arms-length from the Government. There is no legislative requirement for the Corporation to report to the Parliaments of the Commonwealth or the States (the taxpayers' representatives).
Secondly, he goes on:
Despite the fact that it is Commonwealth Government policy—
as I have already mentioned—

that the Auditor-General be the sole external auditor of Commonwealth-owned or—controlled entities, it is understood that a private-sector auditor has been appointed as the Corporation's auditor under the Corporations Law.

The report then goes on to spell out in detail the specific concerns which the Auditor-General has about those two aspects of the establishment of the National Rail Corporation, as it is established under the legislation which will be debated next week.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I trust this chamber will see fit to amend that legislation next week so that the Auditor-General resumes the responsibility for the auditing of this organisation and, therefore, accountability to this Parliament will be retained effectively—as indeed it should be.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Equal Employment Opportunities

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a matter in relation to equal employment opportunity as it is practised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Within the very large group of people who are interested in the extent to which the Government practises what it preaches in the equal employment opportunity area, Foreign Affairs and Trade as a department is frequently the subject of discussion. Of course, that is not to say that other departments do not enjoy such a deplorable reputation, but Foreign Affairs and Trade certainly has to be in the top group in that area.

PARA.TAB: A matter has come to my attention which relates to a Mrs Sue Boswell, a constituent of Mr Sinclair. I want to say at the outset that I am aware that proceedings have been issued in relation to this matter and, therefore, I want to be somewhat careful in what I say; but I am not of the view that simply because proceedings have been issued there is nothing I can say about this matter, nor am I of the view that there is nothing that the Government ought to be saying in response in this place to queries about it.

Mrs Boswell is unhappy—that is perhaps an understatement—with the treatment she maintains she has had from the Department. This evening I would like to put some allegations, which are public allegations on the record, and invite the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to seek a response from the Department. If that response is forthcoming we can then examine it.

The allegations are basically these. Mrs Boswell was subjected to an unprecedented two-year probation period in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. That is apparently quite extraordinary. I am not someone who is—to use a colloquial expression—full bottle on the rules and regulations governing Public Service employment and the progression there through but, as I understand it, a two-year probation period is quite extraordinary. It is further alleged that the Department failed to follow the Public Service guidelines in relation to this probation period, long as it was, and that during this probation period she was subjected to quite unusual procedures that were applied to none of her colleagues.

Thirdly, there is an allegation that the Department found by its own inquiry that a supervisor had reported unfairly on her; that this supervisor had a direct and indirect influence over her throughout that entire probation period; and that this supervisor admitted sending her messages, shall I say, not directly associated with her work and which she took to be a form of harassment. This is the third allegation: here was a supervisor that the Department has apparently established reported on her unfairly, at least in one respect; that this supervisor had direct and indirect influence over her throughout the entire probation period; and that this supervisor admitted sending her messages not related to her work, which she took to be harassment.

There is also a fourth allegation that a senior departmental investigation officer destroyed certain papers that Mrs Boswell sought for the appeal that she is undertaking, or has undertaken, to the Merit Protection and Review Agency. As I understand it, the material that has been destroyed is a record of interview with another officer of the Department. I do not recall now whether that interview reflected positively or adversely on Mrs Boswell but that is really not the point. The point is that an interview was done as part of some sort of assessment process, and the record of that interview has not been kept. The allegation is that the record of that interview has been destroyed by the interviewer.

That is an unusual process. If that has happened, irrespective of the outcome of that interview, we deserve an explanation of why that sort of thing is allowed to happen and what has happened as a consequence of it. Has it just been ignored? Was this some sort of aberrant practice that everyone agrees should not have happened but about which we say, no, we will not worry about it because we think it will not happen again? I am not raising these matters just because they relate to Mrs Boswell. I have never met Mrs Boswell. I am relating these matters to the chamber tonight because I think it is important, as a matter of principle, to know how these matters are generally dealt with by a department.

I further understand that the Department denied Mrs Boswell her right to have an investigation under regulation 83 of the Public Service Regulations before her employment was terminated. What that means is that, if that maximum probation period had expired, Mrs Boswell would have been automatically permanently appointed to the Public Service. But just before the expiration of that period, Mrs Boswell, as I am informed, sought an investigation under regulation 83. We do not need to be bright to understand that if she sought that investigation very close to the expiration of her probation period then that investigation may well, and probably would, have carried on past the expiration of that period and she would have been a permanent appointee. The significance of her having been denied that investigation is that the time period of her probation was not allowed to expire; in other words, she was dismissed before that happened.

The allegations were further put to me that the Department had refused as of a couple of weeks ago—it may now have complied but in any event had not in what one would regard as an appropriate time—to furnish reasons required under section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

The Department has failed to respond to a written application for compensation for domestic dislocation which the Merit Protection Review Agency recommended be made. As I understand it, Mrs Boswell moved here with the expectation of getting the job. After the expiry of a significant period of time, that expectation obviously grew. One would have thought that if her performance was unsatisfactorily, and the Department was able to make up its mind, it would have dismissed her immediately. I would have no qualms with that at all. If the Department had decided that she was unsatisfactory within one week, two weeks, one month, two months, three months, four months, five months or six months, well and good—get rid of her. I am certainly not in the category of people who think that someone should be taken on who, on their merit, does not deserve the job.

To allow the assessment of that merit to go on and on, well beyond the period that the Department would let it go on for anyone else, and then to use some sort of technical mechanism to deprive that person of the opportunity of being appointed in a fair and reasonable time, seems to beg some sort of explanation.

I pass these on as allegations that have been made to me. I have made no further investigation of the allegations. I believe they have been made in good faith. The allegations certainly fit in with the sorts of allegations that have been made in the past about the conduct of the management of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. They are not out of place. I am not surprised by that. I ask that the Parliamentary Secretary take these matters to the Minister and seek some sort of explanation of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will take only a few minutes of the Senate's time. I must place on record, as have my colleagues, the Opposition's condemnation of the decision set out in the Auditor-General's report No. 16, entitled Accountability off the Rails. I understand I needed to seek leave to discuss this matter as it is still on the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: I think this is one of those benchmark questions which have to be fought at every turn. One of the most important reports of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts was entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. If the report had one strong message which had to stand out almost above all others it was that the Auditor-General must have mandate wherever the public purse is concerned. Very simply, that means that where there is a vehicle—be it corporate or otherwise—which is funded from the public purse the Auditor-General must be the auditor.

The reason for this is very simple. There is a distinction to be drawn between investment in commercial operations and public operations. Those who invest in private operations take their hard-earned after-tax money and make a decision as to whether they will invest in a corporation. Once they have invested in that corporation, if they do not like what it does, they can dispose of their shares, get up at the annual meeting—they have all sorts of ways—and express a view about the management and other matters concerning that corporation, or they can vote with their feet and simply get out of it.

There is no such option available when the entity is in the public sector. The money is taken from taxpayers compulsorily. The decision as to how that investment is made is made by the executive of government and finally appropriated by the Parliament. There is no way in the world that an individual taxpayer has any say over where his or her money is invested in that corporation and whether it remains in that corporation. Therefore, the whole concept of accountability in the public sector is totally different from the concept of accountability in the private sector. That distinction must remain paramount in deciding who is the auditor. That is why the Joint Committee of Public Accounts said that the Auditor-General must maintain a mandate.

When the Bill is finally presented, we will have an opportunity to see whether we can rectify this position, as we have done with a previous piece of legislation. If my memory serves me correctly, it was the AIDC legislation where we last effected that amendment. I only wanted to take a few minutes to place my concern on the record and, perhaps, to forewarn. I certainly will have a lot more to say about the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the past month news headlines of several newspapers heralded triumphantly the fact that inflation in Australia had hit a 20-year low. The consumer price index for the September quarter was only 0.6 per cent. On this figure, inflation for the year was now only 3.8 per cent. Because of this low inflation factor, I would like to address my remarks tonight to the plight of provisional taxpayers whose incomes are deemed to increase by 10 per cent for provisional tax purposes. I use this opportunity to call on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) and his Government to take immediate steps to reduce what is known as the tax uplift factor to a more reasonable figure.

PARA.TAB: Provisional taxpayers pay their tax liability calculated in advance of their earnings. Customarily, three broad classes of people are provisional taxpayers. They include, firstly, the owners of small businesses operating as sole proprietors or in partnership. They could incorporate under existing rules but generally do not have sufficient funds or commercial sophistication to take that step. Secondly, they include self-employed professionals who are prohibited by the rules of their profession from incorporating. Thirdly, there are employed and retired persons who earn their income from investments.

Over the past decade wages and incomes as a result of inflation have steadily increased each year. To ensure that the provisional taxpayer does not underpay his taxation liability, the Australian Taxation Office calculates the provisional taxpayer's income at an increased rate. It has been at a minimum of 10 per cent, and somewhat higher, each year. Simply put, this means that, if taxable income in year one is $50,000, the provisional tax for the next year is calculated on an income of $55,000—that is, if the 10 per cent uplift factor applies in that particular year.

I was concerned—and I spoke strongly earlier—about the Government fixing this uplift factor at 10 per cent. This low inflation factor, as revealed in the September quarter, is a vindication of the stand that I took then and I take tonight. The uplift factor of 10 per cent is based on the fact that for many years Australia has had high inflation, something in excess of 10 per cent. In addition, provisional taxpayers who are self-employed tend to earn more money with the passage of time. Neither of those assumptions is correct at present when Australia is in such a severe recession, with the consequence that provisional incomes especially are severely down.

I mentioned that our inflation rate has dropped dramatically. Therefore, it is appropriate and not unreasonable for a much lower inflation factor to be applied. Takings have dropped so much that during 1990-91 Australia reported a record 13,000 bankruptcies, with over 50 per cent occurring in the last 12 months. It is interesting to note that in 1982-83 there was less than half this number of bankruptcies—in fact, only 5,151—in Australia. The average weekly earnings only increased from $562 in August of last year to $569 in May 1991. There was a negative quarterly change of 2.7 per cent from February to May of this year.

Consequently, I repeat, I am calling on this Government to immediately reduce the uplift factor that has been applied to provisional taxpayers for this year. The combination of reduced inflation and decreased takings means that the uplift factor for this year should be almost nil.

Further, this reduced inflation rate and decreased takings is not something that has occurred only in the last month. Rather, there has been a steady decline over the whole year. Therefore, when the Commissioner of Taxation released in late July a media release announcing that assessments for paying provisional tax for 1991-92 will be issued from 1 July 1991, the media release assumed that the uplift factor of 10 per cent would remain unchanged. Of course, it remains unchanged unless changed by this Parliament. This was the dictate of this Government with the support of the Democrats.

The early issuing of provisional tax assessments will naturally benefit those taxpayers who will receive an early refund, but not everybody is entitled to a refund. The fact that the media release assumes that there will be no change in the uplift factor rather surprises and, I must say, disappoints me. Perhaps the ATO was privy to some private knowledge that the economy was going to improve, but the figures out today do not really suggest that. If the Government does not drop the uplift factor soon many of the provisional taxpayers will have to vary their liability. It is putting taxpayers to additional expense and possibly additional liability to penalties. So there are problems for a lot of people, particularly the elderly, in pursuing this avenue.

In many cases taxpayers are unwise to lodge such a variation without obtaining professional advice. This costs them time as well as expense, money which many of these people do not have in difficult times. Many businesses and many people in these straitened times cannot afford professional advice. The New Accountant newspaper declared only recently that accountancy appointments had dropped to their lowest level since the last recession of 1982. The prospects for senior executives looked particularly bleak with more and more of the accounting firms shedding jobs. As well, even if the provisional taxpayer does obtain professional advice, there is still the possibility that the taxpayer's estimate will underestimate the income for the current year by 10 per cent or more. An underestimate may result in a penalty tax at the annual rate of 20 per cent. This Government should have announced during the Budget that a change in the uplift factor was necessary, because that was the ideal time for such an announcement. I regret that that announcement was not made.

Before I conclude I would like to highlight a section of provisional taxpayers who have been severely hurt by the uplift factor being set at 10 per cent. These are retirees who earn income from investments. This is the third category that I mentioned earlier. A retiree's investments are normally so structured that they receive, hopefully, a livable income. However, the retiree is hit on two counts. Firstly, the interest rate on savings and long term loans has been steadily decreasing over the past 12 months. It is now very difficult to invest at 10 per cent or more. Secondly, he is not in business and his investments are not increasing; therefore it cannot be assumed that his income increases by 10 per cent. In fact, in many cases it will be less than the previous year's financial income. Yet the ATO assumes that the retiree's income has increased by 10 per cent. There is no distinction between the various classes by this Government or by the Tax Office. I therefore believe that these people deserve special consideration and should be excluded from having the uplift factor applied to them, maybe on a permanent basis.

However, let us not be distracted from the pressing need at hand. If this Government is concerned at how people are hurting in this recession, this is one way—with very little effort—in which the Parliamentary Secretary can give significant relief to a large sector of taxpayers in Australia. I believe that a failure by the Government to act promptly will cause scepticism that there is not a commitment to lower inflation; at the same time the Government can help the needy, particularly the aged, and also those struggling businesses whose incomes have dramatically declined. Now is the time to act. The 10 per cent provisional tax uplift factor needs to be reduced. I look forward to the Parliamentary Secretary's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day for Australian democracy when a political party resorts to intimidation to stop the people of Queensland having a say on political matters. I am appalled by the reported action of the ALP in Mount Isa in reporting a Mount Isa businessman with a franchise to the `franchisor' company head office in an attempt to prevent the businessman from explaining aspects of John Hewson's Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: I have nothing but contempt for the ALP and its attempt to interfere with the livelihood of a Mount Isa businessman who was prepared, as a service to the people of Mount Isa, to allow his business office to be used as a post box for those wanting to ask questions and seek clarification about the Fightback package. I will read from a letter from Mr Rob Hulls, MP, the Federal member for Kennedy. The final paragraph of the letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: There are many questions on the goods and services tax proposal that Mount Isa residents would no doubt like answered however it concerns me that you may be unaware of your company's association with such a blatantly political exercise.

It is obvious that Mr Hulls has been mortally wounded by the Fightback package. He will stop at nothing to attempt to silence his opponents. The action of threatening people's employment because of their political views is reminiscent of the sort of thing that happened in Germany during the 1930s that led to the ascendancy of Hitler and the Nazis. It is the dirtiest Mafia-type tactic used to silence opposition. This comes on top of the ALP's legislation to severely limit free speech, designed, again, to prevent the people of Mount Isa receiving details of John Hewson's package.

PARA.TAB: What can Mr Hulls possibly have to fear from giving the people of Mount Isa the opportunity to raise queries, criticism and questions about the Fightback package? Why is he so afraid of people learning more about the Fightback package? I find Mr Hulls's action despicable and un-Australian. It deserves the contempt of all Australians, no matter what their political affiliations. The moment Australians are intimidated for their own political beliefs or freedom of association with a party of their choice, we are back in the days of Joseph Stalin and Adolf Hitler. Mr Hulls knows he will lose his seat at the next election. He is prepared to resort to any desperate action, including intimidation, to try to silence his opponents.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Australian Capital Territory—Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer) (11.03 p.m.)—There were several points raised on the adjournment to which specific response was requested. Senator Chapman and Senator Bishop used this forum to continue the debate that had been held on the Auditor-General's report and I will not comment on that. Senator Vanstone raised a matter about which I know absolutely nothing, but she asked me to refer it to the relevant Minister, and I will do that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson spoke at length about the issue of inflation and provisional tax. I am sure I am as pleased as he is—perhaps more pleased—about the success so far in achieving a low rate of inflation, and I can tell him that there is better to come. But I have to remind him that the law as it stands in relation to a fixed rate of provisional tax was not the Government's preferred position. We sought flexibility in setting that rate and were denied it by this chamber. That is why the 10 per cent rate is set in the legislation—not because we wanted it, but because we could not get the flexibility we wanted passed by the Senate.

The people who are in the particular situation of concern to which Senator Watson refers should remember, firstly, that that is the case. Secondly, they should be made aware, as Senator Watson correctly outlined, of the options they have if their income is declining. I understand that falling interest rates—desirable as they are overall—do have an impact on the income of people who rely upon interest rates for their income. I understand that that obviously is the case, but, given the dramatic nature of the fall in interest rates over the last 12 months, I suspect that those individuals will have available to them options to adjust their tax obligations.

I was going to just let Senator Macdonald's remarks pass because they are part of the political give and take between Senator Macdonald and Mr Hulls. Mr Hulls is perfectly capable of taking care of himself and Senator Macdonald. But I was appalled that a series of overblown and quite inappropriate insults and remarks were thrown about.
If the democratic process is going to be valued, words like `Nazi'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the sort of thing they did.
—Well, I include Senator Bishop in this then. I would not have thought that she would have stooped to it. But, really, the word `Nazi' is not a word that ought lightly to be thrown around.
—Nor `rabble'.

—If Senator Panizza thinks `rabble' and `Nazi' are equivalent, that is his judgment. The word `Nazi' has some special and important implications. To throw it around at all belittles the user and not the person accused. But to use it about another member of parliament in these circumstances is entirely inappropriate, in poor taste and shows poor judgment. I think `Mafia' is a category lower. But it is equally undesirable and inappropriate, and reflects upon the user, not the person against whom it is made.

PARA.TAB: We had allegations about things being un-Australian and whatever. I know nothing about the matter in hand and I cannot deal with it. As I said initially, I would otherwise have considered the matter to be one properly for debate between Mr Hulls and Senator Macdonald. But I think the language that was used was entirely inappropriate and the Senate is not enhanced by that sort of cheap shot.

The issues are entitled to be debated. I take no exception to the right of Senator Macdonald to come in here and criticise the actions of anybody, including Mr Hulls or any of my other colleagues, to refer to information given to him with which he disagrees and to speak as vigorously as he chooses. But I think that sort of allegation is not well made. It does not enhance the Parliament or the reputation of Senator Macdonald.

This is not a matter about which I need to take any further action. I am sure that Mr Hulls is capable of taking care of it for himself. I reiterate that I will refer the matter raised by Senator Vanstone.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since the transfer of commercial television transmission to UHF band, have residents in certain areas surrounding Cairns been unable to receive these services even with the aid of a high mast, high-gain antenna and masthead amplifier.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of an article in the July edition of Pacific News Bulletin (newsletter of Nuclear Free and Independent Pacific) which says fifteen leading scientists from France, UK, USA, Germany, Japan, New Zealand and the South Pacific have published an open letter to the French Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, to support Greenpeace's demand for an international independent scientific investigation at Mururoa with full data and access to sampling.

(2) Is the Minister aware that Cesium-134 was found in plankton in the waters near Mururoa but outside the 12-mile exclusion zone in 1990 which suggests leakage from the atoll and that when a scientific team from Greenpeace tried to take samples within the 12-mile zone in December l990 they were arrested.
(3) Does the Minister support Greenpeace's call for an international independent scientific inquiry at Mururoa.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The Greenpeace sponsored report "Radioactivity in Plankton Outside the 12-Mile Exclusion Zone of the French Nuclear Test Site" (by N Buske, SEARCH Technical Services, June 1991) claims that Cesium-134 was measured in plankton selectively collected in international waters some 12-14 miles down current off the French nuclear test site at Mururoa. The report also states that after Cesium-134 was detected in plankton, Greenpeace scientific parties entering French territorial waters were arrested, precluding verification of the activity and source of the radioactivity.

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation examined the report and concluded that it contains methodological inadequacies to the extent that little confidence can be placed in the reported planktonic radionuclide concentrations.

(3) An international independent scientific study of the radioactivity in waters off the French Pacific Test Centre was conducted recently under the auspices of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The IAEA International Laboratory of Marine Radioactivity (ILMR) Report No 48 of 1991 provides a summary of radionuclide measurements of sea-water and plankton samples collected in March 1991. These measurements were conducted by three internationally respected laboratories. The samples were collected in the presence of a bailiff, providing legal guarantee that the IAEA protocol was properly carried out, and the analyses were conducted concurrently to enable cross-comparisons of measurements.

The IAEA study found that, contrary to Greenpeace's claim, Cesium-134 could not be detected in plankton or sea-water collected near the territorial boundary outside Mururoa Atoll (including the area where Greenpeace said it found Cesium-134).
I consider the Greenpeace request for an independent international scientific inquiry to have been met by the IAEA study.
